question: If the half-life time, \(t_{1/2}\), of the initiator AIBN in an unknown solvent is 22.6 h at 60 \({}^{\circ}\)C, calculate its dissociation rate constant, \(k_{d}\), in units of reciprocal seconds.
context:
**1-4**: **(a)** Calculate the \(z\)-average molecular weight, \(\widetilde{M}_{z}\), of the discrete molecular weight distribution described in Example Problem 1.1.
_Solution_
\[\widetilde{M}_{x}=\frac{\sum\limits_{j=1}^{3}{W_{i}{M_{i}}^{2}}}{\sum\limits_{i=1 }^{3}{W_{i}{M_{i}}}}=\frac{1(10,000)^{2}+2\big{(}50,000\big{)}^{2}+2\big{(}100, 000\big{)}^{2}}{1\big{(}10,000\big{)}+2\big{(}50,000\big{)}+2\big{(}100,000 \big{)}}=80,968}\]
**(b)** Calculate the \(z\)-average molecular weight, \(\widetilde{M}_{x}\), of the continuous molecular weight distribution shown in Example 1.2.
_Solution_
\[\widetilde{M}_{z}=\frac{\int_{10^{3}}^{10^{4}}{M^{2}dM}}{\int_{10^{3}}^{10^{4} }{MdM}}=\frac{\Big{(}{M^{3}}\Big{/}3\Big{)}_{10^{3}}^{10^{4}}}{\Big{(}{M^{2}} \Big{/}2\Big{)}_{10^{3}}^{10^{4}}}=66,673}\]
**(c)** Obtain an expression for the \(z\)-average degree of polymerization, \(\widetilde{X}_{z}\), for the Flory distribution described in Example 1.3.
Solution
\[\vec{X}_{x}=\frac{\sum\limits_{1}^{\infty}X^{2}W(X)}{\sum\limits_{1}^{\infty}XW (X)}=\frac{\sum\limits_{1}^{\infty}X^{3}p^{x-1}}{\sum\limits_{1}^{\infty}X^{2} p^{x-1}}\]
Let
\[A=\sum\limits_{1}^{\infty}Xp^{x-1}=1+2p+3p^{2}+\cdots=\frac{1}{1-p}\quad\text{ (geometric series)}\]
\[B=\sum\limits_{1}^{\infty}X^{2}p^{x-1}=1+2^{2}p+3^{2}\ p^{2}+\cdots\]
\[C=\sum\limits_{1}^{\infty}X^{3}p^{x-1}=1+2^{3}\ p+3^{2}\ p^{2}+\cdots\]
Can show that \(B\big{(}1-p\big{)}=A\big{(}1+p\big{)}\)
Therefore \(B=\frac{1+p}{\big{(}1-p\big{)}^{3}}\)
Write \(C\big{(}1-p\big{)}=\sum\limits_{x=1}^{\infty}3X^{2}p^{x-1}-\sum\limits_{x=1}^ {\infty}3Xp^{x-1}+\sum\limits_{x=1}^{\infty}p^{x-1}=3B-3A^{2}+\frac{1}{1-p}= \frac{1+4p+p^{2}}{\big{(}1-p\big{)}^{3}}\)
Therefore \(C=\frac{1+4p+p^{2}}{\big{(}1-p\big{)}^{4}}\)
and finally \(\vec{X}_{x}=\frac{\sum\limits_{1}^{\infty}X^{3}p^{x-1}}{\sum \limits_{1}^{\infty}X^{2}p^{x-1}}=\frac{C}{B}=\frac{1+4p+p^{2}\big{(}1-p\big{)} ^{3}}{\big{(}1-p\big{)}^{4}\big{(}1+p\big{)}}=\frac{1+4p+p^{2}}{\big{(}1-p \big{)}\big{(}1+p\big{)}}=\frac{1+4p+p^{2}}{1-p^{2}}\)
\[\vec{M}_{x}=M_{\circ}\vec{X}_{z}\]
## Chapter 2
2.1If the half-life time, \(t_{1/2}\), of the initiator AIBN in an unknown solvent is 22.6 h at 60\({}^{\circ}\)C, calculate its dissociation rate constant, \(k_{\text{d}}\), in units of reciprocal seconds.
Solution
\(\big{[}1\big{]}=\big{[}1\big{]}_{\circ}\exp\big{(}-k_{\text{d}}t\big{)}\)
\(\big{[}1\big{]}_{\circ}=\frac{1}{2}=\exp\big{(}-k_{\text{d}}t\big{)}\)\(-k_{d}t=\ln\left(\left\{1/2\right\}\right)=-0.693\)
\(k_{d}=\frac{0.693}{t}=\frac{0.693}{22.6\ \mathrm{h}}\ 3600\ \mathrm{s}=8.52\times 10^{-5}\ \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)

question: Rate of initiation at \(1\ \mathrm{min}\) and at \(16.6\ \mathrm{h}\)
context:
**2.2**: Styrene is polymerized by free-radical mechanism in solution. The initial monomer and initiator concentrations are \(1\ M\) (molar) and \(0.001\ M\), respectively. At the polymerization temperature of \(60^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), the initiator efficiency is \(0.30\). The rate constants at the polymerization temperature are as follows:
\(k_{d}=1.2\times 10^{-5}\ \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
\(k_{p}=176\ M^{1}\ \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
\(k_{t}=7.2\times 10^{7}\ M^{1}\ \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
Given this information, determine the following:
**(a)** Rate of initiation at \(1\ \mathrm{min}\) and at \(16.6\ \mathrm{h}\)
_Solution_
\(R_{i}=2/k_{d}\left[1\right]=2\left(0.30\right)\left(1.2\times 10^{-5}\right) \left[1\right]=7.2\times 10^{-6}\left[1\right]\)
\(\left[1\right]=\left[1_{o}\right]\exp\left(-k_{d}t\right)\)
at \(1\ \mathrm{min}\):
\(\left[1\right]=0.001\left(0.9993\right)=0.0009993\ M\)
\(R_{i}=\left(7.2\times 10^{-6}\right)\left(0.0009993\right)=7.19\times 10^{-9} \ M\ \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
at \(16.6\ \mathrm{h}\):
\(\left[1\right]=0.001\left(0.488\right)=0.000488\ M\)
\(R_{i}=\left(7.2\times 10^{-6}\right)\left(0.000448\right)=3.51\times 10^{-9} \ M\ \ \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
**(b)** Steady-state free-radical concentration at \(1\ \mathrm{min}\)
_Solution_
\(\left[\mathrm{IM}_{x}\cdot\right]=\left(\frac{\mathit{f}_{k_{d}}}{k_{t}} \right)^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\left[1\right]^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\)
at \(1\ \mathrm{min}\):
\(\left[\mathrm{IM}_{x}\right]=\left[\frac{\left(0.30\right)\left(1.2\times 10^{-5 }\right)}{7.2\times 10^{7}}\right]^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\left(0.0009993 \right)^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}=7.08\times 10^{-9}\ M\)
**(c)** Rate of polymerization at \(1\ \mathrm{min}\)
_Solution_
\(R_{o}=k_{p}\left[\mathrm{IM}_{x}\cdot\right]\left[\mathrm{M}\right]\)
\(\left[\mathrm{M}\right]=\left[\mathrm{M}\right]_{o}\exp\left(-k_{p}\left[ \mathrm{IM}_{x}\cdot\right]t\right)=\left(1\right)\exp\left[-176\left(7.08 \times 10^{-9}\right)60\right]=0.9999\ \mathrm{M}\)
\(R_{o}=176\left(7.08\times 10^{-9}\right)\left(0.9999\right)=1.24\times 10^{-6} \ M\ \ \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
**(d)** Average free-radical lifetime, \(\tau\), at \(1\ \mathrm{min}\), where \(\tau\) is defined as the radical concentration divided by the rate of termination
_Solution_
\(\tau=\frac{\left[\mathrm{IM}_{x}\cdot\right]}{2k_{t}\left[\mathrm{IM}_{x} \cdot\right]^{2}}=\frac{1}{2k_{t}\left[\mathrm{IM}_{x}\cdot\right]}=\frac{1}{2 \left(7.2\times 10^{7}\right)\left(7.08\times 10^{-9}\right)}=0.981\ \mathrm{s}\)
[MISSING_PAGE_FAIL:9]
\[R_{\circ}=\frac{-d\left[\text{M}\right]}{dt}=k_{3}\left[\text{M}\right]\left[\text{ RM}_{n}\cdot\right]\]
steady state for \(\text{ RM}_{n}\cdot\) : \(k_{2}\left[\text{R}\cdot\right]\left[\text{M}\right]=k_{4}\left[\text{RM}_{n} \cdot\right]^{2}\) or \(\left[\text{RM}_{n}\cdot\right]=\left(\frac{k_{2}}{k_{4}}\left[\text{R}\cdot \right]\left[\text{M}\right]\right)^{\!\!/2}\) (eq. 2.3.1)
steady state for \(\left[\text{R}\cdot\right]\): \(k_{1}\left[\text{M}\right]\left[\text{D}\right]=k_{2}\left[\text{R}\cdot \right]\left[\text{M}\right]+k_{5}\left[\text{R}\cdot\right]\) or \(\left[\text{R}\cdot\right]=\frac{k_{1}\left[\text{M}\right]\left[\text{D} \right]}{k_{2}\left[\text{M}\right]+k_{5}}\) (eq. 2.3.2)
substituting eq. 2.3.2 into eq. 2.3.1, gives
\[\left[\text{RM}_{n}\cdot\right]=\left(\frac{k_{2}}{k_{4}}\frac{k_{1}\left[ \text{M}\right]^{2}\left[\text{D}\right]}{k_{2}\left[\text{M}\right]+k_{5}} \right)^{\!\!/2}\text{ and }\text{ }R_{\circ}=k_{3}\left[\text{M}\right]\left(\frac{k_{2}}{k_{4}}\frac{k_{1} \left[\text{M}\right]\left[\text{D}\right]^{2}}{k_{2}\left[\text{M}\right]+k_ {5}}\right)^{\!\!/2}\]
Letting \(\left[\text{D}\right]=1\) and \(k_{5}>>k_{2}\left[\text{M}\right]\), we have \(R_{\circ}=k_{3}\left(\frac{k_{1}k_{2}}{k_{4}k_{5}}\right)^{\!\!/2}\left[\text {M}\right]^{2}1^{\!\!/2}\) or \(R_{\circ}\propto\left[\text{M}\right]^{2}1^{\!\!/2}\)
_See_ G.K. Oster, G. Oster, & G. Prati, _JACS_**79**, 595 (1957).

question: What is the osmotic pressure (units of atm) of a 0.5 wt % solution of poly(methyl methacrylate) in acetonitrile at 45°C for which [η] = 4.8×10^(-3) M^0.5?
context:
**3.3**: **(a)** What is the osmotic pressure (units of atm) of a 0.5 wt % solution of poly(methyl methacrylate) ( \(\widetilde{M}_{n}=100,000\)) in acetonitrile (density, 0.7857 g cm-3) at 45\({}^{\circ}\)C for which [ \(\eta\)] = 4.8\(\times\)10\({}^{-3}\) M\({}^{0.5}\)?
_Solution_
The form of the Mark-Houwink-Sakurata equation shown above (see eq 3.101) indicates that for PMMA in acetonitrile \(a=0.5\) and, therefore, \(\Lambda_{2}=0\) (i.e., \(\theta\) solvent) and from eq. 3.85 we can write
\[\Pi=\frac{RTc}{\widetilde{\mathrm{M}}_{n}}=82.057\frac{\mathrm{atm~{}cm^{3}}} {\mathrm{mol~{}K}}318~{}\mathrm{K}\frac{0.5~{}\mathrm{g}}{100~{}\mathrm{cm^{3} }}\frac{\mathrm{mol}}{10^{5}~{}\mathrm{g}}=1.305\times 10^{-3}~{}\mathrm{atm}\]
**(b)** What is the osmotic head in units of cm?
_Solution_
From eq 3.88, we have
\[h=\frac{\Pi}{\rho g}=\frac{1.305\times 10^{-3}~{}\mathrm{atm~{}cm^{3}~{}s^{2}}} {0.7857~{}\mathrm{g}~{}9.80665~{}\mathrm{m}}\frac{1~{}\mathrm{kg}}{9.869\times 1 0^{-6}~{}\mathrm{atm~{}m~{}s^{2}}}\frac{1000~{}\mathrm{g}}{\mathrm{kg}}\frac{ \mathrm{m}^{2}}{10^{4}~{}\mathrm{cm}^{2}}=1.716~{}\mathrm{cm}\]
**(c)** Estimate the Flory interaction parameter for polysulfone in methylene chloride.
_Solution_
\[\chi_{12}\propto\left(\delta_{1}-\delta_{2}\right)^{2}\]
Table 3-3: \(\delta_{\mathrm{psF}}=9.92~{}\left(\mathrm{cal~{}cm^{-3}}\right)^{\!\!\!/2}\) and \(\delta_{\mathrm{CH_{2}Cl}}=9.92~{}\left(\mathrm{cal~{}cm^{-3}}\right)^{\!\!\!/2}\) and therefore \(\chi_{12}\approx 0\)
**(d)** Based upon your answer above, would you expect methylene chloride to be a good or poor solvent for polysulfone?
_Answer_
Good solvent (solubility parameters match).
### The osmotic pressure of two samples, A and B, of poly(vinyl pyridinium chloride)
were measured in different solvents. The following data were obtained:
\begin{tabular}{l l l} \multicolumn{3}{l}{**Osmotic Pressure Data in Distilled Water**} \\
**Sample** & \(\boldsymbol{c\) (g mL-1)} & \(\boldsymbol{\Pi\) (atm \(\boldsymbol{\times}\) 10\({}^{3}\))} \\ \hline A & 0.002 & 29 \\ A & 0.005 & 50 \\ B & 0.002 & 31 \\ B & 0.005 & 52 \\ \multicolumn{3}{l}{**Osmotic Pressure Data in 0.01 \(N\) Aqueous NaCl**} \\
**Sample** & \(\boldsymbol{c\) (g mL-1)} & \(\boldsymbol{\Pi\) (atm \(\boldsymbol{\times}\) 10\({}^{3}\))} \\ \hline A & 0.002 & 5 \\ A & 0.005 & 13 \\ B & 0.002 & 2 \\ B & 0.005 & 5.5 \\ \end{tabular}
This text is associated with Fried/Polymer Science and Technology, Third Edition (9780137039555) Copyright 2014, Pearson Education, Inc. Do not redistribute.
Discuss these results and account for any features that you consider anomalous.
_Solution_
\[\frac{\Pi}{c}=RT\bigg{(}\frac{1}{\overline{\mathrm{M}}_{\mathrm{n}}}+A_{2}c+ \cdots\bigg{)}\]
**Distilled Water**
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline
**Sample** & \(\boldsymbol{c}\) **( g mL-1)** & \(\boldsymbol{\Pi}\) **(atm x 103)** & \(\boldsymbol{\overline{\tau}}\) \\ \hline A & 0.002 & 29 & 14.5 \\ \hline A & 0.005 & 50 & 10.0 \\ \hline B & 0.002 & 31 & 15.5 \\ \hline B & 0.005 & 52 & 10.4 \\ \hline \end{tabular}

question: Calculate the molecular weight of PS using Mark-Houwink parameters of \(a=0.725\) and \(K=1.1\times 10^{-4}\) dL g\(^{-1}\).
context:
**3.5** The following viscosity data were obtained for solutions of polystyrene (PS) in toluene at 30\({}^{\circ}\)C:
\begin{tabular}{l c} \(\boldsymbol{c}\) **(g dL-1)** & \(\boldsymbol{t}\) **(s)** \\ \hline
0 & 65.8 \\
0.54 & 101.2 \\
1.08 & 144.3 \\
1.62 & 194.6 \\
2.16 & 257.0 \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Using this information, please do the following:
**(a)** Plot the reduced viscosity as a function of concentration
_Solution_
\[\frac{\eta_{\mathrm{s}}}{c}=\left[\eta\right]+k_{\mathrm{n}}\left[\eta \right]^{2}c\;\;\mathrm{where}\]
\[\eta_{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{\eta-\eta_{\mathrm{s}}}{\eta_{\mathrm{s}}}\approx \frac{t-t_{\mathrm{s}}}{t_{\mathrm{s}}}\]
\(t_{\mathrm{s}}=65.8\) s 
**(b)** Determine the intrinsic viscosity of this PS sample and the value of the Huggins constant, \(k_{\rm H}\)
_Solution_
From plot (\(R^{2}=0.9958\)); we can obtain the following:
From eq 3.103
\[\frac{\eta_{{}_{i}}}{c}=\left[\eta\right]+k_{{}_{H}}\left[\eta\right]^{2}c\]
the intercept gives \(\left[\eta\right]=0.8760\) dL g-1
and the slope (\(k_{\rm H}[\eta]\)) is 0.2130 which gives \(k_{{}_{\rm H}}=0.278\)
**(c)** Calculate the molecular weight of PS using Mark-Houwink parameters of \(a=0.725\) and \(K=1.1\times 10^{-4}\) dL g-
_Solution_
\(\left[\eta\right]=K\overline{M}_{{}_{\rm v}}{}^{a}\)
Substituting values, we have
\(0.876=\left(1.1\times 10^{-4}\right)\overline{M}_{{}_{\rm v}}{}^{0.725}\) or \(\overline{M}_{{}_{\rm v}}=240,350\)
Given that the molecular weight of a polystyrene (PS) repeating unit is 104 and that the carbon-carbon bond distance is 1.54 A, calculate the following:
**(a)** The mean-square end-to-end distance for a PS molecule of 1 million molecular weight assuming that the molecule behaves as a freely-rotating, freely-jointed, and volumeless chain. Assume that each link is equivalent to a single repeating unit of PS.
_Solution_\(n=\frac{10^{6}}{104}=9.62\times 10^{3}\)
\(l=2\left(1.54\ \mathrm{\AA}\right)=3.08\ \mathrm{\AA}\)
\(\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle=nl^{2}=9.13\times 10^{4}\ \mathrm{\AA^{2}}\)
**(b)** The unperturbed root-mean-square end-to-end distance, \(\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle_{0}\)\({}^{1/2}\), given the relationship for intrinsic viscosity, \(\left[\eta\right]\), of PS in a \(\theta\)solvent at 35\({}^{\circ}\)C as
\[\left[\eta\right]=8\times 10^{-4}\ M^{0.5}\]
where \(\left[\eta\right]\) is in units of dL g\({}^{1}\).
_Solution_
\(\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle_{o}=\left\langle\frac{\mathrm{M}\left[\eta \right]_{o}}{\mathrm{\Phi}}\right\rangle^{2/3}=\left[\frac{10^{6}\left(8\times 1 0^{-4}\right)\left(10^{6}\right)^{0.5}}{2.1\times 10^{21}}\right]^{2/3}=5.26\times 10^{ 5}\ \mathrm{\AA^{2}}\)
\(\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle_{o}^{1/2}=725\ \mathrm{\AA}\)
**(c)** The characteristic ratio, \(C_{\mathrm{N}}\), for PS.
_Solution_
\(C_{\mathrm{N}}=\frac{\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle}{nl^{2}}=\frac{5.26\times 1 0^{5}}{9.13\times 10^{4}}=5.76\)

question: What is the molecular weight of a fraction of poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) at the same elution volume in toluene at 25\({}^{\circ}\)C?
context:
**3.7** The use of universal calibration curves in GPC is based upon the principle that the product \(\left[\eta\right]M\), the hydrodynamic volume, is the same for all polymers at equal elution volumes. If the retention volume for a monodisperse polystyrene (PS) sample of 50,000 molecular weight is 100 mL in toluene at 25\({}^{\circ}\)C, what is the molecular weight of a fraction of poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) at the same elution volume in toluene at 25\({}^{\circ}\)C? The Mark-Houwink parameters, \(K\) and \(a\), for PS are given as \(7.54\times 10^{-3}\) mL g\({}^{-1}\) and 0.783, respectively; the corresponding values for PMMA are \(8.12\times 10^{-3}\) mL g\({}^{-1}\) and 0.71.
_Solution_
\(\left\lfloor\eta\right\rfloor\)M=KM\({}_{\mathrm{v}}\)\({}^{1+a}\)
\(7.54\times 10^{-3}\left(5\times 10^{4}\right)^{1.783}=8.12\times 10^{-3}\ M^{1.71}\)
or \(\mathrm{\ \overline{M}_{\mathrm{V}}=75,988}\)

question: What is the most probable end-to-end distance of a freely-jointed polymer chain?
answer: The most probable end-to-end distance of a freely-jointed polymer chain is \(\left(2n\ell^{2}/3\right)^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\).
context:
**3.8** Show that the most probable end-to-end distance of a freely-jointed polymer chain is given as \(\left(2n\ell^{2}/3\right)^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\).
_Solution_
\(\omega\left(r\right)=\left(\frac{b}{\pi^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}}\right)^{3} \exp\left(-b^{2}r^{2}\right)4\pi r^{2}\)
The maximum value occurs at \(\frac{d\omega\left(r\right)}{dr}=0\)
\(\frac{d\omega\left(r\right)}{dr}=8\pi r\left(\frac{b}{\pi^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{ 2}}}}\right)^{3}\left(1-b^{2}r^{2}\right)\exp\left(-b^{2}r^{2}\right)=0\)or \(b^{2}r^{2}=1\) and
\[r=\frac{1}{b}=\left(\frac{2nl}{3}\right)^{\!\!\!/2}\]

question: Calculate the weight-average molecular weight of cellulose acetate in dioxane.
context:
**3.9** The (reduced or excess) Rayleigh ratio (\(R_{\theta}\)) of cellulose acetate (CA) in dioxane was determined as a function of concentration by low-angle laser light-scattering measurements. Data are given in the following table. If the refractive index (\(n_{{}_{\circ}}\)) of dioxane is 1.4199, the refractive-index increment (\(dn/dc\)) for CA in dioxane is \(6.297\times 10^{-2}\) cm\({}^{3}\) g\({}^{-1}\), and the wavelength (\(\lambda\)) of the light is 6328 A, calculate the weight-average molecular weight of CA and the second virial coefficient (\(A_{2}\))
\begin{tabular}{l l} \multicolumn{2}{l}{\(c\times 10^{3}\)} & \multicolumn{1}{c}{\(R(\theta)\times 10^{5}\)} \\ \multicolumn{2}{l}{**(g mL\({}^{-1}\))**} & \multicolumn{1}{c}{**(cm\({}^{-1}\))**} \\ \hline
0.5034 & 0.239 \\
1.0068 & 0.440 \\
1.5102 & 0.606 \\
2.0136 & 0.790 \\
2.517 & 0.902 \\ \hline \end{tabular}
_Solution_
\[K=\frac{2\pi^{2}n_{{}_{\mathrm{o}}}^{2}}{\mathrm{N}_{{}_{\mathrm{A}}}\lambda^ {4}}\!\left(\frac{dn}{dc}\right)^{\!\!\!/2}=\frac{2\pi^{2}\left(1.4199\right)^ {2}\left(6.297\times 10^{-2}\right)^{2}}{6.023\times 10^{23}\left(6328\right)^{4} \left(10^{-8}\right)^{4}}=1.63\times 10^{-8}\]
\begin{tabular}{l|c|c} \multicolumn{3}{l}{\(c\times 10^{3}\)} & \multicolumn{1}{c}{\(R(\theta)\times 10^{5}\)} & \multicolumn{1}{c}{\(\mathbf{Kc/R(\theta)\times 10^{6}}\)} \\ \hline

2.0136 & 0.790 & 4.15 \\ \hline
2.517 & 0.902 & 4.55 \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Least squares (\(R^{2}=0.9758\)) fit of data gives (from the intercept)

question: What is the \(T_{\rm g}\) (K) of the styrene oligomer?
context:
**3.11**: **(a)** Derive eq (3.72) and **(b)** develop an expression that can be used to obtain the exchange interaction parameter, \(X_{{}_{12}}\), appearing in the Flory equation of state from inverse gas chromatography measurements.
_Solution_
**(a)** The F-H equation, eq 3.37
\[\ln a_{{}_{1}}=\ln\left(1-\phi_{{}_{2}}\right)+\phi_{{}_{2}}+\chi_{{}_{12}}\phi _{{}_{2}}^{2}\]
Rearrangement of eq. 3.37 gives
\[\ln\left(\frac{a_{{}_{1}}}{\phi_{{}_{1}}}\right)=\ln a_{{}_{1}}-\ln\phi_{{}_{1} }=\ln a_{{}_{1}}-\ln\left(1-\phi_{{}_{2}}\right)=1-\phi_{{}_{1}}+\chi_{{}_{12}} \left(1-\phi_{{}_{1}}\right)^{2}\]
and it follows that
\[\lim_{\phi_{{}_{1}}\to 0}\ln\left(\frac{a_{{}_{1}}}{\phi_{{}_{1}}}\right)=1+ \chi_{{}_{12}}\]
Substituting eq. 3.70 (below) into the LHS of the equation above
\[\ln\gamma_{{}_{1}}^{\infty}=\ln\left(\frac{a_{{}_{1}}}{\phi_{{}_{1}}}\right)^ {\infty}=\lim_{\phi_{{}_{1}}\to 0}\left(\frac{a_{{}_{1}}}{\phi_{{}_{1}}} \right)=\ln\left(\frac{273.16Rv_{{}_{2}}}{V_{{}_{\rm g}}\,p_{{}_{1}}^{\infty} }\right)-\frac{p_{{}_{1}}^{\infty}\left(B_{{}_{11}}-V_{{}_{1}}\right)}{RT}\]
finally gives the required result eq. 3.72
\[\chi_{{}_{12}}=\ln\left(\frac{273.16Rv_{{}_{2}}}{V_{{}_{\rm g}}\,p_{{}_{1}}^{ \infty}V_{{}_{1}}}\right)-\frac{p_{{}_{1}}^{\infty}\left(B_{{}_{11}}-V_{{}_{1 }}\right)}{RT}-1\]
**(b)** For the Flory EOS, write eq. 3.61 as
\[\ln a_{{}_{1}}=\frac{\Delta\mu_{{}_{1}}}{RT}=\ln\phi_{{}_{1}}+\left(1-\frac{v_ {{}_{1}}^{*}}{v_{{}_{2}}^{*}}\right)\phi_{{}_{2}}+\frac{1}{RT}\left\{\frac{ \theta_{{}_{2}}^{2}v_{{}_{1}}^{*}X_{{}_{12}}}{\tilde{v}}+v_{{}_{1}}^{*}p_{{}_{ 1}}^{*}\left[3\widetilde{T}_{{}_{1}}\ln\left(\frac{\tilde{v}_{{}_{1}}^{\prime {}_{1}}-1}{\tilde{v}}^{\prime{}_{1}}-1\right)+\frac{1}{\tilde{v}_{{}_{1}}}-\frac {1}{\tilde{v}}\right]\right\}\]
and then rearrangement gives
\[\ln\frac{a_{{}_{1}}}{\phi_{{}_{1}}}=\left(1-\frac{v_{{}_{1}}^{*}}{v_{{}_{2}}^ {*}}\right)\phi_{{}_{2}}+\frac{1}{RT}\left\{\frac{\theta_{{}_{2}}^{2}v_{{}_{1 }}^{*}X_{{}_{12}}}{\tilde{v}}+v_{{}_{1}}^{*}p_{{}_{1}}^{*}\left[3\widetilde{T} _{{}_{1}}\ln\left(\frac{\tilde{v}_{{}_{1}}^{\prime{}_{1}}-1}{\tilde{v}}^{ \prime{}_{1}}-1\right)+\frac{1}{\tilde{v}_{{}_{1}}}-\frac{1}{\tilde{v}}\right]\right\}\]
Noting that \(\phi_{{}_{2}}=1\); \(\phi_{{}_{1}}=1\); \(\theta_{{}_{2}}=1\); \(\theta_{{}_{1}}=1\); \(\tilde{v}=\tilde{v}_{{}_{2}}\); \(\tilde{T}=\widetilde{T}_{{}_{2}}^{*}\); \(\alpha=\)\(\alpha_{{}_{2}}\) and using eq. 3.70 (part a), we have
\[\lim_{\phi_{{}_{1}}\to 0}\ln\left(\frac{a_{{}_{1}}
and finally
\[X_{12}=RT\Bigg{(}\frac{\tilde{v}_{2}}{v_{1}^{3}}\Bigg{)}\ln\Bigg{(}\frac{273.16 Rv_{2}}{V_{g}p_{1}^{\alpha}}\Bigg{)}-p_{1}^{\alpha}\left(B_{11}-V_{1} \right)\Bigg{(}\frac{\tilde{v}_{2}}{v_{1}^{3}}\Bigg{)}-RT\Bigg{(}1-\frac{v_{1}^ {*}}{v_{2}^{*}}\Bigg{)}\Bigg{(}\frac{\tilde{v}_{2}}{v_{1}^{2}}\Bigg{)}-v_{1}^{* }p_{1}^{*}\Bigg{(}\frac{\tilde{v}_{2}}{v_{1}^{3}}\Bigg{)}\Bigg{[}3\tilde{T}_{1} \ln\Bigg{(}\frac{\tilde{v}_{1}^{\prime\prime}-1}{\tilde{v}_{2}^{\prime\prime}-1} \Bigg{)}+\frac{1}{\tilde{v}_{1}}-\frac{1}{\tilde{v}_{2}}\Bigg{]}\]
Derive the expression for osmotic pressure given by eq. (3.83).
\[\frac{\Pi}{c}=\frac{RT}{M}\Bigg{[}1+\Bigg{(}\frac{M\nu^{2}}{V_{1}}\Bigg{)} \Bigg{(}\frac{1}{2}-\chi_{12}\Bigg{)}c+\frac{1}{3}\Bigg{(}\frac{M\nu^{3}}{V_{ 1}}\Bigg{)}c^{2}+\ldots\Bigg{]}\]
_Solution_
From eq. 3.80, we can write
\[\Pi=-\frac{RT}{V_{1}}\ln a_{1}\]
Substituting eq. 3.36 for \(\ln a_{1}\) in the Flory-Huggins model gives
\[\Pi=-\frac{RT}{V_{1}}\Bigg{[}\ln\left(1-\phi_{2}\right)+\Bigg{(}1-\frac{1}{r} \Bigg{)}\phi_{2}+\chi_{12}\phi_{2}^{\ 2}\ \Bigg{]}\]
Substituting the Taylor series (Appendix E) in the form
\[\ln\left(1-\phi_{2}\right)\approx-\phi_{2}-\frac{\phi_{2}^{\ 2}}{2}-\frac{\phi_{2}^{\ 3}}{3}+\ldots\]
gives
\[\Pi\approx\frac{RT}{V_{1}}\Bigg{[}\phi_{2}+\frac{\phi_{2}^{\ 2}}{2}+\frac{\phi_{2}^{\ 3}}{3}-\Bigg{(}1-\frac{1}{r}\Bigg{)}\phi_{2}-\chi_{12}\phi_{2}^{\ 2}+\cdots\Bigg{]}=\frac{RT}{V_{1}}\Bigg{[} \frac{\phi_{2}}{r}+\Bigg{(}\frac{1}{2}-\chi_{12}\Bigg{)}\phi_{2}^{\ 2}+\frac{\phi_{2}^{\ 3}}{3}+\cdots\Bigg{]}\]
Since \(r=\frac{v\,\mathrm{M}}{V_{1}}\) and \(\phi_{2}=cv\) (eq. 3.82)
we can write
\[\frac{\phi_{2}}{r}=\frac{cv}{v\,\mathrm{M}}V_{1}=\frac{1}{\,\mathrm{M}}\,cV_{1}\]
and finally, we obtain eq. 3.83 as
\[\frac{\Pi}{c}=RT\Bigg{[}\frac{1}{\,M}+\Bigg{(}\frac{1}{2}-\chi_{12}\Bigg{)}cv^ {2}+\frac{c^{2}v^{3}}{3}+\cdots\Bigg{]}=\frac{RT}{M}\Bigg{[}1+\Bigg{(}\frac{M \nu^{2}}{V_{1}}\Bigg{)}\Bigg{(}\frac{1}{2}-\chi_{12}\Bigg{)}c+\frac{1}{3} \Bigg{(}\frac{M\nu^{3}}{V_{1}}\Bigg{)}c^{2}+\cdots\Bigg{]}\]
Show how eq. eq. 3.78 for the relationship between the Flory-Huggins interaction parameter and the solubility parameters of polymer and solvent was derived.
Eq. 3.78
\[\chi_{12}\equiv\frac{V_{1}}{RT}\big{(}\delta_{1}-\delta_{2}\big{)}^{2}\]

\[V=10.5\times 4.92\times 1.97=101.77\ \mathrm{cm}^{3}\]
\[\Delta V=101.77-100=1.77\ \mathrm{cm}^{3}\ \mathrm{or}\ 1.77\%\]
A polymer has a crystalline growth parameter (\(n\)) of 2 and a rate constant (\(k\)) of 10\({}^{\text{-2}}\) s\({}^{\text{-2}}\) at 100\({}^{\text{o}}\)C. The polymer is melted and then quenched to 100\({}^{\text{o}}\)C and allowed to crystallize isothermally. After 10 s, what is the percent crystallinity of the sample?
_Solution_
\[\phi=1-\exp\left(-kt^{n}\right)\]
\[\phi=1-\exp\left[-10^{2}\left(10\right)^{2}\right]=1-\exp\left(-1\right)=1-0.3679=0.6321\ \mathrm{or}\ 63.2\%\ \mathrm{crystalline}\]
What is the % volume change that is expected at 100% elongation of natural rubber, assuming that no crystallization occurs during deformation?
_Solution_
\[\varepsilon=\ln\left(L/L_{\text{\tiny o}}\right)=\ln 2=0.6931\]
\[\Delta v=\left(1-2v\right)\varepsilon V_{\text{\tiny o}}\ \mathrm{where}\ v=0.49\ \mathrm{(Table\ \ref{eq:PJ})}\]
\[\frac{\Delta V}{V_{\text{\tiny o}}}=\left(1-0.98\right)\left(0.6931\right)=0.0139\ \mathrm{or}\ 1.39\%\]
Give your best estimate for the weight fraction of plasticizer required to lower the \(T_{\text{g}}\) of poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) to 30\({}^{\text{o}}\)C. Assume that the \(T_{\text{g}}\) of PVC is 356 K and that of the plasticizer is 188 K. No other information is available.
_Solution_
Eq. 4.33
\[\ln\left(\frac{303}{188}\right)=\frac{\left(1-W_{1}^{\prime}\right)\ln\left(35 6/188\right)}{W_{1}\left(356/188\right)+1-W_{1}^{\prime}}\]
solve for W\({}_{1}\) gives \(W_{1}=0.151\ \mathrm{or}\ 15.1\ \mathrm{wt}\%\)
Show that the inverse rule of mixtures given by eq.4.34 can be obtained from the generalized relationship given by eq.4.32 when \(T_{\text{g},1}\approx T_{\text{g},2}\)
_Solution_
Substituting \(\Delta C_{\text{\tiny p},1}=\mathrm{constant}\big{/}T_{\text{g},1}\) and \(\Delta C_{\text{\tiny p},2}=\mathrm{constant}\big{/}T_{\text{g},2}\) into eq. 4.32 and multiplying numerator and denominator by \(T_{\text{g},2}\) gives eq. 4.33.
Next, let \(\ln\left(1+x\right)\approx x\) where \(x=\left(T_{\text{g}}\big{/}T_{\text{g},1}\right)-1\)
Substitute into eq. 4.33 gives\[\frac{T_{\text{g}}}{T_{\text{g,1}}}-1=\frac{W_{2}\left(\frac{T_{\text{g,2}}}{T_{ \text{g,1}}}-1\right)}{W_{1}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{2}}\]
\[T_{\text{g}}=\frac{W_{2}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}-T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{1}T_{ \text{g,2}}+W_{2}T_{\text{g,1}}}{W_{1}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}} \right)+W_{2}}=\frac{W_{2}T_{\text{g,2}}+W_{1}T_{\text{g,2}}}{W_{1}\left(T_{ \text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{2}}=\frac{\left(W_{1}+W_{2}\right)T_{ \text{g,2}}}{W_{1}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{2}}=\frac{T_{ \text{g,2}}}{W_{1}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{2}}\]
\[\frac{1}{T_{\text{g}}}=\frac{W_{1}}{T_{\text{g,1}}}+\frac{W_{2}}{T_{\text{g,2 }}}\]
Polytetrafluoroethylene has been reported to exhibit a negative Poisson ratio. Explain why this polymer exhibits this unusual behavior.
Teflon thickens upon elongation due to a rotation of crystals perpendicular to the draw direction.
_Solution_
_See_ B. W. Ludwig and M. W. Urban, _Polymer_**35**, 5130 (1994).
### A sample of poly(ethylene terephthalate) is reported to be 20% crystalline.
**(a)** What is the expected density of this sample?
_Solution_
Using eq. 4.6 and densities give in Table 4-5
\[\rho=\phi\left(\rho_{\text{c}}-\rho_{a}\right)+\rho_{a}=0.2\left(1.396-1.280 \right)+1.280=1.303\text{ g cm}^{\text{-3}}\]
**(b)** What is the expected specific heat increment of this semicrystalline sample?
_Solution_
From eq. 4.26
Simha-Boyer rule: \(\left(\Delta C_{\text{p}}\right)_{\text{am}}\approx 115\text{ J g}^{\text{-1}}\Big{/}T_{\text{g}}\)
From Table 4-3, \(T_{\text{g}}=342\text{ K}\)
\[\left(\Delta C_{\text{p}}\right)_{\text{am}}=\frac{115}{342}=0.336\text{ J g}^{\text{-1}}\text{ K}^{\text{-1}}\]
\[\Delta C_{\text{p}}=\left(0.8\right)0.336=0.269\text{ J g}^{\text{-1}}\text{ K}^{\text{-1}}=0.269\left(0.2387\right)=0.06416\text{ cal g}^{\text{-1}}\text{ K}^{\text{-1}}\]
**(d)** What is the expected heat of fusion of this sample?
_Solution_
From eq. 4.25 and Table 4-4
\[\Delta Q=\phi\Delta H_{t}=0.2\left(6.431\right)\text{ kcal mol}^{\text{-1}}=1.286\text{ kcal mol}^{\text{-1}}=1.286\left(0.2387\right)=0.307\text{ kJ mol}^{\text{-1}}\]
Twenty wt % of a styrene oligomer having a number-average degree of polymerization of 7 is mixed with a commercial polystyrene sample having a number-average molecular weight of 100,000.
**(a)** What is the \(T_{\rm g}\) (K) of the styrene oligomer?
_Solution_
Use of the Fox-Flory relation, eq 4.27, and parameters given in Table 4-11
\[\widetilde{M}_{\rm n}=7\times 104=728\]
\[T_{\rm g,1}=373-\frac{1.2\times 10^{5}}{728}=373-165=208\ {\rm K}\]
**(b)** What is the \(T_{\rm g}\) (K) of the polystyrene mixture.
_Solution_
\[T_{\rm g,2}=373-\frac{1.2\times 10^{5}}{10^{5}}=372\ {\rm K}\]
Use eq. 4.34 as best approximation since \(T_{\rm g}\)s are far apart
\[\ln\left(\frac{T_{\rm g}}{165}\right)=\frac{0.8\ln\left(372/165\right)}{0.2 \left(372/165\right)+0.8}=0.5199\]
\[T_{\rm g}=1.6819\left(165\right)=277.5\ {\rm K}\]

From eq. 3.80, we can write

Substituting eq. 3.36 for \(\ln a_{1}\) in the Flory-Huggins model gives

Substituting the Taylor series (Appendix E) in the form

Show that the inverse rule of mixtures given by eq.4.34 can be obtained from the generalized relationship given by eq.4.32 when \(T_{\text{g},1}\approx T_{\text{g},2}\)

Substituting \(\Delta C_{\text{\tiny p},1}=\mathrm{constant}\big{/}T_{\text{g},1}\) and \(\Delta C_{\text{\tiny p},2}=\mathrm{constant}\big{/}T_{\text{g},2}\) into eq. 4.32 and multiplying numerator and denominator by \(T_{\text{g},2}\) gives eq. 4.33.
Next, let \(\ln\left(1+x\right)\approx x\) where \(x=\left(T_{\text{g}}\big{/}T_{\text{g},1}\right)-1\)
Substitute into eq. 4.33 gives\[\frac{T_{\text{g}}}{T_{\text{g,1}}}-1=\frac{W_{2}\left(\frac{T_{\text{g,2}}}{T_{ \text{g,1}}}-1\right)}{W_{1}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{2}}\]
\[T_{\text{g}}=\frac{W_{2}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}-T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{1}T_{ \text{g,2}}+W_{2}T_{\text{g,1}}}{W_{1}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}} \right)+W_{2}}=\frac{W_{2}T_{\text{g,2}}+W_{1}T_{\text{g,2}}}{W_{1}\left(T_{ \text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{2}}=\frac{\left(W_{1}+W_{2}\right)T_{ \text{g,2}}}{W_{1}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{2}}=\frac{T_{ \text{g,2}}}{W_{1}\left(T_{\text{g,2}}/T_{\text{g,1}}\right)+W_{2}}\]
\[\frac{1}{T_{\text{g}}}=\frac{W_{1}}{T_{\text{g,1}}}+\frac{W_{2}}{T_{\text{g,2 }}}\]

question: Show that \(\left|E*\right|=\sigma^{\circ}/\varepsilon^{\circ}\) and \(\left|D*\right|=1/E*\).
context:
**5.1** Show that \(\left|E*\right|=\sigma^{\circ}/\varepsilon^{\circ}\) and \(\left|D*\right|=1/E*\).
_Solution_
\(\left|E*\right|=\sqrt{\left(E^{*}\right)^{2}+\left(E^{*}\right)^{2}}\)
\(E^{*}=\left(\frac{\sigma^{\circ}}{\varepsilon^{\circ}}\right)\cos\delta\); \(E^{*}=\left(\frac{\sigma^{\circ}}{\varepsilon^{\circ}}\right)\sin\delta\)
Therefore \(\left|E*\right|=\left[\left(\frac{\sigma^{\circ}}{\varepsilon^{\circ}} \right)^{2}\left(\sin^{2}\delta+\cos^{2}\delta\right)\right]^{\!/2}=\frac{ \sigma^{\circ}}{\varepsilon^{\circ}}\)
Similarly \(D*\times\overline{D}*=\left|D*\right|^{2}\)
where \(D*=D^{*}-iD^{*}\) and \(\overline{D}*=D^{*}+iD^{*}\)
\(D^{*}=\left(\frac{\varepsilon^{\circ}}{\sigma^{\circ}}\right)\cos\delta\) and \(D^{*}=\left(\frac{\varepsilon^{\circ}}{\sigma^{\circ}}\right)\sin\delta\)
therefore \(\left|D*\right|=\left[\left(\frac{\varepsilon^{\circ}}{\sigma^{\circ}} \right)^{2}\left(\sin^{2}\delta+\cos^{2}\delta\right)\right]^{\!/2}=\frac{ \varepsilon^{\circ}}{\sigma^{\circ}}=\frac{1}{\left|E*\right|}\)

question: Show that the work per cycle per unit volume performed during dynamic tensile oscillation of a viscoelastic solid may be given as \(\pi\sigma^{\circ}\varepsilon^{\circ}\sin\delta\) (eq. (5.30)).
context:
**5.2** Show that the work per cycle per unit volume performed during dynamic tensile oscillation of a viscoelastic solid may be given as \(\pi\sigma^{\circ}\varepsilon^{\circ}\sin\delta\) (eq. (5.30)).
_Solution_
\(W=\int_{0}^{2\pi}\sigma*d\varepsilon*\)
\(\sigma*=\sigma^{\circ}\sin\left(\omega t+\delta\right)\)
\(\varepsilon*=\varepsilon^{\circ}\sin\omega t\) and \(d\varepsilon*=\varepsilon^{\circ}\cos\omega t\)
This text is associated with Fried/Polymer Science and Technology, Third Edition (9780137039555) Copyright 2014, Pearson Education, Inc. Do not redistribute.
\[W=\sigma^{\circ}\varepsilon^{\circ}\int_{\sigma=0}^{2\pi}\sin\big{(}\omega t+ \delta\big{)}\cos\omega t\big{(}\omega t\big{)}\]
Since \(\sin\big{(}\omega t+\delta\big{)}=\sin\omega t\cos\delta+\cos\omega t\sin\delta\), write
\[\frac{W}{\sigma^{\circ}\varepsilon^{\circ}}=\cos\delta\int_{0}^{2\pi}\sin \omega t\cos\omega t\big{(}\omega t\big{)}+\sin\delta\int_{0}^{2\pi}\cos^{2} \omega t\big{(}\omega t\big{)}\]
Note \(\int\sin\omega x\cos\omega xdx=\frac{\sin^{2}\omega x}{2\omega}\) and \(\sin^{2}\theta=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}\cos 2\theta\)
Therefore \(\int_{0}^{2\pi}\sin\omega t\cos\omega t\big{(}\omega t\big{)}=\omega\frac{ \sin^{2}\omega t}{2\omega}\bigg{|}_{0}^{2\pi}=\frac{1}{2}\bigg{[}\frac{1}{2}- \frac{1}{2}\big{(}\cos 4\pi\big{)}-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}\big{(}\cos 0\big{)} \bigg{]}=0\)
This is the elastic response (no work expanded).
Next, \(\frac{W}{\sigma^{\circ}\varepsilon^{\circ}}=\sin\delta\int_{0}^{2\pi}\cos^{2 }\omega t\big{(}\omega t\big{)}\)
Note \(\int\cos^{2}udu=\frac{u}{2}+\frac{\sin 2u}{4}\)
Then \(\frac{W}{\sigma^{\circ}\varepsilon^{\circ}}=\sin\delta\bigg{(}\frac{\omega t }{2}+\frac{\sin 2\omega t}{4}\bigg{)}_{0}^{2\pi}=\sin\delta\bigg{[}\pi+\frac{\sin \big{(}4\pi\big{)}}{4}-0-\frac{\sin 0}{4}\bigg{]}=\pi\sin\delta\) and
\[W=\pi\sigma^{\circ}\varepsilon^{\circ}\sin\delta\]
Given the expression \(G(t)=G_{\circ}\exp\big{(}-t/\tau\big{)}+G_{\circ}\), show that the compliance function, \(J(t)\), can be written in the form \(J(t)=\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B}\exp\big{(}-\mathrm{C}\,t/\tau\big{)}\), where \(\mathrm{A}\), \(\mathrm{B}\), and \(\mathrm{C}\) are constants.
_Solution_
\[L\big{[}J(t)\big{]}L\big{[}G(t)\big{]}=\frac{1}{p^{2}}\]
\[L\big{[}G(t)\big{]}=\frac{G_{\circ}}{p+1/\tau}+\frac{G_{\circ}}{p}\]
\[L\big{[}J(t)\big{]}=\frac{1}{p^{2}L\big{[}G(t)\big{]}}=\frac{p+1/\tau}{p\big{[} \big{(}G_{\circ}+G_{\circ}\big{)}\,p+\big{(}G_{\circ}/\tau\big{)}\big{]}}\]
Rearrange in form \(\frac{p+a}{bp\big{(}p+c\big{)}}\)
where\[a=\frac{1}{\tau}\ ;\ b=G_{\rm o}+G_{1}\ ;\ c=G_{1}\ a/b=G_{1}\sqrt{\left[\tau\left(G_{ \rm o}+G_{1}\right)\right]}\]
Then \(J\left(t\right)=L^{-1}\left[\frac{p+a}{bp\left(p+c\right)}\right]\)
Use partial fractions, to find inverse
\[\frac{p+a}{bp\left(p+c\right)}=\frac{A}{bp}+\frac{B}{p+c}=\frac{p\left(A+bB \right)+Ac}{bp\left(p+c\right)}=\frac{p+a}{bp\left(p+c\right)}\]
Then \(A+bB=1\)
\[a=Ac\ \ \mbox{or}\ \ A=a/c=\frac{G_{\rm o}+G_{1}}{G_{1}}\]
\[B=\frac{1-A}{b}=\frac{c-a}{cb}\]
\[J\left(t\right)=L^{-1}\left(\frac{A}{bp}\right)+L^{-1}\left(\frac{B}{p+c} \right)=\frac{A}{b}+B\exp\left(-ct\right)=\frac{1}{G_{1}}+B\exp\left[-\left( \frac{G_{1}}{G_{\rm o}+G_{1}}\right)\frac{t}{\tau}\right]\]
\[B=\frac{1-A}{b}=\frac{-G_{\rm o}}{G_{1}+\left(G_{\rm o}+G_{1}\right)}\]
\[J\left(t\right)=\frac{1}{G_{1}}-\frac{G_{\rm o}}{G_{1}\left(G_{\rm o}+G_{1} \right)}\]

question: For a Maxwell model, how can the equation for the complex modulus \(E\) (eq. (5.57)) be obtained from the Fourier transform of the stress-relaxation modulus, \(E_{\rm r}\) (eq. (5.49))?
answer: The equation for the complex modulus \(E\) (eq. (5.57)) is obtained as \(E^{\prime}=E\frac{ \omega\tau}{\left(\omega\tau\right)^{2}+1}\).
context:
**5.4**: For a Maxwell model, show the following:
**(a)** The equation for complex modulus \(E\)* (eq. (5.57)) can be obtained from the Fourier transform of the stress-relaxation modulus, \(E_{\rm r}\) (eq. (5.49)).
**(b)** A maximum in the loss modulus plotted as a function of frequency occurs at \(\omega=1/\tau\).
_Solutions_
**(a)** eq. 5.49: \(E_{\rm r}=E\exp\left(-\frac{t}{\tau}\right)\)
\[E^{\prime}=\omega\int_{0}^{\infty}\sin\left(\omega s\right)E\left(s\right)ds =\omega E\int_{0}^{\infty}\exp\left(-s/\tau\right)\sin\left(\omega s\right)ds\]
Fourier transform \(f\left(x\right)=\exp\left(-bx\right);\ F_{\rm S}=\frac{\alpha}{\alpha^{2}+b^{ 2}}\)Therefore \(E^{\prime}=E\frac{\left(\omega\tau\right)^{2}}{\left(\omega\tau\right)^{2}+1}\)
Similarly \(E^{\prime}=\omega E\int_{0}^{\infty}\exp\left(-s/\tau\right)\cos\left(\omega s\right)\)_ks_
Fourier transform \(f\left(x\right)=\exp\left(-bx\right);\ F_{c}\left(\alpha\right)=\frac{b}{ \alpha^{2}+b^{2}}\)
Get eq. 5.59:
\[E^{\prime}=\omega E\frac{1/\tau}{\omega^{2}+\left(1/\tau\right)^{2}}=E\frac{ \omega\tau}{\left(\omega\tau\right)^{2}+1}\]
**(b)** \[\frac{dE^{\prime}}{d\omega}=\frac{\left(\omega^{2}\tau^{2}+1\right)E\tau-E \tau\omega 2\omega w\tau^{2}}{\left(\omega^{2}\tau^{2}+1\right)^{2}}=0\]
\[\left(\omega^{2}\tau^{2}+1\right)E\tau-E\tau\omega 2\omega w\tau^{2}=0\]
or \(\omega^{2}\tau^{2}=1\) and \(\omega=1/\tau\) at maximum

question: If the stress at 23degC of an ideal rubber is 100 psi when stretched to twice its original length, what would be the stress at a 50% extension?
context:
**5.10**: An elastomeric cube, 2 cm on a side, is compressed to 95% of its original length by applying a mass of 5 kg. What force is required to stretch a strip of the same elastomer by 50%? The initial length of the strip is 2 cm and its original cross-sectional area is 1 cm\({}^{2}\).
#### Solution
\[K=\frac{\Delta P}{\Delta V/V_{\circ}}\]
The hydrostatic pressure is obtained as follows:
\[\Delta P=5\ \mathrm{kg}\frac{9.80665\ \mathrm{m}\ 10^{4}\ \mathrm{cm}^{2}}{ \mathrm{s}^{2}\ 24\ \mathrm{cm}^{2}}=2.043\times 10^{4}\ \mathrm{kg}\ \mathrm{m}^{-1}\ \mathrm{s}^{2}\]
\[V_{\circ}=8\ \mathrm{cm}^{3};\ V=6.859\ \mathrm{cm}^{3}\ ;\ \Delta V=8-6.859=1.141\ \mathrm{cm}^{3}\]
\[K=\frac{2.043\times 10^{4}}{1.141/8}=14.32\times 10^{4}=0.143\ \mathrm{MPa}\]
From eqs. 4.54 and 4.56, we have
\[K=\frac{2\big{(}1+v\big{)}G}{3\big{(}1-2v\big{)}}\ \mathrm{or}\ \ G=\frac{3 \big{(}1-2v\big{)}K}{2\big{(}1+v\big{)}}\]
Table 4-13, \(v=0.49\) for NR
\[G=\frac{3\big{(}1-0.98\big{)}}{2\big{(}1.49\big{)}}0.143=0.00288\ \mathrm{MPa}\]
\[\lambda=\frac{L}{L_{\circ}}=1.5\]
\[f^{\ast}=G_{\circ}\bigg{(}\lambda-\frac{1}{\lambda^{2}}\bigg{)}=0.00288\bigg{(} 1.5-\frac{1}{1.5^{2}}\bigg{)}=0.00288\big{(}1.0556\big{)}=0.00304\ \mathrm{MPa}\]
or unit conversion
\[f^{\ast}=3.04\times 10^{3}\ \frac{\mathrm{kg}}{\mathrm{m}\ \mathrm{s}^{2}}1\ \mathrm{cm}^{2}\ \frac{\mathrm{m}^{2}}{10^{4}\ \mathrm{cm}^{2}}\ \lambda=0.304\ \mathrm{kg}_{\mathrm{f}}\]

12The length of an ideal rubber band is increased 100% to 12.0 cm at 23\({}^{\circ}\)C. Stress on this rubber band increases by 0.2 MPa when it is heated to 30\({}^{\circ}\)C at 100% elongation. What is its tensile modulus in MPa at 23\({}^{\circ}\)C when it is stretched 2%?
_Solution_
Neglecting any changes in volume with temperature
\[\sigma_{1}=\left(\frac{296}{303}\right)\sigma_{2}=\left(\frac{296}{303} \right)\left(\sigma_{1}+0.2\text{ MPa}\right)=0.9769\sigma_{1}+0.1954\text{ MPa}\]
\[0.02310\sigma_{1}=0.1954\text{ MPa}\]
\[\sigma_{1}=8.4589\text{ MPa}\]
\[G_{1}=\frac{8.4589}{2-\nicefrac{{1}}{{4}}}=4.8336\text{ MPa}\]
\[\sigma_{3}=4.8336\left[1.02-\frac{1}{1.02^{2}}\right]=0.2844\text{ MPa}\]
\[E=\frac{\sigma_{3}}{0.02}=\frac{0.28436}{0.02}=14.2\text{ MPa}\]

\[G^{\prime}=F_{\text{s}}I\left(\frac{1}{p^{2}}\right)=\frac{64\pi^{2}L}{Wt^{3} }\frac{1}{u}I\left(\frac{1}{p^{2}}\right)=3.743\times 10^{7}\text{ }\frac{1}{u}\text{g cm}^{ \nicefrac{{1}}{{4}}}\text{ s}^{2}\]
See ASTM D 4065 (ref. in Appendix C)
\[u=\frac{16}{3}-3.36\frac{t}{W}\left(1-\frac{t^{4}}{12W^{4}}\right)=4.075\]
\[G^{\prime}=3.743\times 10^{7}\text{ }\frac{1}{4.075}\text{g cm}^{ \nicefrac{{1}}{{4}}}\text{ s}^{2}=0.9185\times 10^{7}\text{ g cm}^{ \nicefrac{{1}}{{4}}}s^{-2}=9.185\times 10^{6}\text{ dynes cm}^{ \nicefrac{{2}}{{4}}}\frac{\text{Pa}}{10\text{ dynes cm}^{ \nicefrac{{2}}{{2}}}}\]
=0.9185 MPa

Give your best estimate for the \(T_{\text{g}}\) of PVC plasticized with 30 phr of TOTM (\(T_{\text{g}}\) = -72\({}^{\circ}\)C).
Solution_
\(T_{g,1}\) = 201 K ; \(T_{g,1}\) = 354 K (Table B-1, Appendix B)
With the information available, the accurate expression would be eq. 7.3 since the \(T_{\text{g}}\)s are widely separated.
\[W_{1}=\frac{30}{100+30}=0.231\]\[\ln\left(\frac{T_{g}}{T_{g,1}}\right)=\ln\left(\frac{T_{g}}{201}\right)=\frac{W_{2 }\ln\left(T_{g,2}/T_{g,1}\right)}{W\left(T_{g,2}/T_{g,1}\right)+W_{21}}=\frac{0.76 9\ln\left(354/201\right)}{0.231\left(354/201\right)+0.769}=0.3699\]
\[T_{g}=1.448\left(201\right)=291\text{ K or }18^{\circ}\text{C}\]
Explain why the curve representing the \(T_{g}\) of miscible TMPC/PS blends appearing in Figure 7.4 appears to diverge at low TMPC compositions.
_Solution_
At low TMPC concentration, PS is the major component and the overall \(T_{g}\) of the blend is reduced by the lowest-molecular-weight PS ( \(\vec{M}_{n}=42,000\) ) component; the actual reduction in \(T_{g}\) is small. From the Fox-Flory equation (eq. 4.27)
\[T_{g}=373-\frac{1.2\times 10^{5}}{42,000}=370\text{ K}\.\]
Show that the Halpin-Tsai equation (eq. 7.9) reduces to the simple law of mixtures
\[M=\phi_{1}M_{1}+\phi_{2}M_{2}\]
when the Halpin-Tsai parameter \(A\) approaches infinity and reduces to the inverse rule of mixtures
\[\frac{1}{M}=\frac{\phi_{1}}{M_{1}}+\frac{\phi_{2}}{M_{2}}\]
when \(A\) approaches zero.
_Solution_
As \(A\rightarrow\infty\) (corresponding to the case where fibers are aligned in a parallel direction)
\(M=\phi_{1}M_{1}+\phi_{2}M_{2}\)
As \(A\to 0\), \(B=\frac{\left(M_{1}/M_{2}\right)-1}{M_{1}/M_{2}}=1-\frac{M_{2}}{M_{1}}\)
\[\frac{M}{M_{2}}=\frac{1}{1-\psi\phi_{1}\left(1-M_{2}/M_{1}\right)}\]
and \(\frac{M}{M_{1}}=1-\psi\phi_{1}\left(1-\frac{M_{2}}{M_{1}}\right)\)
\[\frac{1}{M}=\frac{1}{M_{2}}\left(1-\psi\phi_{1}\right)+\psi\frac{\phi_{1}}{M_ {1}}\]
When \(\psi\approx 1\), the inverse rule of mixture
\[\frac{1}{M}=\frac{\phi_{1}}{M_{1}}+\frac{\phi_{2}}{M_{2}}\]
is obtained.
(_See_ L. E. Nielsen, "Mechanical Properties of Polymers and Composites," Dekker, Vol. 2.)
Inverse gas chromatography (see Section 3.2.5) can be used to determine an apparent Flory interaction, \(\chi_{23,\text{app}}\), using a solvent probe through the relationship \[\chi_{23,\text{app}}\,^{\prime}\phi_{2}\phi_{3}=\ln\left(\frac{V_{g,b}}{w_{2}v_{2} +w_{3}v_{3}}\right)-\phi_{2}\ln\left(\frac{V_{g,2}}{v_{2}}\right)-\phi_{3}\ln \left(\frac{V_{g,3}}{v_{3}}\right)\]
where \(w\) and \(v\) are weight fraction and specific volume, respectively. Specific retention volumes for polystyrene (2), poly(2,6-dimethyl-1,4-phenylene oxide) (PPO) (3), and a 50/50 blend of PPO and polystyrene using toluene as the probe at 270\({}^{\circ}\)C are given below. From this data, calculate \(\chi_{23}\) for the PPO/PS blend. Is this value consistent with the reported miscibility of this blend?
\begin{tabular}{l l} \hline
**Coating** & \(V_{g}\) \\  & **mL/g-coating** \\ \hline PS & 2.38 \\ PPO & 2.96 \\ PPO/PS & 2.42 \\ \hline \end{tabular}
_Solution_
Rearranging, we have
\[\chi_{23,\text{app}}\,^{\prime}=\left[\ln\left(\frac{V_{g,\text{ blend}}}{w_{2}v_{2}+w_{3}v_{3}}\right)-\phi_{2}\ln\frac{V_{g,2}}{v_{2}}-\phi_{3}\ln \frac{V_{g,3}}{v_{3}}\right]\Bigg{/}\phi_{2}\phi_{3}\]
where
\[\rho_{2}\left(\text{PS}\right)=1.05\text{ g cm}^{-3}\] (Tables 9-3 and B-1, Appendix B) \[v_{2}=0.9524\text{ cm}^{3}\text{ g}^{-1}\] \[w_{2}=0.5\] \[\rho_{3}\left(\text{PPO}\right)=1.06\text{ g cm}^{-3}\] (Table 4-5) \[v_{3}=0.9434\text{ cm}^{3}\text{ g}^{-1}\] \[w_{3}=0.5\] \[\phi_{2}=\frac{w_{2}\big{/}\rho_{2}}{w_{2}\big{/}\rho_{2}+w_{3} \big{/}\rho_{3}}\] \[\phi_{3}=\frac{w_{3}\big{/}\rho_{3}}{w_{2}\big{/}\rho_{2}+w_{3} \big{/}\rho_{3}}\] \[w_{2}v_{2}+w_{3}v_{3}=0.5\big{(}0.9524\big{)}+0.5\big{(}0.9434 \big{)}=0.9479\] \[\phi_{2}=\frac{0.4762}{0.9479}=0.5024\] \[\phi_{3}=\frac{0.4717}{0.9479}=0.4976\text{ or }\phi_{3}=1-\phi_{2}\] \[\chi_{23,\text{app}}\,^{\prime}=\left[\ln\left(\frac{2.42}{0.9479 }\right)-0.5024\ln\left(\frac{2.38}{0.9524}\right)-0.4976\ln\left(\frac{2.96}{ 0.9434}\right)\right]\Bigg{/}0.5024\big{(}0.4976\big{)}=-0.367\]
The negative value is consistent with a compatible blend. The value reported for this blend at 270\({}^{\circ}\)C from IGC measurements using a toluene probe is -0.31 and -0.35\(\pm\)0.03 as an average value for five solvent probes (A. C. Su and J. R. Fried, in D. R. Lloyd, T. C. Ward, and H. P. Schreiber, eds., _ACS Symp. Series_ No. **390**, ACS, Washington, DC, 1989, pp. 155-165).

Molten polystyrene flows through a circular tube at 210\({}^{\circ}\)C under a pressure drop of 1,000 psi. Given that the inside diameter of the tube is 0.25 in. and that the tube is 3 in. in length, calculate the following:
**(a)** the (nominal) shear stress at the wall in units of N m\({}^{\text{-2}}\)
_Solution_
Eq. 11.38, \(\tau_{\text{w}}=\dfrac{R\Delta p}{2L}=\dfrac{0.125}{2\left(3\right)}\Delta p=2. 08\times 10^{\text{-2}}\Delta p\)
\[\Delta p=\dfrac{1000\text{ lb}_{\text{r}}}{\text{in}^{\text{2}}}\dfrac{1\text{ N}}{0.2248\text{ lb}_{\text{f}}}\dfrac{\text{in}^{\text{2}}}{\left(2.54\text{ cm}\right)^{\text{2}}}\dfrac{10^{\text{4}}\text{ cm}^{\text{2}}}{\text{m}^{\text{2}}}=6.895\times 10^{\text{6}}\text{ N m}^{\text{-2}}\]
\[\tau_{\text{w}}=2.08\times 10^{\text{-2}}\left(6.895\times 10^{\text{6}} \right)=1.43\times 10^{\text{5}}\text{ N m}^{\text{-2}}\]
**(b)** the (nominal) shear rate at the wall in s\({}^{\text{-1}}\)
_Solution_
Get values of power-law parameters \(m\) and \(n\) for PS (210\({}^{\circ}\)C) from Table 11-1
\[\dot{\gamma}_{\text{w}}=\left(\dfrac{\tau_{\text{w}}}{m}\right)^{\nicefrac{{ \gamma_{n}}}{{2}}}=\left(\dfrac{1.43\times 10^{\text{5}}}{2.38\times 10^{\text{4}}} \right)^{\text{4}}=1.30\times 10^{\text{3}}\text{ s}^{\text{-1}}\]
Note that this value is within the allowable range for the parameters used (i.e., 100-4500 s\({}^{\text{-1}}\)).
\[Q=\dfrac{n\pi R^{\text{3}}}{1+3n}\left(\dfrac{R\Delta p}{2mL} \right)^{\nicefrac{{\gamma_{n}}}{{2}}}=\dfrac{0.25\pi\left(0.125\right)^{ \text{3}}}{1+0.75}\left[\dfrac{0.125\Delta p}{2\left(2.38\times 10^{\text{4}} \right)3}\right]^{\text{4}}=19.1\text{ cm}^{\text{3}}\text{ s}^{\text{-1}}\]
Assume that flow is isothermal, steady, and fully developed.
### (a) Given that tensile (Trouton's) viscosity is defined as
\[\eta_{\text{T}}=\dfrac{\sigma}{\dot{\varepsilon}}\]
where \(\sigma\) and \(\varepsilon\) are the _true_ tensile stress and _true_ strain, respectively, show that
\[\ln L=\left(\dfrac{1}{\eta_{\text{T}}}\right)\sigma t+\ln\text{L}_{\text{o}}\]
when viscosity is independent of \(\dot{\varepsilon}\) and L\({}_{\text{o}}\) is the _initial_ length of the sample.
**(a)**
_Solution_
\[\sigma=\eta_{\text{T}}\,\dfrac{d\varepsilon}{dt}\text{ or }\sigma dt=\eta_{ \text{T}}d\left[\ln\left(L/\text{L}_{\text{o}}\right)\right]\]
integrating gives \(\sigma t=\eta_{\text{T}}\,\ln\left(L/\text{L}_{\text{o}}\right)\text{ or }\ln L=\left(\dfrac{1}{\eta_{\text{T}}}\right)\sigma t+\ln\text{L}_{\text{o}}\)
### Solution
\(\sigma=F/A\)
Assuming that PIB is incompressible (a reasonable assumption for an elastomer)
\(V=6.0\left(0.699\right)\left(0.155\right)=0.650\) cm\({}^{3}\)
Therefore, \(A=0.650/L\) at any time.
Force (\(F\)) is 75 g\({}_{\rm m}\times\) g\({}_{\rm o}\)=9.81 \(\times\) 10\({}^{2}\) cm s\({}^{2}\)

1 & 6.90 & 1.932 & 0.0942 & 7.81 & 4.69 \\ \hline

12 & 7.48 & 2.013 & 0.0869 & 8.47 & 60.98 \\ \hline

Note that the data provides a linear fit only from values of \(\sigma t=2.95\times 10^{8}\) g cm\({}^{-1}\) s\({}^{-1}\) and larger. A least squares fit (\(R^{2}=0.9927\)) of the six data points from \(\sigma t=2.95\times 10^{8}\) to \(1.28\times 10^{8}\) g cm\({}^{-1}\) s\({}^{-1}\) gives a slope of \(8.54\times 10^{-11}\) cm s g\({}^{-1}\) and an intercept of 1.959.
\(\frac{1}{\eta_{\rm T}}=8.54\times 10^{-11}\) cm s g\({}^{-1}\)
\(\eta_{\rm T}=1.17\times 10^{10}\) g cm\({}^{-1}\) s\({}^{-1}\)=1.17\(\times 10^{10}\) poise\(\frac{\mbox{Pa-s}}{10\) poise\(\mbox{Pa-s}}=1.17\times 10^{9}\) Pa-s
Note that extrapolation of the linear portion gives an intercept of 1.959 or an apparent L\({}_{\rm o}\) of 7.09 cm versus an actual L\({}_{\rm o}\) of 6.00 cm. The difference is due to initial elastic deformation (stretching of coiled chains) prior to viscous flow (i.e., chain slippage).
### Solution
A strip of polyisobutylene (800,000 molecular weight) is subjected to a fixed tensile load at ambient conditions. Initially, the sample is 0.699 cm wide, 6.0 cm long, and 0.155 cm thick. The strip is hung vertically and a mass of 75 g is attached to the bottom of the strip. The sample length is then recorded as a function of time with the following measurements:

Comment on the probable phenomenological significance of the actual intercept of the plot obtained by extrapolating the linear portion of the data.
Show that eq. 11.37, that defines shear stress in pressure flow through a capillary, is correct by balancing pressure force and shear force in a cylindrical element.
### Solution
The balance of forces gives
\[\pi r^{2}\Delta p=\tau 2\pi rL\ \ \mbox{or}\ \ \tau=\frac{r\Delta p}{2L}\]

Derive eqs. 11-72 and 11-74 for the axial annular Couette flow of a Newtonian fluid in a wire coating die.
_Solution_
Eq. 11.72
\(Q=-2\pi R\left(R-R_{{}_{i}}\right)V_{{}_{z}}\frac{2\kappa^{2}\ln\kappa-\kappa ^{2}+1}{4\left(1-\kappa\right)\ln\kappa}\)
Put eq. 11.30 in form (where \(R=D/2\))
\(Q=2\pi\int_{R_{{}_{i}}}^{R}ru_{{}_{z}}\left(r\right)dr\)Use eq. 11.32 in form
\[\frac{u_{z}}{U}=\frac{\ln\left(r/R\right)}{\ln\kappa}\]
or
\[u_{z}=\frac{V_{z}}{\ln\kappa}\ln\left(r/R\right)\]
where eq. 11.73 should read
\[\kappa=\frac{R_{i}}{R}\]
Then
\[Q=\frac{2\pi V_{z}}{\ln\kappa}\int_{R_{i}}^{R}r\ln\left(r/R\right)dr\]
Note
\[\int x\ln xdx=\frac{x^{2}}{2}\left(\ln x-\frac{1}{2}\right)\]
Therefore
\[\int_{R_{i}}^{R}r\ln\left(r/R\right)dr=\int_{R_{i}}^{R}r\ln rdr-\ln r\int_{R_{i }}^{R}rdr=\left[\frac{r^{2}}{2}\left(\ln r-\frac{1}{2}\right)-\left(\frac{r^{2 }}{2}\right)\ln R\right]_{R_{i}}^{R}=\]
\[\frac{1}{2}R^{2}\left(\ln R-\frac{1}{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2}R_{i}^{2}\left( \ln R_{i}-\frac{1}{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2}R^{2}\ln R-\frac{1}{2}R_{1}^{2}\ln R= -\frac{1}{4}\left(R^{2}-R_{i}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2}R_{i}^{2}\ln\kappa\]
Next
\[Q=-2\pi V_{z}\left(\frac{R^{2}-R_{i}^{2}+2R_{i}^{2}\ln\kappa}{4\ln\kappa}\right)\]
Multiply numerator and denominator by \(\left(R-R_{i}\right)R\) gives
\[Q=-2\pi V_{z}R\left(R-R_{i}\right)\left[\frac{R^{2}-R_{i}^{2}+2R_{i}^{2}\ln \kappa}{4R\left(R-R_{i}\right)\ln\kappa}\right]\]
Division of the numerator and denominator in brackets by \(R^{2}\) and substitution of \(\kappa=R_{i}/R\) gives eq. 11.68.
Next eq. 11.70
\[\dot{m}_{\epsilon}=\dot{m}_{\mathrm{d}}\]
\[Q=Q_{\mathrm{d}}+Q_{\mathrm{p}}=V_{z}\pi\left[\left(R_{i}+h\right)^{2}-R_{i} ^{2}\right]\rho=-2\pi\rho^{\prime}\left(R-R_{i}\right)V_{z}F\left(\kappa\right)\]
where \(F\left(\kappa\right)\) is defined by eq. 11.75. Rearrangement gives
\[\rho h^{2}+2R_{i}\rho h+2\rho^{\prime}R\left(R-R_{i}\right)F\left(\kappa \right)=0\]
Using the quadratic formula (Appendix E), we have
\[h^{\prime}=\frac{h}{R_{i}}=-1+\left[1-\frac{2\rho^{\prime}\left(R-R_{i} \right)F\left(\kappa\right)}{\rho R_{i}}\right]^{\prime 2}=\left[1-\frac{2\rho^{ \prime}}{\kappa\rho}\left(\frac{1}{\kappa}-1\right)F\left(\kappa\right) \right]^{\prime 2}-1\]11.12A Newtonian fluid having a viscosity of 15,000 poise is to be coated on a wire having a diameter of 0.06 inch through an annular die of 0.08-inch inside diameter. The length of the die is 1.25 inch. Assuming isothermal flow, calculate the required pressure drop (in psi) across the die to produce a uniform coating having a thickness of 0.06 inch. The wire is moving at a velocity of 100 ft min-1. What is the nominal shear rate in the die?
_Solution_
This is a problem not specified developed in Section 11.5.2, but can be solved with the information provided. For a Newtonian fluid subject to both isothermal drag and pressure flows,
\[Q=Q_{\rm d}+Q_{\rm p}\ \ \big{(}\mbox{see eq. 5-29 in Middleman}\big{)}\]
and
\[\dot{m}_{\rm c}=\dot{m}_{\rm d}+\dot{m}_{\rm p}\,.\]
Assuming \(\rho=\rho^{\prime}\), we get
\[V_{z}\pi\bigg{[}\big{(}R_{i}+h\big{)}^{2}-{R_{i}}^{2}\bigg{]}=-2\pi R\big{(}R- R_{i}\big{)}V_{z}\,\frac{2\kappa^{2}\ln\kappa-\kappa^{2}+1}{2\big{(}1-\kappa \big{)}\ln\kappa}+\frac{\pi\Delta pR^{4}}{8\mu L}\Bigg{[}1-\kappa^{4}-\frac{ \big{(}1-\kappa^{2}\big{)}^{2}}{\ln\big{(}1/\kappa\big{)}}\,\Bigg{]}\]
where \(\kappa=R_{i}\big{/}R\). Need to substitute the parameters given in the problem and solve for the pressure drop, \(\Delta p\). Given and calculated parameters are \(\mu=15,000\) poise ; \(h=0.06\) in; \(R=0.04\) in; \(L=\)1.25 in; \(\kappa=0.75\); \(V_{z}=100\) ft min-1; and \(R_{i}=0.03\) in. Note 10 poise = 1 Pa-sec and 1 Pa =1.45\(\times\)10\({}^{-4}\) psi. Substitution gives \(\Delta p=0.00609\) psi.
11.13Derive eq. 11-76 for a PLF in a wire coating operation.
_Solution_
No pressure flow, PLF. Start with eq. 11.36 for isothermal axial annular Couette flow of a PLF. Put this expression for \(Q\) into eq. 11.72 for \(\dot{m}_{\rm d}\) and equate with eq. 11.70 for \(\dot{m}_{\rm c}\). Rearrangement and solution of the quadratic gives the expression for the dimensionless thickness, eq. 11.76.
## Chapter 12
12.1An asymmetric hollow fiber of polysulfone has a surface pore area, \(A_{3}/A_{2}\), of \(1.9\times 10^{-6}\) and an effective skin thickness of 1000 A. If the fiber is coated with a 1-\(\mu\)m layer of silicone rubber, calculate the effective \(P/\ell\) for the coated membrane for CO\({}_{2}\) and the permselectivity for CO\({}_{2}\)/CH\({}_{4}\).
_Solution_
Use eq. 12.25 with permeability data given in Table 12-4.
For CO\({}_{2}\),
\[\frac{P}{\ell}=\Bigg{[}\frac{10^{-6}}{4553}+\frac{10^{-7}}{4.9+4553\big{(}1.9 \times 10^{-6}\big{)}}\Bigg{]}^{-1}=4.86\times 10^{7}\ \mbox{barrer cm}^{-1}\]
For CH\({}_{4}\),\[\frac{P}{\ell}=\left[\frac{10^{-6}}{1339}+\frac{10^{-7}}{0.213+1339\left(1.9\times 1 0^{-6}\right)}\right]^{-1}=2.15\times 10^{6}\text{ barrer cm}^{-1}\]
\[\alpha_{\text{CH4}}^{\text{CO2}}=\frac{\left(P/\ell\right)_{\text{CO2}}}{\left( P/\ell\right)_{\text{CH4}}}=\frac{4.86\times 10^{7}}{2.15\times 10^{6}}=23\]
This value matched the reported permselectivity of polysulfone (see Table 12-4).
12.2What pore size is required for Knudsen flow of oxygen and nitrogen through a porous membrane? What would be the ratio of diffusion coefficient, \(D(\text{O}_{2})/D(\text{N}_{2})\), for the permeation of air through this membrane. How does this ratio compare to that for the permeation of air through a polysulfone membrane hollow fiber membrane. How does this ratio of diffusion coefficients compare to the ideal permselectivity, \(\alpha(\text{O}_{2},\text{N}_{2})\), reported for oxygen/nitrogen through the polysulfone membrane.
_Solution_
Using eq. 12.8
\[\frac{D\left(\text{O}_{2}\right)}{D\left(\text{N}_{2}\right)}=\left[\frac{M \left(\text{N}_{2}\right)}{M\left(\text{O}_{2}\right)}\right]^{\!\!1/2}= \left(\frac{14.0067}{15.9994}\right)^{\!\!1/2}=0.936\]
The Knudsen number is the ratio of mean free path to pore diameter (see for example J. Gilron, A. Soffer, _J. Membr. Sci._**209**, 339 (2002). The mean free path is given as
\[\lambda=\frac{3\eta}{2P}\frac{\left(\pi RT\right)^{\!\!1/2}}{2M}\]
Typical diameters are in the area of 5 A.
\(D(\text{O}_{2})/D(\text{N}_{2})=3.6\) while \(P(\text{O}_{2})/P(\text{N}_{2})=5.6\) for PSF due to higher O\({}_{2}\) solubility. _See_ Koros et al., _Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci._**22**, 47 (1992).
12.3What are the limitations, if any, to the statement that \(P=SD\) (eq. 12.7)?
_Solution_
Equation 12.9 requires sufficiently low gas solubility that Henry's law is valid and the diffusion coefficient is independent of concentration (usually a good assumption for supercritical gases in rubbery polymers). See the excellent review by Stern (_J. Membr. Sci._**94**, 1 (1994)).
13.1Poly(2,6-dimethyl-1,4-phenylene oxide) (PDMPO) can be partially crystallized in solution (i.e., solvent-induced crystallization). (**a**) Calculate the density of 100% crystalline PDMPO using the group-contribution parameters given in Table 13-1. (**b**) If the crystallinity of a semicrystalline sample of PDMPO is 8%, estimate its crystallinity using the relationship
\[V_{\infty}=x_{\text{c}}V_{\text{c}}+(1-x_{\text{c}})V_{\text{a}}\]
where \(x_{\text{c}}\) is the degree of crystallinity, \(V_{\text{c}}\) is the molar specific volume of a 100% crystalline polymer, and \(V_{\text{a}}\) is the molar specific volume of the totally amorphous polymer.
_Solution_
For \(V_{\text{a}}\), see Example Problems 13.1
**(a)**
\[V_{\text{c}}=7.1+94=101.1\frac{\text{cm}^{3}}{\text{mol}}\frac{\text{mol}}{120.2\text{ g}}=0.841\frac{\text{cm}^{3}}{\text{g}}\]\[V_{\rm sc}=0.08\big{(}0.8411\big{)}+0.92\big{(}0.9318\big{)}=0.0673+0.8573=0.9246 \frac{\rm cm^{3}}{\rm g}\]
\[\rho_{\rm sc}=\frac{1}{0.9246}=1.082\frac{\rm g}{\rm cm^{3}}\]

question: What material design could minimize damage or keep an aircraft canopy from shattering due to rocks or birds?
answer:
The design involves sandwiching a thin sheet of transparent polymer between two layers of ceramic (traditional window glass) to prevent complete disintegration when the canopy fails.

**1-8**:
context:
**1-6**: We would like to produce a transparent canopy for an aircraft. If we were to use a ceramic (that is, traditional window glass) canopy, rocks or birds might cause it to shatter. Design a material that would minimize damage or at least keep the canopy from breaking into pieces.
Solution: We might sandwich a thin sheet of a transparent polymer between two layers of the glass. This approach, used for windshields of automobiles, will prevent the "safety" glass from completely disintegrating when it fails, with the polymer holding the broken pieces of glass together until the canopy can be replaced.
Another approach might be to use a transparent, "glassy" polymer material such as polycarbonate. Some polymers have reasonably good impact properties and may resist failure. The polymers can also be toughened to resist impact by introducing tiny globules of a rubber, or elastomer, into the polymer; these globules improve the energy-absorbing ability of the composite polymer, while being too small to interfere with the optical properties of the material.
1-7Coiled springs ought to be very strong and stiff. Si\({}_{3}\)N\({}_{4}\) is a strong, stiff material. Would you select this material for a spring? Explain.
1-8Temperature indicators are sometimes produced from a coiled metal strip that uncoils a specific amount when the temperature increases. How does this work; from what kind of material would the indicator be made; and what are the important properties that the material in the indicator must possess?
1-9You would like to design an aircraft that can be flow by human power nonstop for a distance of 30 km. What types of material properties would you recommend?
1-9You would like to design an aircraft that can be flow by human power nonstop for a distance of 30 km. What types of material properties would you recommend?
1-9Such an aircraft must possess enough strength and stiffness to resist its own weight, the weight of the human "power source", and any aerodynamic forces imposed on it. On the other hand, it must be as light as possible to assure that the human can generate enough work to operate the aircraft. Composite materials, particularly those based on a polymer matrix, might comprise the bulk of the aircraft. The polymers have a light weight (with densities of less than half that of aluminum) and can be strengthened by introducing strong, stiff fibers made of glass, carbon, or other polymers. Composites having the strength and stiffness of steel, but with only a fraction of the weight, can be produced in this manner.
* You would like to place a three-foot diameter microsatellite into orbit. The satellite will contain delicate electronic equipment that will send and receive radio signals from earth. Design the outer shell within which the electronic equipment is contained. What properties will be required and what kind of materials might be considered? Solution: The shell of the microsatellite must satisfy several criteria. The material should have a low density, minimizing the satellite weight so that it can be lifted economically into its orbit; the material must be strong, hard, and impact resistant in order to assure that any "space dust" that might strike the satellite does not penetrate and damage the electronic equipment; the material must be transparent to the radio signals that provide communication between the satellite and earth; and the material must provide some thermal insulation to assure that solar heating does not damage the electronics. One approach might be to use a composite shell of several materials. The outside surface might be a very thin reflective metal coating that would help reflect solar heat. The main body of the shell might be a light weight fiber-reinforced composite that would provide impact resistance (preventing penetration by dust particles) but would be transparent to radio signals.
* What properties should the head of a carpenter's hammer possess? How would you manufacture a hammer head? Solution: The head for a carpenter's hammer is produced by forging, a metal-working process; a simple steel shape is heated and formed in several steps while hot into the required shape. The head is then heat treated to produce the required mechanical and physical properties. The striking face and claws of the hammer should be hard--the metal should not dent or deform when driving or removing nails. Yet these portions must also possess some impact resistance, particularly so that chips do not flake off the striking face and cause injuries.
* The hull of the space shuttle consists of ceramic tiles bonded to an aluminum skin. Discuss the design requirements of the shuttle hull that led to the use of this combination of materials. What problems in producing the hull might the designers and manufacturers have faced? Solution: The space shuttle experiences extreme temperatures during re-entry into earth's atmosphere; consequently a thermal protection system must be used to prevent damage to the structure of the shuttle (not to mention its contents!). The skin must therefore be composed of a material that has an exceptionally low thermal conductivity. The material must be capable of being firmly attached to the skin of the shuttle and to be easily repaired when damage occurs. The tiles used on the space shuttle are composed of silica fibers bonded together to produce a very low density ceramic. The thermal conductivity is so low that a person can hold on to one side of the tile while the opposite surface is red hot. The tiles are attached to the shuttle skin using a rubbery polymer that helps assure that the forces do not break the tile loose, which would then expose the underlying skin to high temperatures.
* You would like to select a material for the electrical contacts in an electrical switching device which opens and closes frequently and forcefully. What properties should the contact material possess? What type of material might you recommend? Would Al2O3 be a good choice? Explain.
* The material must have a high electrical conductivity to assure that no electrical heating or arcing occurs when the switch is closed. High purity (and therefore very soft) metals such as copper, aluminum, silver or gold provide the high conductivity. However the device must also have good wear resistance, requiring that the material be hard. Most hard, wear resistant materials have poor electrical conductivity.
One solution to this problem is to produce a particulate composite material composed of hard ceramic particles embedded in a continuous matrix of the electrical conductor. For example, silicon carbide particles could be introduced into pure aluminum; the silicon carbide particles provide wear resistance while aluminum provides conductivity. Other examples of these materials are described in Chapter 16.
Al2O3 by itself would not be a good choice--alumina is a ceramic material and is an electrical insulator. However alumina particles dispersed into a copper matrix might provide wear resistance to the composite.
* Aluminum has a density of 2.7 g/cm3. Suppose you would like to produce a composite material based on aluminum having a density of 1.5 g/cm3. Design a material that would have this density. Would introducing beads of polyethylene, with a density of 0.95 g/cm3, into the aluminum be a likely possibility? Explain.
* In order to produce an aluminum-matrix composite material with a density of 1.5 g/cm3, we would need to select a material having a density considerably less than 1.5 g/cm3. While polyethylene's density would make it a possibility, the polyethylene has a very low melting point compared to aluminum; this would make it very difficult to introduce the polyethylene into a solid aluminum matrix--processes such as casting or powder metallurgy would destroy the polyethylene. Therefore polyethylene would NOT be a likely possibility.
One approach, however, might be to introduce _hollow_ glass beads. Although ceramic glasses have densities comparable to that of aluminum, a hollow bead will have a very low density. The glass also has a high melting temperature and could be introduced into liquid aluminum for processing as a casting.
* You would like to be able to identify different materials without resorting to chemical analysis or lengthy testing procedures. Describe some possible testing and sorting techniques you might be able to use based on the physical properties of materials.
* Some typical methods might include: measuring the density of the material (may help in separating metal groups such as aluminum, copper, steel, magnesium, etc.), determining the electrical conductivity of the material (may help in separating ceramics and polymers from metallic alloys), measuring the hardness of the material (perhaps even just using a file), and determining whether the material is magnetic or nonmagnetic (may help separate iron from other metallic alloys).
* You would like to be able to physically separate different materials in a scrap recycling plant. Describe some possible methods that might be used to separate materials such as polymers, aluminum alloys, and steels from one another. Solution: Steels can be magnetically separated from the other materials; steel (or carbon-containing iron alloys) are ferromagnetic and will be attracted by magnets. Density differences could be used--polymers have a density near that of water; the specific gravity of aluminum alloys is around 2.7; that of steels is between 7.5 and 8. Electrical conductivity measurements could be used--polymers are insulators, aluminum has a particularly high electrical conductivity.
* Some pistons for automobile engines might be produced from a composite material containing small, hard silicon carbide particles in an aluminum alloy matrix. Explain what benefits each material in the composite may provide to the overall part. What problems might the different properties of the two materials cause in producing the part? Solution: Aluminum provides good heat transfer due to its high thermal conductivity. It has good ductility and toughness, reasonably good strength, and is easy to cast and process. The silicon carbide, a ceramic, is hard and strong, providing good wear resistance, and also has a high melting temperature. It provides good strength to the aluminum, even at elevated temperatures. However there may be problems producing the material--for example, the silicon carbide may not be uniformly distributed in the aluminum matrix if the pistons are produced by casting. We need to assure good bonding between the particles and the aluminum--the surface chemistry must therefore be understood. Differences in expansion and contraction with temperature changes may cause debonding and even cracking in the composite.

question: How do temperature indicators made from a coiled metal strip work, and what kind of material would be used for the indicator?
answer:
The indicator works by uncoiling a specific amount when the temperature increases. The important properties that the material in the indicator must possess include the ability to uncoil and be resilient at various temperatures. The specific material used would depend on these properties.

The thermal conductivity is so low that a person can hold on to one side of the tile while the opposite surface is red hot. The tiles are attached to the shuttle skin using a rubbery polymer that helps assure that the forces do not break the tile loose, which would then expose the underlying skin to high temperatures.
* You would like to select a material for the electrical contacts in an electrical switching device which opens and closes frequently and forcefully. What properties should the contact material possess? What type of material might you recommend? Would Al2O3 be a good choice? Explain.
* The material must have a high electrical conductivity to assure that no electrical heating or arcing occurs when the switch is closed. High purity (and therefore very soft) metals such as copper, aluminum, silver or gold provide the high conductivity. However the device must also have good wear resistance, requiring that the material be hard. Most hard, wear resistant materials have poor electrical conductivity.
One solution to this problem is to produce a particulate composite material composed of hard ceramic particles embedded in a continuous matrix of the electrical conductor. For example, silicon carbide particles could be introduced into pure aluminum; the silicon carbide particles provide wear resistance while aluminum provides conductivity. Other examples of these materials are described in Chapter 16.
Al2O3 by itself would not be a good choice--alumina is a ceramic material and is an electrical insulator. However alumina particles dispersed into a copper matrix might provide wear resistance to the composite.
* Aluminum has a density of 2.7 g/cm3. Suppose you would like to produce a composite material based on aluminum having a density of 1.5 g/cm3. Design a material that would have this density. Would introducing beads of polyethylene, with a density of 0.95 g/cm3, into the aluminum be a likely possibility? Explain.
* In order to produce an aluminum-matrix composite material with a density of 1.5 g/cm3, we would need to select a material having a density considerably less than 1.5 g/cm3. While polyethylene's density would make it a possibility, the polyethylene has a very low melting point compared to aluminum; this would make it very difficult to introduce the polyethylene into a solid aluminum matrix--processes such as casting or powder metallurgy would destroy the polyethylene. Therefore polyethylene would NOT be a likely possibility.
One approach, however, might be to introduce _hollow_ glass beads. Although ceramic glasses have densities comparable to that of aluminum, a hollow bead will have a very low density. The glass also has a high melting temperature and could be introduced into liquid aluminum for processing as a casting.
* You would like to be able to identify different materials without resorting to chemical analysis or lengthy testing procedures. Describe some possible testing and sorting techniques you might be able to use based on the physical properties of materials.
* Some typical methods might include: measuring the density of the material (may help in separating metal groups such as aluminum, copper, steel, magnesium, etc.), determining the electrical conductivity of the material (may help in separating ceramics and polymers from metallic alloys), measuring the hardness of the material (perhaps even just using a file), and determining whether the material is magnetic or nonmagnetic (may help separate iron from other metallic alloys).
* You would like to be able to physically separate different materials in a scrap recycling plant. Describe some possible methods that might be used to separate materials such as polymers, aluminum alloys, and steels from one another. Solution: Steels can be magnetically separated from the other materials; steel (or carbon-containing iron alloys) are ferromagnetic and will be attracted by magnets. Density differences could be used--polymers have a density near that of water; the specific gravity of aluminum alloys is around 2.7; that of steels is between 7.5 and 8. Electrical conductivity measurements could be used--polymers are insulators, aluminum has a particularly high electrical conductivity.
* Some pistons for automobile engines might be produced from a composite material containing small, hard silicon carbide particles in an aluminum alloy matrix. Explain what benefits each material in the composite may provide to the overall part. What problems might the different properties of the two materials cause in producing the part? Solution: Aluminum provides good heat transfer due to its high thermal conductivity. It has good ductility and toughness, reasonably good strength, and is easy to cast and process. The silicon carbide, a ceramic, is hard and strong, providing good wear resistance, and also has a high melting temperature. It provides good strength to the aluminum, even at elevated temperatures. However there may be problems producing the material--for example, the silicon carbide may not be uniformly distributed in the aluminum matrix if the pistons are produced by casting. We need to assure good bonding between the particles and the aluminum--the surface chemistry must therefore be understood. Differences in expansion and contraction with temperature changes may cause debonding and even cracking in the composite.

question: Using the densities and atomic weights given in Appendix A, calculate and compare the number of atoms per cubic centimeter in (a) lead and (b) lithium.
context:
**2-6(a)**: Aluminum foil used for storing food weighs about 0.3 g per square inch. How many atoms of aluminum are contained in this sample of foil?
Solution: In a one square inch sample:
\[\text{number}=\frac{(0.3\text{ g})(6.02\times 10^{23}\text{ atoms/mol})}{26.981\text{ g/mol}}=6.69 \times 10^{21}\text{ atoms}\]

**2-6(b)**: Using the densities and atomic weights given in Appendix A, calculate and compare the number of atoms per cubic centimeter in (a) lead and (b) lithium.
Solution: (a) In lead:
\[\frac{(11.36\text{ g/cm}^{3})(1\text{ cm}^{3})(6.02\times 10^{23}\text{ atoms/mol})}{207.19\text{ g/mol}}=3.3 \times 10^{22}\text{ atoms/cm}^{3}\]

**2-7(a)**: Using data in Appendix A, calculate the number of iron atoms in one ton (2000 pounds).
Solution: (2000 lb)(454 g/lb)(6.02\(\times\) 10^{23}\text{ atoms/mol})\)\(55.847\text{ g/mol}=9.79\times 10^{27}\text{ atoms/ton}\)

**2-7(b)**: Using data in Appendix A, calculate the volume in cubic centimeters occupied by one mole of boron.
Solution: (1 mol)(10.81 g/mol)
2.3 g/cm

question: In order to plate a steel part with a 0.002 in. thick layer of nickel, how many atoms of nickel are required?
context: **2-8**: In order to plate a steel part having a surface area of 200 in.\({}^{2}\) with a 0.002 in. thick layer of nickel, (a) how many atoms of nickel are required and (b) how many moles of nickel are required? Solution: Volume = (200 in.\({}^{2}\))(0.002 in.)(2.54 cm/in.)\({}^{3}\) = 6.555 cm\({}^{3}\) (a) (6.555 cm\({}^{3}\)) (8.902 g/cm\({}^{3}\))(6.02 \(\times\) 10\({}^{23}\) atoms/mol) 58.71 g/mol 58.71 g/mol = 5.98 \(\times\) 10\({}^{23}\) atoms (b) (6.555 cm\({}^{3}\))(8.902 g/cm\({}^{3}\)) 58.71 g/mol = 0.994 mol Ni required

question: Suppose an element has a valence of 2 and an atomic number of 27. Based only on the quantum numbers, how many electrons must be present in the 3\(d\) energy level?
context: **2-9**: Suppose an element has a valence of 2 and an atomic number of 27. Based only on the quantum numbers, how many electrons must be present in the 3\(d\) energy level? Solution: We can let \(x\) be the number of electrons in the 3\(d\) energy level. Then: 1s\({}^{2}\) 2s\({}^{2}\)2p\({}^{6}\)3s\({}^{2}\)3p\({}^{6}\)3d\({}^{4}\)4s\({}^{2}\) (must be 2 electrons in 4\(s\) for valence = 2) Since 27-(2+2+6+2+6+2) = 7 = \(x\) there must be _7 electrons_ in the 3\(d\) level.

question: Why is there little, if any, ionic bonding component in the intermetallic compound Ni\({}_{3}\)Al?
answer: There is little, if any, ionic bonding component in the compound Ni\({}_{3}\)Al because the electronegativity of nickel is about 1.8 and that of aluminum is 1.5, which are relatively close values, indicating a predominantly metallic bonding.
context: * 2 Bonding in the intermetallic compound Ni\({}_{3}\)Al is predominantly metallic. Explain why there will be little, if any, ionic bonding component. The electronegativity of nickel is about 1.8. Solution: The electronegativity of Al is 1.5, while that of Ni is 1.8. These values are relatively close, so we wouldn't expect much ionic bonding. Also, both are metals and prefer to give up their electrons rather than share or donate them.

question: What are the melting temperatures of the elements Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, Ta, Cr, Mo, W, Mn, Tc, Re, Fe, Ru, Os, Co, Rh, Ir, Ni, Pd, and Pt?
context: * 2 Plot the melting temperatures of elements in the 4A to 8-10 columns of the periodic table versus atomic number (i.e., plot melting temperatures of Ti through Ni, Zr through Pd, and Hf through Pt). Discuss these relationships, based on atomic bonding and binding energy, (a) as the atomic number increases in each row of the periodic table and (b) as the atomic number increases in each column of the periodic table. Solution: Ti -1668 Zr -1852 Hf-2227 V -1900 Nb -2468 Ta -2996 Cr -1875 Mo-2610 W -3410 Mn -1244 Tc -2200 Re-3180 Fe -1538 Ru -2310 Os-2700 Co -1495 Rh -1963 Ir -2447 Ni -1453 Pd -1552 Pt -1769For each row, the melting temperature is highest when the outer "\(d\)" energy level is partly full. In Cr, there are 5 electrons in the 3\(d\) shell; in Mo, there are 5 electrons in the 4\(d\) shell; in W there are 4 electrons in the 5\(d\) shell. In each column, the melting temperature increases as the atomic number increases--the atom cores contain a larger number of tightly held electrons, making the metals more stable.

question: Would you expect MgO or magnesium to have the higher modulus of elasticity? Explain.
answer: MgO should have the higher modulus of elasticity, with a value of 30*10^6 psi.
context: * 2.31 Would you expect MgO or magnesium to have the higher modulus of elasticity? Explain. Solution: MgO has ionic bonds, which are strong compared to the metallic bonds in Mg. A higher force will be required to cause the same separation between the ions in MgO compared to the atoms in Mg. Therefore, MgO should have the higher modulus of elasticity. In Mg, \(E=6\times 10^{6}\) psi; in MgO, \(\mathrm{E}=30\times 10^{6}\) psi.

question: Would you expect Al2O3 or aluminum to have the higher coefficient of thermal expansion? Explain.
context:
* 2.32 Would you expect Al2O3 or aluminum to have the higher coefficient of thermal expansion? Explain. Solution: Al2O3 has stronger bonds than Al; therefore, Al2O3 should have a lower thermal expansion coefficient than Al. In Al, \(\alpha=25\times 10^{-6}\) cm/cm\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C; in Al2O3, \(\alpha=6.7\times 10^{-6}\) cm/cm\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C.

* 2.33 Aluminum and silicon are side by side in the periodic table. Which would you expect to have the higher modulus of elasticity (\(E\))? Explain. Solution: Silicon has covalent bonds; aluminum has metallic bonds. Therefore, Si should have a higher modulus of elasticity.

context:
* 3.27 The density of potassium, which has the BCC structure and one atom per lattice point, is 0.855 g/cm\({}^{3}\). The atomic weight of potassium is 39.09 g/mol. Calculate (a) the lattice parameter; and (b) the atomic radius of potassium.
Solution: (a) Using Equation 3-5: \[0.855\ \mathrm{g/cm^{3}=\frac{(2\ atoms/cell)(39.09\ g/mol)}{(a_{o})^{3}(6.02\times 1 0^{23}\ atoms/mol)}}\] \[a_{\mathrm{o}}^{\ 3}=1.5189\times 10^{-22}\ \mathrm{cm^{3}}\ \mathrm{or}\ a_{ \mathrm{o}}=5.3355\times 10^{-8}\ \mathrm{cm}\] (b) From the relationship between atomic radius and lattice parameter: \[r=\frac{\left(\sqrt{3}\right)\left(5.3355\times 10^{-8}\mathrm{cm}\right)}{4}=2. 3103\times 10^{-8}\mathrm{cm}\]
