context:
* 3-323. Bismuth has a hexagonal structure, with \(a_{\rm o}=0.4546\) nm and \(c_{\rm o}=1.186\) nm. The density is 9.808 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the atomic weight is 208.98 g/mol. Determine (a) the volume of the unit cell and (b) how many atoms are in each unit cell. Solution: (a) The volume of the unit cell is \(V=a_{\rm o}^{\rm 2}c_{\rm o}\)cos30. \(\begin{array}{l}\mbox{V}=(0.4546\ \mbox{nm})^{\rm 2}(1.186\ \mbox{nm})(\mbox{cos30})=0.21226\ \mbox{nm}^{\rm 3}\\ \mbox{}=2.1226\times 10^{-22}\ \mbox{cm}^{\rm 3}\end{array}\) (b) If "\(x\)" is the number of atoms per unit cell, then: \[9.808\ \mbox{g/cm}^{\rm 3}=\ \frac{(x\ \mbox{atoms/cell})(208.98\ \mbox{g/mol})}{(2.1226\times 10^{-22}\ \mbox{cm}^{\rm 3})(6.02\times 10^{23}\ \mbox{atoms/mol})}\] \[x=6\ \mbox{atoms/cell}\]
3. Gallium has an orthorhombic structure, with \(a_{\rm o}=0.45258\) nm, \(b_{\rm o}=0.45186\) nm, and \(c_{\rm o}=0.76570\) nm. The atomic radius is 0.1218 nm. The density is 5.904 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the atomic weight is 69.72 g/mol. Determine (a) the number of atoms in each unit cell and (b) the packing factor in the unit cell. Solution: The volume of the unit cell is \(V=a_{\rm o}b_{\rm o}c_{\rm o}\) or \[\begin{array}{l}\mbox{V}=(0.45258\ \mbox{nm})(0.45186\ \mbox{nm})(0.76570\ \mbox{nm})=0.1566\ \mbox{nm}^{\rm 3}\\ \mbox{}=1.566\times 10^{-22}\ \mbox{cm}^{\rm 3}\end{array}\] (a) From the density equation: \[5.904\ \mbox{g/cm}^{\rm 3}=\ \frac{(x\ \mbox{atoms/cell})(69.72\ \mbox{g/mol})}{(1.566\times 10^{-22}\ \mbox{cm}^{\rm 3})(6.02\times 10^{23}\ \mbox{atoms/mol})}\] \[x=8\ \mbox{atoms/cell}\] (b) From the packing factor (PF) equation: \[\mbox{PF}=\frac{(8\ \mbox{atoms/cell})(4\pi/3)(0.1218\ \mbox{nm})^{\rm 3}}{0.1566\ \mbox{nm}^{\rm 3}}=0.387\]
3. Beryllium has a hexagonal crystal structure, with \(a_{\rm o}=0.22858\) nm and \(c_{\rm o}=0.35842\) nm. The atomic radius is 0.1143 nm, the density is 1.848 g/cm\({}^{3}\), and the atomic weight is 9.01 g/mol. Determine (a) the number of atoms in each unit cell and (b) the packing factor in the unit cell. Solution: \[\mbox{V}=(0.22858\ \mbox{nm})^{\rm 2}(0.35842\ \mbox{nm})\mbox{cos}\ 30=0.01622\ \mbox{nm}^{\rm 3}=16.22\times 10^{-24}\ \mbox{cm}^{\rm 3}\] (a) From the density equation: \[1.848\ \mbox{g/cm}^{\rm 3}=\ \frac{(x\ \mbox{atoms/cell})(9.01\ \mbox{g/mol})}{(1 6.22\times 10^{-24}\ \mbox{cm}^{\rm 3})(6.02\times 10^{23}\ \mbox{atoms/mol})}\] \[x=2\ \mbox{atoms/cell}\] (b) The packing factor (PF) is: \[\mbox{PF}=\frac{(2\ \mbox{atoms/cell})(4\pi/3)(0.1143\ \mbox{nm})^{\rm 3}}{0.01622\ \mbox{nm}^{\rm 3}}=0.77\]

* Determine the repeat distance, linear density, and packing fraction for FCC nickel, which has a lattice parameter of 0.35167 nm, in the [100], [110], and [111] directions. Which of these directions is close-packed? Solution: \(r=\sqrt{2}\)(0.35167) / 4 = 0.1243 nm For [100]: repeat distance = \(a_{\rm o}\) = 0.35167 nm linear density = 1/\(a_{\rm o}\) = 2.84 points/nm linear packing fraction = (2)(0.1243)(2.84) = 0.707 For [110]: repeat distance = \(\sqrt{2}\)\(a_{\rm o}\)/2 = 0.2487 nm linear density = \(2\) / \(\sqrt{2}\)\(a_{\rm o}\) = 4.02 points/nm linear packing fraction = (2)(0.1243)(4.02) = 1.0 For [111]: repeat distance = \(\sqrt{3}\)\(a_{\rm o}\) = 0.6091 nm linear density = \(1\) / \(\sqrt{3}\)\(a_{\rm o}\) = 1.642 points/nm linear packing fraction = (2)(0.1243)(1.642) = 0.408 Only the [110] is close packed; it has a linear packing fraction of 1.
* Determine the repeat distance, linear density, and packing fraction for BCC lithium, which has a lattice parameter of 0.35089 nm, in the [100], [110], and [111] directions. Which of these directions is close-packed? Solution: \(r=\sqrt{3}\) (0.35089) / 4 = 0.1519 nm For [100]: repeat distance = \(a_{\rm o}\) = 0.35089 nm linear density = 1/\(a_{\rm o}\) = 2.85 points/nm linear packing fraction = (2)(0.1519)(2.85) = 0.866 For [110]: repeat distance = \(\sqrt{2}\)\(a_{\rm o}\) = 0.496 nm linear density = \(1\) / \(\sqrt{2}\)\(a_{\rm o}\) = 2.015 points/nm linear packing fraction = (2)(0.1519)(2.015) = 0.612For [111]: repeat distance = \(\sqrt{3}\,a_{\rm o}/2\) = 0.3039 nm
linear density = \(2/\sqrt{3}\,a_{\rm o}\) = 3.291 points/nm
linear packing fraction = (2)(0.1519)(3.291) = 1
The [111] direction is close packed; the linear packing factor is 1.

question: What is the planar density for FCC nickel in the (100), (110), and (111) planes?
answer:
Planar density for (100) plane = 0.1617 x 10^16 points/cm^2, Planar density for (110) plane = 0.1144 x 10^-16 points/cm^2, Planar density for (111) plane = 0.1867 x 10^16 points/cm^2
---
context:
**3-71**: Determine the planar density and packing fraction for FCC nickel in the (100), (110), and (111) planes. Which, if any, of these planes is close-packed?
Solution: \(a_{\rm o}=3.5167\) A
_For (100):_
\[\mbox{planar density}=\frac{2}{(3.5167\times 10^{-8}\,\mbox{cm})^{2}}=0.1617 \times 10^{16}\,\mbox{points/cm}^{2}\]
packing fraction = \(\frac{2\pi r^{2}}{\left(4\pi/\sqrt{2}\right)^{2}}=0.7854\)_For (110):_
\[\text{planar density} =\frac{2\text{ points}}{(3.5167\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm})\left(\sqrt{2}\right)(3.5167\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm})}\] \[=0.1144\times 10^{-16}\text{ points/cm}^{2}\] \[\text{packing fraction} =\frac{2\pi r^{2}}{\sqrt{2}\left(4r/\sqrt{2}\right)^{2}}=0.555\]
_For (111):_
From the sketch, we can determine that the area of the (111) plane is \(\left(\sqrt{2}a_{o}/2\right)\left(\sqrt{3}a_{o}/\sqrt{2}\right)=0.866a_{o}^{2}\). There are (3)(\(\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}\)) + (3)(\(\nicefrac{{1}}{{6}}\)) = 2 atoms in this area.
\[\text{planar density} =\frac{2\text{ points}}{0.866(3.5167\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm})^{2}}\] \[=0.1867\times 10^{16}\text{ points/cm}^{2}\] \[\text{packing fraction} =\frac{2\pi\left(\sqrt{2}a_{o}/4\right)^{2}}{0.866a_{o}^{2}}=0.907\]
The (111) is close packed.

question: What is the packing fraction for FCC nickel in the (100), (110), and (111) planes?
answer: Packing fraction for (100) plane = 0.7854, Packing fraction for (110) plane = 0.555, Packing fraction for (111) plane = 0.907

question: How many (111) interplanar spacings \(d_{111}\) thick is the 1 mm thick sheet of FCC rhodium?
context:
**3-73**: Suppose that FCC rhodium is produced as a 1 mm thick sheet, with the (111) plane parallel to the surface of the sheet. How many (111) interplanar spacings \(d_{111}\) thick is the sheet? See Appendix A for necessary data.
\[\text{Solution:}\qquad d_{111}=\frac{a_{\text{o}}}{\sqrt{1^{2}+1^{2}+1^{2}}}= \frac{3.796\text{ \AA}}{\sqrt{3}}=2.1916\text{ \AA}\]
\[\text{thickness}=\frac{(1\text{ mm/10 mm/cm})}{2.1916\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm}}=4.563\times 10^{6}\text{ }d_{111}\text{ spacings}\]

question: In a FCC unit cell, how many \(d_{111}\) are present between the 0,0,0 point and the 1,1,1 point?
context:
**3-74**: In a FCC unit cell, how many \(d_{111}\) are present between the 0,0,0 point and the 1,1,1 point?
\[\text{Solution:}\qquad\text{The distance between the 0,0,0 and 1,1,1 points is }\sqrt{3}a_{\text{o}}\text{. The interplanar spacing is}\]
\[d_{111}=a_{\text{o}}/\sqrt{1^{2}+1^{2}+1^{2}}=a_{\text{o}}/\sqrt{3}\]
Therefore the number of interplanar spacings is
\[\text{number of }d_{111}\text{ spacings}=\sqrt{3}a_{\text{o}}/(a_{\text{o}}/\sqrt{3})=3\]

question: Would you expect NiO to have the cesium chloride, sodium chloride, or zinc blende structure?
context: * 3-88 Would you expect NiO to have the cesium chloride, sodium chloride, or zinc blende structure? Based on your answer, determine (a) the lattice parameter, (b) the density, and (c) the packing factor. Solution: \(r_{\rm Ni}\)+2 = 0.69 A \(r_{\rm O}\)\({}^{-2}\) = 1.32 A \(r_{\rm O}\)\({}^{-2}\) = 0.52 CN = 6 A A coordination number of 8 is expected for the CsCl structure, and a coordination number of 4 is expected for ZnS. But a coordination number of 6 is consistent with the _NaCl structure_. (a) \(a_{\rm o}\) = 2(0.69) + 2(1.32) = 4.02 A (b) \(\rho\) = \(\frac{(4\ {\rm of\ each\ ion/cell})(58.71+16\ {\rm g/mol})}{(4.02\times 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm})^{3}(6.02 \times 10^{23}\ {\rm atoms/mol})}\) = 7.64 g/cm\({}^{3}\) (c) PF = \(\frac{(4\pi/3)(4\ {\rm ions/cell})[(0.69)^{3}+(1.32)^{3}]}{(4.02)^{3}}\) = 0.678

\(r_{\rm Be}\)/\(r_{\rm O}\) = 0.265 CN = 4 \(\therefore\) Zinc Blende (a) \(\sqrt{3}\,a_{\rm o}\) = \(4r_{\rm Be}\)+2 + \(4r_{\rm O}\)\({}^{-2}\) = 4(0.35 + 1.32) = 6.68 or \(a_{\rm o}\) = 3.8567 A (b) \(\rho\) = \(\frac{4(9.01+16\ {\rm g/mol})}{(3.8567\times 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm})^{3} \ (6.02\times 10^{23}\ {\rm atoms/mol})}\) = 2.897 g/cm\({}^{3}\) (c) PF = \(\frac{(4\pi/3)(4)[(0.35)^{3}+8(1.32)^{3}]}{(3.8567)^{3}}\) = 0.6843-91Would you expect CsBr to have the sodium chloride, zinc blende, fluorite, or cesium chloride structure? Based on your answer, determine (a) the lattice parameter, (b) the density, and (c) the packing factor. Solution: \(r_{\text{Cs}}^{+1}=1.67\) A \(r_{\text{Br}}^{-1}=1.96\) A \(r_{\text{Br}}^{-1}=0.852\) CN = 8 \(\therefore\) CsCl (a) \(\sqrt{3}\)\(a_{\text{o}}=2r_{\text{Cs}}^{-1}+2r_{\text{Br}}^{-1}=2(1.96+1.67)=7.26\) or \(a_{\text{o}}=4.1916\) A (b) \(\rho=\dfrac{79.909+132.905\text{ g/mol}}{(4.1916\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm})^{3}\ (6.02\times 10^{23}\text{ atoms/mol})}=4.8\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) (c) \(\text{PF}=\dfrac{(4\pi/3)[(1.96)^{3}+(1.67)^{3}]}{(4.1916)^{3}}=0.693\)
3-92Sketch the ion arrangement on the (110) plane of ZnS (with the zinc blende structure) and compare this arrangement to that on the (110) plane of CaF\({}_{2}\) (with the flourite structure). Compare the planar packing fraction on the (110) planes for these two materials. Solution: ZnS: \(\sqrt{3}\)\(a_{\text{o}}=4r_{\text{Zn}}^{+2}+4r_{\text{S}}^{-2}\) \(\sqrt{3}\)\(a_{\text{o}}=4(0.074\text{ nm})+4(0.184\text{ nm})\) \(a_{\text{o}}=0.596\text{ nm}\) \(\sqrt{2}\)\(a_{\text{o}}=0.492\)
\(\text{CaF}_{2}\): \(\sqrt{3}\)\(a_{\text{o}}=4r_{\text{Ca}}^{+2}+4r_{\text{F}}^{-1}\) \(\sqrt{3}\)\(a_{\text{o}}=4(0.099\text{ nm})+4(0.133\text{ nm})\) \(a_{\text{o}}=0.536\text{ nm}\) \(\text{PPF}=\dfrac{\Big{(}2\Big{)}\Big{(}\pi r_{\text{C}}^{2}\Big{)}+\Big{(}4 \Big{)}\Big{(}\pi r_{\text{F}}^{2}\Big{)}}{\Big{(}\sqrt{2}a_{\text{o}}\Big{)} a_{\text{o}}}=\dfrac{2\pi\Big{(}0.099\Big{)}^{2}+4\pi\Big{(}0.133\Big{)}^{2}}{ \sqrt{2}\Big{(}0.536\text{ nm}\Big{)}^{2}}=0.699\)3. **3-93**: MgO, which has the sodium chloride structure, has a lattice parameter of 0.396 nm. Determine the planar density and the planar packing fraction for the (111) and (222) planes of MgO. What ions are present on each plane? Solution: As described in the answer to Problem 3-71, the area of the (111) plane is 0.866\(a_{\mathrm{o}}\)\({}^{2}\). \[a_{\mathrm{o}}=2r_{\mathrm{Mg}}\)\({}^{+2}+2r_{\mathrm{o}}\)\({}^{-2}=2(0.66+1.32)=3.96\) A (111): P.D. = \(\frac{2\) Mg (0.866)(3.96 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-8}\) cm)\({}^{2}}{}=0.1473\times 10^{16}\) points/cm\({}^{2}\) PPF = \(\frac{2\pi(0.66)^{2}}{(0.866)(3.96)^{2}}=0.202\) (222): P.D. = \(0.1473\times 10^{16}\) points/cm\({}^{2}\) PPF = \(\frac{2\pi(1.32)^{2}}{(0.866)(3.96)^{2}}=0.806\) 3-100**: Polypropylene forms an orthorhombic unit cell with lattice parameters of \(a_{\mathrm{o}}\) = 1.450 nm, \(b_{\mathrm{o}}\) = 0.569 nm, and \(c_{\mathrm{o}}\) = 0.740 nm. The chemical formula for the propylene molecule, from which the polymer is produced, is C\({}_{3}\)H\({}_{6}\). The density of the polymer is about 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\). Determine the number of propylene molecules, the number of carbon atoms, and the number of hydrogen atoms in each unit cell. Solution: MW\({}_{\mathrm{PP}}\) = 3 C + 6 H = 3(12) + 6 = 42 g/mol
\[0.90\ \mathrm{g/cm^{3}}=\frac{(x\ C_{3}H_{6})(42\ g/mol)}{(14.5\ cm)(5.69\ cm)(7.40\ cm)(10^{-24})(6.02\times 10^{23}\ \mathrm{molecules/mol})}\]
\[x=8\ C_{3}H_{6}\ \mathrm{molecules\ or\ 24\ C\ atoms\ and\ 48\ H\ atoms}\]

question: Would you expect CsBr to have the sodium chloride, zinc blende, fluorite, or cesium chloride structure? Based on your answer, determine (a) the lattice parameter, (b) the density, and (c) the packing factor.
answer: (a) Lattice parameter = 4.1916 A, (b) Density = 4.8 g/cm^3, (c) Packing factor = 0.693

question: MgO, which has the sodium chloride structure, has a lattice parameter of 0.396 nm. Determine the planar density and the planar packing fraction for the (111) and (222) planes of MgO. What ions are present on each plane?
answer: (111): Planar density = 0.1473 × 10^16 points/cm^2, Planar packing fraction = 0.202; (222): Planar density = 0.1473 × 10^16 points/cm^2, Planar packing fraction = 0.806

question: Polypropylene forms an orthorhombic unit cell with lattice parameters of \(a_{\mathrm{o}}\) = 1.450 nm, \(b_{\mathrm{o}}\) = 0.569 nm, and \(c_{\mathrm{o}}\) = 0.740 nm. question: Calculate the number of SiO\({}_{2}\) ions, the number of silicon ions, and the number of oxygen ions in each unit cell.
context:
**3-101**: The density of cristobalite is about 1.538 g/cm\({}^{3}\), and it has a lattice parameter of 0.8037 nm. Calculate the number of SiO\({}_{2}\) ions, the number of silicon ions, and the number of oxygen ions in each unit cell. Solution: 1.538 g/cm\({}^{3}\) = \(\frac{(x\ SiO_{2})[28.08+2(16)\ g/mol]}{8.037\times 10^{-8}\ \mathrm{cm})^{3}(6.02\times 10^{23}\ \mathrm{ions/mol})}\]
\[x=8\ SiO_{2}\ \mathrm{or\ 8\ Si^{+4} ions\ and\ 16\ O^{-2} ions}\]
\[x=8\ C_{3}H_{6}\ \mathrm{molecules\ or\ 24\ C\ atoms\ and\ 48\ H\ atoms}\]

question: A diffracted x-ray beam is observed from the (220) planes of iron at a 2\(\theta\) angle of 99.1\({}^{\rm o}\) when x-rays of 0.15418 nm wavelength are used. Calculate the lattice parameter of the iron.
context:
**3-104**: The density of cristobalite is about 1.538 g/cm\({}^{3}\), and it has a lattice parameter of 0.8037 nm. Calculate the number of SiO\({}_{2}\) ions, the number of silicon ions, and the number of oxygen ions in each unit cell. Solution: 1.538 g/cm\({}^{3}\) = \(\frac{(x\ SiO_{2})[28.08+2(16)\ g/mol]}{8.037\times 10^{-8}\ \mathrm{cm})^{3}(6.02\times 10^{23} \ \mathrm{ions/mol})}\]
\[x=8\ C_{3}H_{6}\ \mathrm{molecules\ or\* A diffracted x-ray beam is observed from the (220) planes of iron at a 2\(\theta\) angle of 99.1\({}^{\rm o}\) when x-rays of 0.15418 nm wavelength are used. Calculate the lattice parameter of the iron. Solution: \(\sin\,\theta=\lambda/2d_{\rm 220}\) \(\sin(99.1/2)=\ \frac{0.15418\sqrt{2^{2}\,+\,2^{2}\,+\,0^{2}}}{2a_{\rm o}}\) \(a_{\rm o}\,=\,\frac{0.15418\sqrt{8}}{2\sin\!\left(49.55\right)}=\,0.2865\) nm
* A diffracted x-ray beam is observed from the (311) planes of aluminum at a 2\(\theta\) angle of 78.3\({}^{\rm o}\) when x-rays of 0.15418 nm wavelength are used. Calculate the lattice parameter of the aluminum. Solution: \(\sin\,\theta=\lambda/d_{\rm 311}\) \(a_{\rm o}\,=\,\frac{0.15418\sqrt{3^{2}\,+\,1^{2}\,+\,1^{2}}}{2\sin\!\left(78. 3/2\right)}=\,0.40497\) nm
* Figure 3-56 shows the results of an x-ray diffraction experiment in the form of the intensity of the diffracted peak versus the 2\(\theta\) diffraction angle. If x-rays with a wavelength of 0.15418 nm are used, determine (a) the crystal structure of the metal, (b) the indices of the planes that produce each of the peaks, and (c) the lattice parameter of the metal. Solution: The 2\(\theta\) values can be estimated from Figure 3-56: \(2\theta\) values must be divided by 0.077 (one third the first sin\({}^{2}\theta\) value) in order to produce a possible sequence of numbers)
* The 3,4,8,11, \(\ldots\) sequence means that the material is FCC
* The average \(a_{\rm o}=0.8781\) nm
* Figure 3-57 shows the results of an x-ray diffraction experiment in the form of the intensity of the diffracted peak versus the \(2\theta\) diffraction angle. If x-rays with a wavelength of 0.0717 nm are used, determine (a) the crystal structure of the metal, (b) the indices of the planes that produce each of the peaks, and (c) the lattice parameter of the metal. Solution: The \(2\theta\) values can be estimated from the figure: 
* The sequence 1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8 (which includes the "7") means that the material is BCC.
* The average \(a_{o}=0.2307\) nmImperfections in the Atomic and Ionic Arrangements

question: Calculate the number of vacancies per cm\({}^{3}\) expected in copper at 1080\({}^{\circ}\)C.
context:
**4-1**: Calculate the number of vacancies per cm\({}^{3}\) expected in copper at 1080\({}^{\circ}\)C (just below the melting temperature). The activation energy for vacancy formation is 20,000 cal/mol. Solution: \[n = \frac{\left(4\text{ atoms/u.c.}\right)}{\left(3.6151\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm}\right)^{3}} =8.47\times 10^{22}\text{ atoms/cm}^{3}\] \[n_{v} = 8.47\times 10^{22}\text{ exp}[-20,000/(1.987)(1353)]\] \[= 8.47\times 10^{22}\text{ exp}(-7.4393)=4.97\times 10^{19}\text{ vacancies/cm}^{3}\]

**4-2**: The fraction of lattice points occupied by vacancies in solid aluminum at 660\({}^{\circ}\)C is \(10^{-3}\). What is the activation energy required to create vacancies in aluminum? Solution: \[n_{v}/n=10^{-3}=\text{exp}[-Q/(1.987)(933)]\] \[\text{ln}(10^{-3})=-6.9078=-Q/(1.987)(933)\] \[Q=12,800\text{ cal/mol}\]

question: What is the fraction of the lattice points that contain vacancies?
context: * 4-4 The density of a sample of HCP beryllium is 1.844 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the lattice parameters are \(a_{\text{o}}=0.22858\) nm and \(c_{\text{o}}=0.35842\) nm. Calculate (a) the fraction of the lattice points that contain vacancies and (b) the total number of vacancies in a cubic centimeter. Solution: \(V_{\text{u.c.}}=(0.22858\text{ nm})^{2}(0.35842\text{ nm})\text{cos}30=0.01622 \text{ nm}^{3}\) \(=1.622\times 10^{-23}\text{ cm}^{3}\) (a) From the density equation: \[1.844\text{ g/cm}^{3}=\frac{(x)(9.01\text{ g/mol})}{(1.622\times 10^{-23} \text{ cm}^{3})(6.02\times 10^{23}\text{ atoms/mol})}\quad x=1.9984\] fraction = \(\frac{2-1.9984}{2}=0.0008\) (b) number = \(\frac{0.0016\text{ vacancies/uc}}{1.622\times 10^{-23}\text{ cm}^{3}}=0.986\times 10^{20}\text{ vacancies/cm}^{3}\)

question: What is the total number of vacancies in a cubic centimeter?
context: * 4-4 The density of a sample of HCP beryllium is 1.844 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the lattice parameters are \(a_{\text{o}}=0.22858\) nm and \(c_{\text{o}}=0.35842\) nm. Calculate (a) the fraction of the lattice points that contain vacancies and (b) the total number of vacancies in a cubic centimeter. Solution: \(V_{\text{u.c.}}=(0.22858\text{ nm})^{2}(0.35842\text{ nm})\text{cos}30=0.01622 \text{ nm}^{3}\) \(=1.622\times 10^{-23}\text{ cm}^{3}\) (a) From the density equation: \[1.844\text{ g/cm}^{3}=\frac{(x)(9.01\text{ g/mol})}{(1.622\times 10^{-23} \text{ cm}^{3})(6.02\times 10^{23}\text{ atoms/mol})}\quad x=1.9984\] fraction = \(\frac{2-1.9984}{2}=0.0008\) (b) number = \(\frac{0.0016\text{ vacancies/uc}}{1.622\times 10^{-23}\text{ cm}^{3}}=0.986\times 10^{20}\text{ vacancies/cm}^{3}\)

question: Calculate the number of vacancies per cubic centimeter in BCC lithium.
context: * 4-5 BCC lithium has a lattice parameter of \(3.5089\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm}\) and contains one vacancy per 200 unit cells. Calculate (a) the number of vacancies per cubic centimeter and (b) the density of Li. Solution: (a) \(\frac{1\text{ vacancy}}{(200)(3.5089\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm})^{3}}=1.157\times 10^{20}\text{ vacancies/cm}^{3}\) (b) In 200 unit cells, there are 399 Li atoms. The atoms/cell are 399/200: \[\rho=\frac{(399/200)(6.94\text{ g/mol})}{(3.5089\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm})^{3}(6.02\times 10^{23}\text{ atoms/mol})}=0.532\text{ g/cm}^{3}\]

question: Calculate the density of the FCC lead.
context: * 4-6 FCC lead has a lattice parameter of 0.4949 nm and contains one vacancy per 500 Pb atoms. Calculate (a) the density and (b) the number of vacancies per gram of Pb. Solution: (a) The number of atoms/cell = (499/500)(4 sites/cell) \[\rho=\frac{(499/500)(4)(207.19\text{ g/mol})}{(4.949\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm})^{3}(6.02\times 10^{23}\text{ atoms/mol})}=11.335\text{ g/cm}^{3}\] (b) The 500 Pb atoms occupy 500 / 4 = 125 unit cells: \[\frac{1\text{ vacancy}}{\left(\frac{125\text{ cells}}{(4.949\times 10^{-8}\text{ cm})^{3}}\right)}\times\left[(1/11.335\text{ g/cm}^{3})\right]=5.82\times 10^{18}\text{ vacancies/g}\]

question: What is the number of anion vacancies per cm\({}^{3}\)?
context: * 4-12 Suppose one Schottky defect is present in every tenth unit cell of MgO. MgO has the sodium chloride crystal structure and a lattice parameter of 0.396 nm. Calculate (a) the number of anion vacancies per cm\({}^{3}\) and (b) the density of the ceramic. Solution: In 10 unit cells, we expect 40 Mg + 40 O ions, but due to the defect: \[40\ \mathrm{Mg}-1=39\] \[40\ \mathrm{O}\ -1=39\] \[1\ \mathrm{vacancy}/(10\ \mathrm{cells})(3.96\times 10^{-8}\ \mathrm{cm})^{3} =1.61\times 10^{21}\ \mathrm{vacancies}/\mathrm{cm}^{3}\] \[\rho=\frac{(39/40)(4)(24.312\ \mathrm{g/mol})+(39/40)(4)(16\ \mathrm{g/mol})}{(3.96\times 1 0^{-8}\ \mathrm{cm})^{3}(6.02\times 10^{23}\ \mathrm{atoms}/\mathrm{mol})}=4.205\ \mathrm{g/cm}^{3}\]

question: If the density of ZnS with a zinc blende structure is 3.02 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the lattice parameter is 0.59583 nm, determine the number of Schottky defects (a) per unit cell and (b) per cubic centimeter.
answer: (a) 0.0535 defects per unit cell, (b) 2.517×10\({}^{20}\) defects per cubic centimeter.
context: * 4-13 ZnS has the zinc blende structure. If the density is 3.02 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the lattice parameter is 0.59583 nm, determine the number of Schottky defects (a) per unit cell and (b) per cubic centimeter. Solution: Let \(x\) be the number of each type of ion in the unit cell. There normally are 4 of each type. (a) \[3.02\ \mathrm{g/cm}^{3}= \frac{x(65.38\ \mathrm{g/mol})+x(32.064\ \mathrm{g/mol})}{(5.9583 \times 10^{-8}\ \mathrm{cm})^{3}(6.02\times 10^{23}\ \mathrm{ions}/\mathrm{mol})} x=3.9465\] \[4-3.9465=0.0535\ \mathrm{defects}/\mathrm{u.c.}\] (b) \[\#\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{unit}\ \mathrm{cells}/\mathrm{cm}^{3}=1/(5.9683 \times 10^{-8}\ \mathrm{cm})^{3}=4.704\times 10^{21}\] Schottky defects per cm\({}^{3}=(4.704\times 10^{21})(0.0535)=2.517\times 10^{20}\)

question: Determine the interplanar spacing and the length of the Burgers vector for slip on the \((110)/[1\bar{1}1]\) slip system in BCC tantalum.
answer: The interplanar spacing is 2.335 Å and the length of the Burgers vector is 2.860 Å.
context:
**4-27**: Determine the interplanar spacing and the length of the Burgers vector for slip on the \((110)/[1\bar{1}1]\) slip system in BCC tantalum. Repeat, assuming that the slip system is a \((111)/[1\bar{1}0]\) system. What is the ratio between the shear stresses required for slip for the two systems? Assume that k = 2 in Equation 4-2.
Solution: (a) For \((110)/[1\bar{1}1]\):
\[b=(\dot{\gamma}2)\ (\sqrt{3})\ (3.3026\ \mathrm{\AA})=2.860\ \mathrm{\AA} \quad d_{110}=\frac{3.3026\ \mathrm{\AA}}{\sqrt{1^{2}+1^{2}+0^{2}}}=2.335\ \mathrm{\AA}\]
(b) If \((111)/[1\bar{1}0]\), then:
\[b=\sqrt{2}\ (3.3026\ \mathrm{\AA})=4.671\ \mathrm{\AA}\quad d_{111}=\frac{3.3026 \ \mathrm{\AA}}{\sqrt{1^{2}+1^{2}+1^{2}}}=1.907\ \mathrm{\AA}\]
(c) If we assume that k = 2 in Equation 4-2, then:
\[\left(d/b\right)_{a}=\frac{2.335}{2.86}=0.8166\qquad\quad\left(d/b\right)_{b}= \frac{1.907}{4.671}=0.408\]
\[\frac{\tau_{a}}{\tau_{b}}=\frac{\exp(-2(0.8166))}{\exp(-2(0.408))}=0.44\]

question: How many grams of aluminum, with a dislocation density of \(10^{10}\) cm/cm\({}^{3}\), are required to give a total dislocation length that would stretch from New York City to Los Angeles (3000 miles)?

\[\frac{(4.828\times 10^{8}\ \mathrm{cm})(2.699\ \mathrm{g/cm^{3}})}{(10^{10}\ \mathrm{cm/cm^{3}})}= 0.13\ \mathrm{g}\]

question: The strength of titanium is found to be 65,000 psi when the grain size is \(17\times 10^{-6}\) m and 82,000 psi when the grain size is \(0.8\times 10^{-6}\) m. Determine (a) the constants in the Hall-Petch equation and (b) the strength of the titanium when the grain size is reduced to \(0.2\times 10^{-6}\) m.
answer: The strength of the titanium when the grain size is reduced to \(0.2\times 10^{-6}\) m is 103,670 psi.
context:
* 4.49 The strength of titanium is found to be 65,000 psi when the grain size is \(17\times 10^{-6}\) m and 82,000 psi when the grain size is \(0.8\times 10^{-6}\) m. Determine (a) the constants in the Hall-Petch equation and (b) the strength of the titanium when the grain size is reduced to \(0.2\times 10^{-6}\) m. Solution: \[65,000 = \sigma_{\mbox{\tiny o}}+\mbox{K}\,\frac{1}{\sqrt{17\times 10^{-6}}}= \sigma_{\mbox{\tiny o}}+242.5\mbox{ K}\] \[82,000 = \sigma_{\mbox{\tiny o}}+\mbox{K}\,\frac{1}{\sqrt{0.8\times 10^{-6}}}= \sigma_{\mbox{\tiny o}}+1118.0\mbox{ K}\]
* By solving the two simultaneous equations: \[\mbox{K} = 19.4\mbox{ psi}\;/\sqrt{m}\;\;\;\;\;\;\sigma_{\mbox{\tiny o}}=60,290 \mbox{ psi}\] \[\mbox{(b)}\;\sigma=60,290+19.4\;/\sqrt{0.2\times 10^{-6}}\;=103,670\mbox{ psi}\]

We can determine K and \(\sigma_{o}\) either from the graph or by using two of the data points. 170 = \(\sigma_{o}\) + K(8.165) 145 = \(\sigma_{o}\) + K(4.472) 25 = 3.693K K = 6.77 MPa / \(\sqrt{\mathrm{mm}}\) \(\sigma_{o}\) = 114.7 MPa

question: At 750\({}^{\circ}\)C, what is the jump rate of atoms from one lattice position to another?
context: * 5-12 Atoms are found to move from one lattice position to another at the rate of \(5\times 10^{5}\) jumps/s at 400\({}^{\circ}\)C when the activation energy for their movement is 30,000 cal/mol. Calculate the jump rate at 750\({}^{\circ}\)C. Solution: \[\mbox{Rate}=\frac{5\times 10^{5}}{x}=\frac{c_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\exp[-30,000 (1.987)(673)]}{c_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\exp[-30,000(1.987)(1023)]}\;\;=\;\;\exp(-22.43 4+14.759)\] \[\frac{5\times 10^{5}}{x}=\exp(-7.675)=4.64\times 10^{-4}\] \[x=\frac{5\times 10^{5}}{4.64\times 10^{-4}}=1.08\times 10^{9}\mbox{ jumps/s}\]

question: The number of vacancies in a material is related to temperature by an Arrhenius equation. If the fraction of lattice points containing vacancies is \(8\times 10^{-5}\) at 600\({}^{\circ}\)C, determine the fraction at 1000\({}^{\circ}\)C.
context: * 5-13 The number of vacancies in a material is related to temperature by an Arrhenius equation. If the fraction of lattice points containing vacancies is \(8\times 10^{-5}\) at 600\({}^{\circ}\)C, determine the fraction at 1000\({}^{\circ}\)C. Solution: \[8\times 10^{-5}=\exp[-Q/(1.987)(873)]\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;Q=16, 364\mbox{ cal/mol}\] \[f=n_{\mbox{\tiny v}}/n=\exp[-16,364/(1.987)(1273)]=0.00155\]

question: Calculate (a) the activation energy and (b) the constant \(D_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\) for the given diffusion coefficients for Cr\({}^{+3}\) in Cr\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) at different temperatures.
answer: (a) The activation energy is \(59,230\) cal/mol. (b) The constant \(D_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\) is \(0.055\) cm\({}^{2}\)/s.
context: * 5-24 The diffusion coefficient for Cr\({}^{+3}\) in Cr\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) is \(6\times 10^{-15}\) cm\({}^{2}\)/s at 727\({}^{\circ}\)C and is \(1\times 10^{-9}\) cm\({}^{2}\)/s at 1400\({}^{\circ}\)C. Calculate (a) the activation energy and (b) the constant \(D_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\). Solution: \[(\mbox{a)}\;\;\;\;\frac{6\times 10^{-15}}{1\times 10^{-9}}=\frac{D_{ \mbox{\tiny o}}\exp[-Q/(1.987)(1000)]}{D_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\exp[-Q/(1.987)(1673)]}\] \[6\times 10^{-6}=\exp[-Q(0.000503-0.00030)]=\exp[-0.000203\ Q]\] \[-12.024=-0.000203\ Q\quad\mbox{or}\quad\;\;\;Q=59, 230\mbox{ cal/mol}\] \[(\mbox{b)}\;\;\;1\times 10^{-9}=D_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\exp[-59,230/(1.987) (1673)]=D_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\exp(-17.818)\] \[1\times 10^{-9}=1.828\times 10^{-8}\ D_{\mbox{\tiny o}}\quad\mbox{or} \quad\;\;D_{\mbox{\tiny o}}=0.055\mbox{ cm}^{2}\mbox{/s}\]

question: Calculate (a) the activation energy and (b) the constant \(D_{\alpha}\) for the diffusion coefficient for O\({}^{-2}\) in Cr\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\).
answer: (a) The activation energy is 95,700 cal/mol. (b) The constant \(D_{\alpha}\) is 1.98 cm\({}^{2}\)/s.

question:
Calculate the concentration gradient in atomic percent Sb per cm.
2.
context: **5-42**: A 0.2-mm thick wafer of silicon is treated so that a uniform concentration gradient of antimony is produced. One surface contains 1 Sb atom per \(10^{8}\) Si atoms and the other surface contains 500 Sb atoms per \(10^{8}\) Si atoms. The lattice parameter for Si is 5.407 A (Appendix A). Calculate the concentration gradient in (a) atomic percent Sb per cm and (b) Sb atoms/cm\({}^{3}\)-cm. Solution: \[\Delta c/\Delta x=\frac{(1/10^{8}-500/10^{8})}{0.02\text{ cm}}\times 100\%=-0.02495\text{ at}\%/\text{cm}\] \[a_{\alpha}=5.4307\text{ \AA}\qquad\qquad\qquad V_{\text{unit cell}}=160.16 \times 10^{-24}\text{ cm}^{3}\] \[c_{1}=\frac{(8\text{ Si atoms/u.c.})(1\text{ Sb}/10^{8}\text{Si})}{160.16 \times 10^{-24}\text{ cm}^{3}/\text{u.c.}}=0.04995\times 10^{16}\text{ Sb atoms/cm}^{3}\] \[c_{2}=\frac{(8\text{ Si atoms/u.c.})(500\text{ Sb}/10^{8}\text{Si})}{160.16 \times 10^{-24}\text{ cm}^{3}/\text{u.c.}}=24.975\times 10^{16}\text{ Sb atoms/cm}^{3}\] \[\Delta c/\Delta x=\frac{(0.04995-24.975)\times 10^{16}}{0.02\text{ cm}}=-1.246\times 10^{19}\text{ Sb atoms/cm}^{3}\text{ cm}\]

question: Determine the maximum allowable temperature that will produce a flux of less than 2000 H atoms/cm^2-s through a BCC iron foil when the concentration gradient is \(-5\times 10^{16}\ {\rm atoms/cm^{3}-cm}\).
context:
**5-48**: Determine the maximum allowable temperature that will produce a flux of less than 2000 H atoms/cm^2-s through a BCC iron foil when the concentration gradient is \(-5\)\(\times\)\(10^{16}\ {\rm atoms/cm^{3}-cm}\). (Note the negative sign for the flux.)
Solution:
\[2000\ {\rm H\ atoms/cm^{2}-s}=-0.0012\ {\rm exp}[-3600/1.987T][-5\times 10^{16} \ {\rm atoms/cm^{3}-cm}]\]
\[\ln(3.33\times 10^{-11})=-3600/1.987T\]
\[T=-3600/((-24.12)(1.987))=75\ {\rm K}=-198^{\rm o}{\rm C}\]

**5-53**: Explain why a rubber balloon filled with helium gas deflates over time.
Solution: Helium atoms diffuse through the chains of the polymer material due to the small size of the helium atoms and the ease at which they diffuse between the loosely-packed chains.

question: The electrical conductivity of \({\rm Mn_{3}O_{4}}\) is \(8\times 10^{-18}\ {\rm ohm^{-1}-cm^{-1}}\) at 140\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\) and is \(1\times 10^{-7}\ {\rm ohm^{-1}-cm^{-1}}\) at 400\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\). Determine the activation energy that controls the temperature dependence of conductivity. Explain the process by which the temperature controls conductivity.
context:
**5-59**: The electrical conductivity of \({\rm Mn_{3}O_{4}}\) is \(8\times 10^{-18}\ {\rm ohm^{-1}-cm^{-1}}\) at 140\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\) and is \(1\times 10^{-7}\ {\rm ohm^{-1}-cm^{-1}}\) at 400\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\). Determine the activation energy that controls the temperature dependence of conductivity. Explain the process by which the temperature controls conductivity.
Solution: \[\frac{8\times 10^{-18}}{1\times 10^{-7}}=\frac{C_{\rm o}{\rm exp }[-Q/(1.987)(413)]}{C_{\rm o}{\rm exp}[-Q/(1.987)(673)]}\]
\[8\times 10^{-11}={\rm exp}(-0.000471Q)\ \ \ \ {\rm or}\ \ \ \ -23.25=-0.000471Q\]
\[Q=49,360\ {\rm cal/mol}\]
Electrical charge is carried by the diffusion of the atoms; as the temperature increases, more rapid diffusion occurs and consequently the electrical conductivity is higher.

question: Compare the rate at which oxygen ions diffuse in \({\rm Al_{2}O_{3}}\) with the rate at which aluminum ions diffuse in \({\rm Al_{2}O_{3}\) at 1500\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\). Explain the difference.
answer: The rate of diffusion for oxygen ions in \({\rm Al_{2}O_{3}}\) is \(3.47\times 10^{-16}\) cm\(^2\)/s, while the rate of diffusion for aluminum ions in \({\rm Al_{2}O_{3}}\) is \(2.48\times 10^{-13}\) cm\(^2\)/s.
context:
**5-60**: Compare the rate at which oxygen ions diffuse in \({\rm Al_{2}O_{3}}\) with the rate at which aluminum ions diffuse in \({\rm Al_{2}O_{3}}\) at 1500\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\). Explain the difference.
Solution: \[{D_{\rm O}}^{-2}=1900\ {\rm exp}[-152,000/(1.987)(1773)]=3.47\times 1 0^{-16}\ {\rm cm^{2}/s}\]
\[{D_{\rm Al}}^{+3}=28\ {\rm exp}[-114,000/(1.987)(1773)]=2.48\times 1 0^{-13}\ {\rm cm^{2}/s}\]
The ionic radius of the oxygen ion is 1.32 A, compared with the aluminum ionic radius of 0.51 A; consequently it is much easier for the smaller aluminum ion to diffuse in the ceramic.

question: Compare the diffusion coefficients of carbon in BCC and FCC iron at the allotropic transformation temperature of 912\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\) and explain the difference.
answer: BCC iron has a diffusion coefficient of \(1.51 \times 10^{-6}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\), while FCC iron has a diffusion coefficient of \(1.92 \times 10^{-7}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\).
context:
**5-61**: Compare the diffusion coefficients of carbon in BCC and FCC iron at the allotropic transformation temperature of 912\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\) and explain the difference.
Solution: \[{D_{\rm BCC}}=0.011\ {\rm exp}[-20,900/(1.987)(1185)]=1.51\times 1 0^{-6}\ {\rm cm^{2}/s}\]
\[{D_{\rm FCC}}=0.23\ {\rm exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1185)]=1.92\times 10^{-7}\ {\rm cm^{2}/s}\]
[MISSING_PAGE_FAIL:50]
FCC: \(\frac{1.2-\ c_{x}}{1.2-0.05}\ =\mbox{erf}[0.05/\left(2\sqrt{(1.97\times 10^{-7})(86,4 00)}\ \right)]\ =\mbox{erf}[0.192]=0.2139\)
\[c_{x}=0.95\%\ \mbox{C}\]
Faster diffusion occurs in the looser packed BCC structure, leading to the higher carbon content at point "x".
* What temperature is required to obtain 0.50% C at a distance of 0.5 mm beneath the surface of a 0.20% C steel in 2 h. when 1.10% C is present at the surface? Assume that the iron is FCC. Solution: \(\frac{1.1-0.5}{1.1-0.2}=0.667=\mbox{erf}[0.05/2\sqrt{Dt}\ \ ]\) \(0.05/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.685\) or \(\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.0365\) or \(\ Dt=0.00133\)
* \(t=(2\ \mbox{h})(3600\ \mbox{s/h})=7200\ \mbox{s}\) \(D=0.00133/7200=1.85\times 10^{-7}=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/1.9877]\) \(\exp(-16,558/T)=8.043\times 10^{-7}\) \(T=1180\mbox{K}=907^{\circ}\mbox{C}\)
* A 0.15% C steel is to be carburized at \(1100^{\circ}\) C, giving 0.35% C at a distance of 1 mm beneath the surface. If the surface composition is maintained at 0.90% C, what time is required? Solution: \(\frac{0.9-0.35}{0.9-0.15}=0.733=\mbox{erf}[0.1/2\sqrt{Dt}\ \ ]\) \(0.1/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.786\) or \(\ Dt=0.00405\) \(D=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1373)]=1.332\times 10^{-6}\ \mbox{cm}^{2}/\mbox{s}\) \(t=0.00405/1.332\times 10^{-6}=3040\ \mbox{s}=51\ \mbox{min}\)
* A 0.02% C steel is to be carburized at \(1200^{\circ}\)C in 4 h, with a point 0.6 mm beneath the surface reaching 0.45% C. Calculate the carbon content required at the surface of the steel. Solution: \(\frac{c_{x}-0.45}{c_{s}-0.02}=\mbox{erf}[0.06/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\) \(D=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1473)]=3.019\times 10^{-6}\ \mbox{cm}^{2}/\mbox{s}\) \(t=(4\ \mbox{h})(3600)=14,400\ \mbox{s}\) \(\sqrt{Dt}\ =\sqrt{(3.019\times 10^{-6})(14,400)}\ =\ 0.2085\) \(\mbox{erf}[0.06/(2)(0.2085)]=\mbox{erf}[0.144]=0.161\) \(\frac{c_{s}-0.45}{c_{s}-0.02}=0.161\ \ \mbox{or}\ \ c_{s}=0.53\%\ \mbox{C}\)
* A 1.2% C tool steel held at \(1150^{\circ}\)C is exposed to oxygen for 48 h. The carbon content at the steel surface is zero. To what depth will the steel be decarburized to less than 0.20% C? Solution: \(\frac{0-0.2}{0-1.2}\ =0.1667\ \ \therefore\ \ x^{\prime}/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.149\)\[D=0.23\ \mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1423)]=2.034\times 10^{-6}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t=(48\ \mathrm{h})(3600\ \mathrm{s/h})=17.28\ \times 10^{4}\ \mathrm{s}\] \[\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.5929\] Then from above, \(x=(0.149)(2)(0.5929)=0.177\ \mathrm{cm}\)
5-72A 0.80% C steel must operate at 950\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C in an oxidizing environment, where the carbon content at the steel surface is zero. Only the outermost 0.02 cm of the steel part can fall below 0.75% C. What is the maximum time that the steel part can operate? Solution: \[\frac{0-0.75}{0-0.8}=0.9375=\mathrm{erf}[x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \ \ \ \cdot\ \ x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =1.384\] \[0.02/\ 2\sqrt{Dt}\ =1.384\ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ \ \sqrt{Dt}\ =0.007226\ \ \ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ \ \ \ Dt=5.22\times 10^{-5}\] \[D=0.23\ \mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1223)]=3.03\times 10^{-7}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t=5.22\times 10^{-5}\ /\ 3.03\times 10^{-7}=172\ \mathrm{s}=2.9\ \mathrm{min}\]
5-73A BCC steel containing 0.001% N is nitridated at 550\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C for 5 h. If the nitrogen content at the steel surface is 0.08%, determine the nitrogen content at 0.25 mm from the surface. Solution: \[\frac{0.08-c_{s}}{0.08-0.001}=\mathrm{erf}[0.025/\ 2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathrm{t=(5\ h)(3600\ \mathrm{s/h})=1.8\times 10^{4}\ \mathrm{s}}\] \[D=0.0047\ \mathrm{exp}[-18,300/(1.987)(823)]\] \[=6.488\times 10\mathrm{-8\ cm^{2}/s}\] \[\sqrt{Dt}=0.0342\] \[\mathrm{erf}[0.025/(2)(0.0342)]=\mathrm{erf}(0.3655)=0.394\] \[\frac{0.08-c_{s}}{0.079}=0.394\ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ c_{s}\ =0.049\%\ \mathrm{N}\]
5-74What time is required to nitride a 0.002% N steel to obtain 0.12% N at a distance of 0.002 in. beneath the surface at 625\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C? The nitrogen content at the surface is 0.15%. Solution: \[\frac{0.15-0.12}{0.15-0.002}=0.2027=\mathrm{erf}[x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \cdot\ \ x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.2256\] \[D=0.0047\ \mathrm{exp}[-18,300/(1.987)(898)]=1.65\times 10^{-7} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[x=0.002\ \mathrm{in.}=0.00508\ \mathrm{cm}\] \[\frac{0.00508}{2\sqrt{(1.65\times 10^{-7})t}}=0.2256\] \[Dt=1.267\times 10^{-4}\ \mathrm{or}\ \mathrm{t=1.267\times 10^{-4}/1.65 \times 10^{-7}=768\ \mathrm{s}=12.8\ \mathrm{min}}\]
5-75We currently can successfully perform a carburizing heat treatment at 1200\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C in 1 h. In an effort to reduce the cost of the brick lining in our furnace, we propose to reduce the carburizing temperature to 950\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C. What time will be required to give us a similar carburizing treatment? Solution: \[D_{1200}=0.23\mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1473)]=3.019\times 10^{-6} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[D_{950}=0.23\mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1223)]=3.034\times 10^{-7} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\]\[t_{1200}=1\ \mathrm{h}\] \[t_{950}=D_{1200}\ t_{1200}/D_{950}=\frac{(3.019\times 10^{-6})(1)}{3.034 \times 10^{-7}}=9.95\ \mathrm{h}\]
* During freezing of a Cu-Zn alloy, we find that the composition is nonuniform. By heating the alloy to 600oC for 3 hours, diffusion of zinc helps to make the composition more uniform. What temperature would be required if we wished to perform this _homogenization_ treatment in 30 minutes? Solution: \[D_{600}=0.78\ \mathrm{exp}[-43,900/(1.987)(873)]=7.9636\times 10^{-12} \qquad t_{600}=3\ \mathrm{h}\] \[t_{x}=0.5\ \mathrm{h}\] \[D_{x}=D_{600}\ t_{600}/t_{x}=(7.9636\times 10^{-12})(3)/0.5\] \[D_{x}=4.778\times 10^{-11}=\ 0.78\ \mathrm{exp}[-43,900/1.9877]\] \[\mathrm{ln}\ (6.1258\times 10^{-11})=-23.516=-43,900/1.987\ T\] \[T=940\ \mathrm{K}=667^{o}\mathrm{C}\]
* A ceramic part made of MgO is sintered successfully at 1700oC in 90 minutes. To minimize thermal stresses during the process, we plan to reduce the temperature to 1500oC. Which will limit the rate at which sintering can be done: diffusion of magnesium ions or diffusion of oxygen ions? What time will be required at the lower temperature? Solution: Diffusion of oxygen is the slower of the two, due to the larger ionic radius of the oxygen. \[D_{1700}=0.000043\ \mathrm{exp}[-82,100/(1.987)(1973)]=3.455\times 10^{-14}\ \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[D_{1500}=0.000043\ \mathrm{exp}[-82,100/(1.987)(1773)]=3.255\times 10^{-15} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t_{1500}=D_{1700}\ t_{1700}/D_{1500}=\frac{(3.455\times 10^{-14})(9 0)}{3.255\times 10^{-15}}=955\ \mathrm{min}=15.9\ \mathrm{h}\]
* A Cu-Zn alloy has an initial grain diameter of 0.01 mm. The alloy is then heated to various temperatures, permitting grain growth to occur. The times required for the grains to grow to a diameter of 0.30 mm are Solution: Temperature (oC) Time (min) 500 80,000 600 700 120 800 10 850 3  Determine the activation energy for grain growth. Does this correlate with the diffusion of zinc in copper? (Hint: Note that rate is the reciprocal of time.) Solution: Temperature (oC) Time (min) 500 773 0.00129 80,000 1.25 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-5}\) 600 873 0.00115 3,000 3.33 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) 700 973 0.001028 120 8.33 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-3}\) 800 1073 0.000932 10 0.100 850 1123 0.000890 3 0.333From the graph, we find that \(Q=51\),286 cal/mol, which does correlate with the activation energy for diffusion of zinc in copper.

Solution: \[\frac{0.15-0.12}{0.15-0.002}=0.2027=\mathrm{erf}[x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \cdot\ \ x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.2256\] \[D=0.0047\ \mathrm{exp}[-18,300/(1.987)(898)]=1.65\times 10^{-7} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[x=0.002\ \mathrm{in.}=0.00508\ \mathrm{cm}\] \[\frac{0.00508}{2\sqrt{(1.65\times 10^{-7})t}}=0.2256\] \[Dt=1.267\times 10^{-4}\ \mathrm{or}\ \mathrm{t=1.267\times 10^{-4}/1.65 \times 10^{-7}=768\ \mathrm{s}=12.8\ \mathrm{min}}\]
5-75We currently can successfully perform a carburizing heat treatment at 1200\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C in 1 h. In an effort to reduce the cost of the brick lining in our furnace, we propose to reduce the carburizing temperature to 950\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C. What time will be required to give us a similar carburizing treatment? Solution: \[D_{1200}=0.23\mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1473)]=3.019\times 10^{-6} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[D_{950}=0.23\mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1223)]=3.034\times 10^{-7} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\]\[t_{1200}=1\ \mathrm{h}\] \[t_{950}=D_{1200}\ t_{1200}/D_{950}=\frac{(3.019\times 10^{-6})(1)}{3.034 \times 10^{-7}}=9.95\ \mathrm{h}\]
* During freezing of a Cu-Zn alloy, we find that the composition is nonuniform. By heating the alloy to 600oC for 3 hours, diffusion of zinc helps to make the composition more uniform. What temperature would be required if we wished to perform this _homogenization_ treatment in 30 minutes? Solution: \[D_{600}=0.78\ \mathrm{exp}[-43,900/(1.987)(873)]=7.9636\times 10^{-12} \qquad t_{600}=3\ \mathrm{h}\] \[t_{x}=0.5\ \mathrm{h}\] \[D_{x}=D_{600}\ t_{600}/t_{x}=(7.9636\times 10^{-12})(3)/0.5\] \[D_{x}=4.778\times 10^{-11}=\ 0.78\ \mathrm{exp}[-43,900/1.9877]\] \[\mathrm{ln}\ (6.1258\times 10^{-11})=-23.516=-43,900/1.987\ T\] \[T=940\ \mathrm{K}=667^{o}\mathrm{C}\]
* A ceramic part made of MgO is sintered successfully at 1700oC in 90 minutes. To minimize thermal stresses during the process, we plan to reduce the temperature to 1500oC. Which will limit the rate at which sintering can be done: diffusion of magnesium ions or diffusion of oxygen ions? What time will be required at the lower temperature? Solution: Diffusion of oxygen is the slower of the two, due to the larger ionic radius of the oxygen. \[D_{1700}=0.000043\ \mathrm{exp}[-82,100/(1.987)(1973)]=3.455\times 10^{-14}\ \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[D_{1500}=0.000043\ \mathrm{exp}[-82,100/(1.987)(1773)]=3.255\times 10^{-15} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t_{1500}=D_{1700}\ t_{1700}/D_{1500}=\frac{(3.455\times 10^{-14})(9 0)}{3.255\times 10^{-15}}=955\ \mathrm{min}=15.9\ \mathrm{h}\]
* A Cu-Zn alloy has an initial grain diameter of 0.01 mm. The alloy is then heated to various temperatures, permitting grain growth to occur. The times required for the grains to grow to a diameter of 0.30 mm are Solution: Temperature (oC) Time (min) 500 80,000 600 700 120 800 10 850 3  Determine the activation energy for grain growth. Does this correlate with the diffusion of zinc in copper? (Hint: Note that rate is the reciprocal of time.) Solution: Temperature (oC) Time (min) 500 773 0.00129 80,000 1.25 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-5}\) 600 873 0.00115 3,000 3.33 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) 700 973 0.001028 120 8.33 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-3}\) 800 1073 0.000932 10 0.100 850 1123 0.000890 3 0.333From the graph, we find that \(Q=51\),286 cal/mol, which does correlate with the activation energy for diffusion of zinc in copper.

question: A 0.15% C steel is to be carburized at \(1100^{\circ}\) C, giving 0.35% C at a distance of 1 mm beneath the surface. If the surface composition is maintained at 0.90% C, what time is required?
context:
**5-61**: Compare the diffusion coefficients of carbon in BCC and FCC iron at the allotropic transformation temperature of 912\({}^{\rm o}{\rm C}\) and explain the difference.
Solution: \[{D_{\rm BCC}}=0.011\ {\rm exp}[-20,900/(1.987)(1185)]=1.51\times 1 0^{-6}\ {\rm cm^{2}/s}\]
\[{D_{\rm FCC}}=0.23\ {\rm exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1185)]=1.92\times 10^{-7}\ {\rm cm^{2}/s}\]
[MISSING_PAGE_FAIL:50]
FCC: \(\frac{1.2-\ c_{x}}{1.2-0.05}\ =\mbox{erf}[0.05/\left(2\sqrt{(1.97\times 10^{-7})(86,4 00)}\ \right)]\ =\mbox{erf}[0.192]=0.2139\)
\[c_{x}=0.95\%\ \mbox{C}\]
Faster diffusion occurs in the looser packed BCC structure, leading to the higher carbon content at point "x".
* What temperature is required to obtain 0.50% C at a distance of 0.5 mm beneath the surface of a 0.20% C steel in 2 h. when 1.10% C is present at the surface? Assume that the iron is FCC. Solution: \(\frac{1.1-0.5}{1.1-0.2}=0.667=\mbox{erf}[0.05/2\sqrt{Dt}\ \ ]\) \(0.05/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.685\) or \(\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.0365\) or \(\ Dt=0.00133\)
* \(t=(2\ \mbox{h})(3600\ \mbox{s/h})=7200\ \mbox{s}\) \(D=0.00133/7200=1.85\times 10^{-7}=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/1.9877]\) \(\exp(-16,558/T)=8.043\times 10^{-7}\) \(T=1180\mbox{K}=907^{\circ}\mbox{C}\)
* A 0.15% C steel is to be carburized at \(1100^{\circ}\) C, giving 0.35% C at a distance of 1 mm beneath the surface. If the surface composition is maintained at 0.90% C, what time is required? Solution: \(\frac{0.9-0.35}{0.9-0.15}=0.733=\mbox{erf}[0.1/2\sqrt{Dt}\ \ ]\) \(0.1/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.786\) or \(\ Dt=0.00405\) \(D=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1373)]=1.332\times 10^{-6}\ \mbox{cm}^{2}/\mbox{s}\) \(t=0.00405/1.332\times 10^{-6}=3040\ \mbox{s}=51\ \mbox{min}\)
* A 0.02% C steel is to be carburized at \(1200^{\circ}\)C in 4 h, with a point 0.6 mm beneath the surface reaching 0.45% C. Calculate the carbon content required at the surface of the steel. Solution: \(\frac{c_{x}-0.45}{c_{s}-0.02}=\mbox{erf}[0.06/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\) \(D=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1473)]=3.019\times 10^{-6}\ \mbox{cm}^{2}/\mbox{s}\) \(t=(4\ \mbox{h})(3600)=14,400\ \mbox{s}\) \(\sqrt{Dt}\ =\sqrt{(3.019\times 10^{-6})(14,400)}\ =\ 0.2085\) \(\mbox{erf}[0.06/(2)(0.2085)]=\mbox{erf}[0.144]=0.161\) \(\frac{c_{s}-0.45}{c_{s}-0.02}=0.161\ \ \mbox{or}\ \ c_{s}=0.53\%\ \mbox{C}\)
* A 1.2% C tool steel held at \(1150^{\circ}\)C is exposed to oxygen for 48 h. The carbon content at the steel surface is zero. To what depth will the steel be decarburized to less than 0.20% C? Solution: \(\frac{0-0.2}{0-1.2}\ =0.1667\ \ \therefore\ \ x^{\prime}/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.149\)\[D=0.23\ \mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1423)]=2.034\times 10^{-6}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t=(48\ \mathrm{h})(3600\ \mathrm{s/h})=17.28\ \times 10^{4}\ \mathrm{s}\] \[\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.5929\] Then from above, \(x=(0.149)(2)(0.5929)=0.177\ \mathrm{cm}\)
5-72A 0.80% C steel must operate at 950\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C in an oxidizing environment, where the carbon content at the steel surface is zero. Only the outermost 0.02 cm of the steel part can fall below 0.75% C. What is the maximum time that the steel part can operate? Solution: \[\frac{0-0.75}{0-0.8}=0.9375=\mathrm{erf}[x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \ \ \ \cdot\ \ x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =1.384\] \[0.02/\ 2\sqrt{Dt}\ =1.384\ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ \ \sqrt{Dt}\ =0.007226\ \ \ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ \ \ \ Dt=5.22\times 10^{-5}\] \[D=0.23\ \mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1223)]=3.03\times 10^{-7}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t=5.22\times 10^{-5}\ /\ 3.03\times 10^{-7}=172\ \mathrm{s}=2.9\ \mathrm{min}\]

* What temperature is required to obtain 0.50% C at a distance of 0.5 mm beneath the surface of a 0.20% C steel in 2 h. when 1.10% C is present at the surface? Assume that the iron is FCC. Solution: \(\frac{1.1-0.5}{1.1-0.2}=0.667=\mbox{erf}[0.05/2\sqrt{Dt}\ \ ]\) \(0.05/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.685\) or \(\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.0365\) or \(\ Dt=0.00133\)
* \(t=(2\ \mbox{h})(3600\ \mbox{s/h})=7200\ \mbox{s}\) \(D=0.00133/7200=1.85\times 10^{-7}=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/1.9877]\) \(\exp(-16,558/T)=8.043\times 10^{-7}\) \(T=1180\mbox{K}=907^{\circ}\mbox{C}\)
* A 0.15% C steel is to be carburized at \(1100^{\circ}\) C, giving 0.35% C at a distance of 1 mm beneath the surface. If the surface composition is maintained at 0.90% C, what time is required? Solution: \(\frac{0.9-0.35}{0.9-0.15}=0.733=\mbox{erf}[0.1/2\sqrt{Dt}\ \ ]\) \(0.1/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.786\) or \(\ Dt=0.00405\) \(D=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1373)]=1.332\times 10^{-6}\ \mbox{cm}^{2}/\mbox{s}\) \(t=0.00405/1.332\times 10^{-6}=3040\ \mbox{s}=51\ \mbox{min}\)
* A 0.02% C steel is to be carburized at \(1200^{\circ}\)C in 4 h, with a point 0.6 mm beneath the surface reaching 0.45% C. Calculate the carbon content required at the surface of the steel. Solution: \(\frac{c_{x}-0.45}{c_{s}-0.02}=\mbox{erf}[0.06/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\) \(D=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1473)]=3.019\times 10^{-6}\ \mbox{cm}^{2}/\mbox{s}\) \(t=(4\ \mbox{h})(3600)=14,400\ \mbox{s}\) \(\sqrt{Dt}\ =\sqrt{(3.019\times 10^{-6})(14,400)}\ =\ 0.2085\) \(\mbox{erf}[0.06/(2)(0.2085)]=\mbox{erf}[0.144]=0.161\) \(\frac{c_{s}-0.45}{c_{s}-0.02}=0.161\ \ \mbox{or}\ \ c_{s}=0.53\%\ \mbox{C}\)
* A 1.2% C tool steel held at \(1150^{\circ}\)C is exposed to oxygen for 48 h. The carbon content at the steel surface is zero. To what depth will the steel be decarburized to less than 0.20% C? Solution: \(\frac{0-0.2}{0-1.2}\ =0.1667\ \ \therefore\ \ x^{\prime}/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.149\)\[D=0.23\ \mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1423)]=2.034\times 10^{-6}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t=(48\ \mathrm{h})(3600\ \mathrm{s/h})=17.28\ \times 10^{4}\ \mathrm{s}\] \[\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.5929\] Then from above, \(x=(0.149)(2)(0.5929)=0.177\ \mathrm{cm}\)
5-72A 0.80% C steel must operate at 950\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C in an oxidizing environment, where the carbon content at the steel surface is zero. Only the outermost 0.02 cm of the steel part can fall below 0.75% C. What is the maximum time that the steel part can operate? Solution: \[\frac{0-0.75}{0-0.8}=0.9375=\mathrm{erf}[x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \ \ \ \cdot\ \ x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =1.384\] \[0.02/\ 2\sqrt{Dt}\ =1.384\ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ \ \sqrt{Dt}\ =0.007226\ \ \ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ \ \ \ Dt=5.22\times 10^{-5}\] \[D=0.23\ \mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1223)]=3.03\times 10^{-7}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t=5.22\times 10^{-5}\ /\ 3.03\times 10^{-7}=172\ \mathrm{s}=2.9\ \mathrm{min}\]
5-73A BCC steel containing 0.001% N is nitridated at 550\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C for 5 h. If the nitrogen content at the steel surface is 0.08%, determine the nitrogen content at 0.25 mm from the surface. Solution: \[\frac{0.08-c_{s}}{0.08-0.001}=\mathrm{erf}[0.025/\ 2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathrm{t=(5\ h)(3600\ \mathrm{s/h})=1.8\times 10^{4}\ \mathrm{s}}\] \[D=0.0047\ \mathrm{exp}[-18,300/(1.987)(823)]\] \[=6.488\times 10\mathrm{-8\ cm^{2}/s}\] \[\sqrt{Dt}=0.0342\] \[\mathrm{erf}[0.025/(2)(0.0342)]=\mathrm{erf}(0.3655)=0.394\] \[\frac{0.08-c_{s}}{0.079}=0.394\ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ c_{s}\ =0.049\%\ \mathrm{N}\]
5-74What time is required to nitride a 0.002% N steel to obtain 0.12% N at a distance of 0.002 in. beneath the surface at 625\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C? The nitrogen content at the surface is 0.15%. Solution: \[\frac{0.15-0.12}{0.15-0.002}=0.2027=\mathrm{erf}[x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \cdot\ \ x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.2256\] \[D=0.0047\ \mathrm{exp}[-18,300/(1.987)(898)]=1.65\times 10^{-7} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[x=0.002\ \mathrm{in.}=0.00508\ \mathrm{cm}\] \[\frac{0.00508}{2\sqrt{(1.65\times 10^{-7})t}}=0.2256\] \[Dt=1.267\times 10^{-4}\ \mathrm{or}\ \mathrm{t=1.267\times 10^{-4}/1.65 \times 10^{-7}=768\ \mathrm{s}=12.8\ \mathrm{min}}\]
5-75We currently can successfully perform a carburizing heat treatment at 1200\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C in 1 h. In an effort to reduce the cost of the brick lining in our furnace, we propose to reduce the carburizing temperature to 950\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C. What time will be required to give us a similar carburizing treatment? Solution: \[D_{1200}=0.23\mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1473)]=3.019\times 10^{-6} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[D_{950}=0.23\mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1223)]=3.034\times 10^{-7} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\]\[t_{1200}=1\ \mathrm{h}\] \[t_{950}=D_{1200}\ t_{1200}/D_{950}=\frac{(3.019\times 10^{-6})(1)}{3.034 \times 10^{-7}}=9.95\ \mathrm{h}\]
* During freezing of a Cu-Zn alloy, we find that the composition is nonuniform. By heating the alloy to 600oC for 3 hours, diffusion of zinc helps to make the composition more uniform. What temperature would be required if we wished to perform this _homogenization_ treatment in 30 minutes? Solution: \[D_{600}=0.78\ \mathrm{exp}[-43,900/(1.987)(873)]=7.9636\times 10^{-12} \qquad t_{600}=3\ \mathrm{h}\] \[t_{x}=0.5\ \mathrm{h}\] \[D_{x}=D_{600}\ t_{600}/t_{x}=(7.9636\times 10^{-12})(3)/0.5\] \[D_{x}=4.778\times 10^{-11}=\ 0.78\ \mathrm{exp}[-43,900/1.9877]\] \[\mathrm{ln}\ (6.1258\times 10^{-11})=-23.516=-43,900/1.987\ T\] \[T=940\ \mathrm{K}=667^{o}\mathrm{C}\]
* A ceramic part made of MgO is sintered successfully at 1700oC in 90 minutes. To minimize thermal stresses during the process, we plan to reduce the temperature to 1500oC. Which will limit the rate at which sintering can be done: diffusion of magnesium ions or diffusion of oxygen ions? What time will be required at the lower temperature? Solution: Diffusion of oxygen is the slower of the two, due to the larger ionic radius of the oxygen. \[D_{1700}=0.000043\ \mathrm{exp}[-82,100/(1.987)(1973)]=3.455\times 10^{-14}\ \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[D_{1500}=0.000043\ \mathrm{exp}[-82,100/(1.987)(1773)]=3.255\times 10^{-15} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t_{1500}=D_{1700}\ t_{1700}/D_{1500}=\frac{(3.455\times 10^{-14})(9 0)}{3.255\times 10^{-15}}=955\ \mathrm{min}=15.9\ \mathrm{h}\]
* A Cu-Zn alloy has an initial grain diameter of 0.01 mm. The alloy is then heated to various temperatures, permitting grain growth to occur. The times required for the grains to grow to a diameter of 0.30 mm are Solution: Temperature (oC) Time (min) 500 80,000 600 700 120 800 10 850 3  Determine the activation energy for grain growth. Does this correlate with the diffusion of zinc in copper? (Hint: Note that rate is the reciprocal of time.) Solution: Temperature (oC) Time (min) 500 773 0.00129 80,000 1.25 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-5}\) 600 873 0.00115 3,000 3.33 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) 700 973 0.001028 120 8.33 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-3}\) 800 1073 0.000932 10 0.100 850 1123 0.000890 3 0.333From the graph, we find that \(Q=51\),286 cal/mol, which does correlate with the activation energy for diffusion of zinc in copper.

Solution: \[\frac{0.15-0.12}{0.15-0.002}=0.2027=\mathrm{erf}[x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ ]\ \ \ \cdot\ \ x/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.2256\] \[D=0.0047\ \mathrm{exp}[-18,300/(1.987)(898)]=1.65\times 10^{-7} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[x=0.002\ \mathrm{in.}=0.00508\ \mathrm{cm}\] \[\frac{0.00508}{2\sqrt{(1.65\times 10^{-7})t}}=0.2256\] \[Dt=1.267\times 10^{-4}\ \mathrm{or}\ \mathrm{t=1.267\times 10^{-4}/1.65 \times 10^{-7}=768\ \mathrm{s}=12.8\ \mathrm{min}}\]
5-75We currently can successfully perform a carburizing heat treatment at 1200\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C in 1 h. In an effort to reduce the cost of the brick lining in our furnace, we propose to reduce the carburizing temperature to 950\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C. What time will be required to give us a similar carburizing treatment? Solution: \[D_{1200}=0.23\mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1473)]=3.019\times 10^{-6} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[D_{950}=0.23\mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1223)]=3.034\times 10^{-7} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\]\[t_{1200}=1\ \mathrm{h}\] \[t_{950}=D_{1200}\ t_{1200}/D_{950}=\frac{(3.019\times 10^{-6})(1)}{3.034 \times 10^{-7}}=9.95\ \mathrm{h}\]
* During freezing of a Cu-Zn alloy, we find that the composition is nonuniform. By heating the alloy to 600oC for 3 hours, diffusion of zinc helps to make the composition more uniform. What temperature would be required if we wished to perform this _homogenization_ treatment in 30 minutes? Solution: \[D_{600}=0.78\ \mathrm{exp}[-43,900/(1.987)(873)]=7.9636\times 10^{-12} \qquad t_{600}=3\ \mathrm{h}\] \[t_{x}=0.5\ \mathrm{h}\] \[D_{x}=D_{600}\ t_{600}/t_{x}=(7.9636\times 10^{-12})(3)/0.5\] \[D_{x}=4.778\times 10^{-11}=\ 0.78\ \mathrm{exp}[-43,900/1.9877]\] \[\mathrm{ln}\ (6.1258\times 10^{-11})=-23.516=-43,900/1.987\ T\] \[T=940\ \mathrm{K}=667^{o}\mathrm{C}\]
* A ceramic part made of MgO is sintered successfully at 1700oC in 90 minutes. To minimize thermal stresses during the process, we plan to reduce the temperature to 1500oC. Which will limit the rate at which sintering can be done: diffusion of magnesium ions or diffusion of oxygen ions? What time will be required at the lower temperature? Solution: Diffusion of oxygen is the slower of the two, due to the larger ionic radius of the oxygen. \[D_{1700}=0.000043\ \mathrm{exp}[-82,100/(1.987)(1973)]=3.455\times 10^{-14}\ \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[D_{1500}=0.000043\ \mathrm{exp}[-82,100/(1.987)(1773)]=3.255\times 10^{-15} \ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t_{1500}=D_{1700}\ t_{1700}/D_{1500}=\frac{(3.455\times 10^{-14})(9 0)}{3.255\times 10^{-15}}=955\ \mathrm{min}=15.9\ \mathrm{h}\]
* A Cu-Zn alloy has an initial grain diameter of 0.01 mm. The alloy is then heated to various temperatures, permitting grain growth to occur. The times required for the grains to grow to a diameter of 0.30 mm are Solution: Temperature (oC) Time (min) 500 80,000 600 700 120 800 10 850 3  Determine the activation energy for grain growth. Does this correlate with the diffusion of zinc in copper? (Hint: Note that rate is the reciprocal of time.) Solution: Temperature (oC) Time (min) 500 773 0.00129 80,000 1.25 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-5}\) 600 873 0.00115 3,000 3.33 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) 700 973 0.001028 120 8.33 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-3}\) 800 1073 0.000932 10 0.100 850 1123 0.000890 3 0.333From the graph, we find that \(Q=51\),286 cal/mol, which does correlate with the activation energy for diffusion of zinc in copper.

* A 0.15% C steel is to be carburized at \(1100^{\circ}\) C, giving 0.35% C at a distance of 1 mm beneath the surface. If the surface composition is maintained at 0.90% C, what time is required? Solution: \(\frac{0.9-0.35}{0.9-0.15}=0.733=\mbox{erf}[0.1/2\sqrt{Dt}\ \ ]\) \(0.1/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.786\) or \(\ Dt=0.00405\) \(D=0.23\ \mbox{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1373)]=1.332\times 10^{-6}\ \mbox{cm}^{2}/\mbox{s}\) \(t=0.00405/1.332\times 10^{-6}=3040\ \mbox{s}=51\ \mbox{min}\)
* A 0.02% C steel is to be carburized at \(1200^{\circ}\)C in 4 h, with a point 0.6 mm beneath the surface reaching 0.45% C. Calculate the carbon content required at the surface of the steel. * A 1.2% C tool steel held at \(1150^{\circ}\)C is exposed to oxygen for 48 h. The carbon content at the steel surface is zero. To what depth will the steel be decarburized to less than 0.20% C? Solution: \(\frac{0-0.2}{0-1.2}\ =0.1667\ \ \therefore\ \ x^{\prime}/2\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.149\)\[D=0.23\ \mathrm{exp}[-32,900/(1.987)(1423)]=2.034\times 10^{-6}\ \mathrm{cm^{2}/s}\] \[t=(48\ \mathrm{h})(3600\ \mathrm{s/h})=17.28\ \times 10^{4}\ \mathrm{s}\] \[\sqrt{Dt}\ =0.5929\] Then from above, \(x=(0.149)(2)(0.5929)=0.177\ \mathrm{cm}\)
5-72A 0.80% C steel must operate at 950\({}^{\mathrm{o}}\)C in an oxidizing environment, where the carbon content at the steel surface is zero. Only the outermost 0.02 cm of the steel part can fall below 0.75% C. What is the maximum time that the steel part can operate? question: What is the activation energy for the diffusion bonding process?
context:
**5-91**: A sheet of gold is diffusion-bonded to a sheet of silver in 1 h at 700\({}^{\rm o}\)C. At 500\({}^{\rm o}\)C, 440 h are required to obtain the same degree of bonding, and at 300\({}^{\rm o}\)C, bonding requires 1530 years. What is the activation energy for the diffusion bonding process? Does it appear that diffusion of gold or diffusion of silver controls the bonding rate? (Hint - note that rate is the reciprocal of time.)
\begin{tabular}{l c c c c} Solution: & Temperature & 1/T & Time & Rate \\  & (\({}^{\rm o}\)C) & (K) & (K\({}^{-1}\)) & (s) & (sec\({}^{-1}\)) \\ \hline
700 & 973 & 0.001007 & 3600 & \(0.278\times 10^{-3}\) \\
500 & 773 & 0.001294 & \(1.584\times 10^{6}\) & \(0.631\times 10^{-6}\) \\

The activation energy for the diffusion of gold in silver is 45,500 cal/mole; thus the diffusion of gold appears to control the bonding rate.

question: A 850-lb force is applied to a 0.15-in. diameter nickel wire having a yield strength of 45,000 psi and a tensile strength of 55,000 psi. Determine (a) whether the wire will plastically deform and (b) whether the wire will experience necking.
answer: (a) The wire will plastically deform. (b) No necking will occur.
context: * 6-24 A 850-lb force is applied to a 0.15-in. diameter nickel wire having a yield strength of 45,000 psi and a tensile strength of 55,000 psi. Determine (a) whether the wire will plastically deform and (b) whether the wire will experience necking. Solution: (a) First determine the stress acting on the wire: \(\sigma\) = _F_/_A_ = 850 lb / (\(\pi\)/4)(0.15 in.)\({}^{2}\) = 48,100 psi Because \(\sigma\) is greater than the yield strength of 45,000 psi, the wire will plastically deform. (b) Because \(\sigma\) is less than the tensile strength of 55,000 psi, no necking will occur.

question: A force of 100,000 N is applied to a 10 mm \(\times\) 20 mm iron bar having a yield strength of 400 MPa and a tensile strength of 480 MPa. Determine (a) whether the bar will plastically deform and (b) whether the bar will experience necking.
answer: (a) Yes, the bar will plastically deform. (b) Yes, the bar will experience necking.
context: * 6-25 A force of 100,000 N is applied to a 10 mm \(\times\) 20 mm iron bar having a yield strength of 400 MPa and a tensile strength of 480 MPa. Determine (a) whether the bar will plastically deform and (b) whether the bar will experience necking. Solution: (a) First determine the stress acting on the wire: \(\sigma\) = _F_/_A_ = 100,000 N / (10 mm)(20 mm) = 500 N/mm\({}^{2}\) = 500 MPa Because \(\sigma\) is greater than the yield strength of 400 MPa, the wire will plastically deform. (b) Because \(\sigma\) is greater than the tensile strength of 480 MPa, the wire will also neck.

question: Calculate the maximum force that a 0.2-in. diameter rod of Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\), having a yield strength of 35,000 psi, can withstand with no plastic deformation.
context:
* 6-25(c) Calculate the maximum force that a 0.2-in. diameter rod of Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\), having a yield strength of 35,000 psi, can withstand with no plastic deformation. Express your answer in pounds and newtons. Solution: \(F\) = \(\sigma\)_A_ = (35,000 psi)(\(\pi\)/4)(0.2 in.)\({}^{2}\) = 1100 lb \(F\) = (1100 lb)(4.448 N/lb) = 4891 N - 10 cm)/10 cm = 0.0045 cm/cm The stress \(\sigma\) is \(\sigma\) = 20,000 N / (10 mm)(10 mm) = 200 N/mm\({}^{2}\) = 200 MPa \(E=\sigma/\varepsilon\) = 200 MPa / 0.0045 cm/cm = 44,444 MPa = 44.4 GPa \(E=\) (44,444 MPa)(145 psi/MPa) = \(6.44\times 10^{6}\) psi

question: An aluminum plate 0.5 cm thick is to withstand a force of 50,000 N with no permanent deformation. If the aluminum has a yield strength of 125 MPa, what is the minimum width of the plate?
context:
* 6-28 An aluminum plate 0.5 cm thick is to withstand a force of 50,000 N with no permanent deformation. If the aluminum has a yield strength of 125 MPa, what is the minimum width of the plate? Solution: The area is \(A=F/\sigma\) = 50,000 N / 125 N/mm\({}^{2}\) = 400 mm\({}^{2}\) The minimum width is \(w=A/t\) = (400 mm\({}^{2}\))(0.1 cm/mm)\({}^{2}\) / 0.5 cm = 8 cm
* \(d_{\rm o}\)) / \(d_{\rm o}\) = 0.00235 in./in. \(2-d_{\rm o}\) = 0.00235 \(d_{\rm o}\) = 2 / 1.00235 = 1.995 in. The opening in the die must be smaller than the final diameter.

* 50 ft) / 50 ft = 0.0010865 ft/ft \(\ell_{\rm f}\) = 50.0543 ft

6-41A three-point bend test is performed on a block of ZrO2 that is 8 in. long, 0.50 in. wide, and 0.25 in. thick and is resting on two supports 4 in. apart. When a force of 400 lb is applied, the specimen deflects 0.037 in. and breaks. Calculate (a) the flexural strength and (b) the flexural modulus, assuming that no plastic deformation occurs. Solution: (a) flexural strength = 3FL/2wh^2 = (3)(400 lb)(4 in.) (2)(0.5 in.)(0.25 in.)^2 = 76,800 psi (b) flexural modulus = \(FL^{3}/4wh^3\delta\)
\[=\frac{(400\text{ lb})(4\text{ in.})^{3}}{(4)(0.5\text{ in.})(0.25\text{ in.})^{3}(0.037\text{ in.})}\]
\[=22.14\times 10^{6}\text{ psi}\]
6-42A three-point bend test is performed on a block of silicon carbide that is 10 cm long, 1.5 cm wide, and 0.6 cm thick and is resting on two supports 7.5 cm apart. The sample breaks when a deflection of 0.09 mm is recorded. Calculate (a) the force that caused the fracture and (b) the flexural strength. The flexural modulus for silicon carbide is 480 GPa. Assume that no plastic deformation occurs. Solution: (a) The force \(F\) required to produce a deflection of 0.09 mm is
\[F=(\text{flexural modulus})(4wh^{3}\delta)/L^{3}\]
\[F=(480,000\text{ MPa})(4)(15\text{ mm})(6\text{ mm})^{3}(0.09\text{ mm})/(75\text{ mm})^{3}\]
\[F=1327\text{ N}\]* (b) flexural strength = 3_FL_/2_wh_2 = (3)(1327 N)(75 mm)/(2)(15 mm)(6 mm)2 = 276 MPa
* (a)A thermosetting polymer containing glass beads is required to deflect 0.5 mm when a force of 500 N is applied. The polymer part is 2 cm wide, 0.5 cm thick, and 10 cm long. If the flexural modulus is 6.9 GPa, determine the minimum distance between the supports. Will the polymer fracture if its flexural strength is 85 MPa? Assume that no plastic deformation occurs. Solution: The minimum distance \(L\) between the supports can be calculated from the flexural modulus. \(L^{3}\) = 4_wh_3_( flexural modulus)/_F_ \(L^{3}\) = (4)(20 mm)(5 mm)(0.5 mm)(6.9 GPa)(1000 MPa/GPa) / 500 N \(L^{3}\) = 69,000 mm\({}^{3}\) or \(L\) = 41 mm The stress acting on the bar when a deflection of 0.5 mm is obtained is \(\sigma=3FL/2_{0}\)_wh_2 = (3)(500 N)(41 mm) / (2)(20 mm)(5 mm)2 = 61.5 MPa The applied stress is less than the flexural strength of 85 MPa; the polymer is not expected to fracture.
* (b)The flexural modulus of alumina is \(45\times 10^{6}\) psi and its flexural strength is 46,000 psi. A bar of alumina 0.3 in. thick, 1.0 in. wide, and 10 in. long is placed on supports 7 in. apart. Determine the amount of deflection at the moment the bar breaks, assuming that no plastic deformation occurs. Solution: The force required to break the bar is \(F\) = 2_wh_2(flexural strength)/3\(L\) \(F\) = (2)(1 in.)(0.3 in.)2(46,000 psi / (3)(7 in.) = 394 lb The deflection just prior to fracture is \(\delta\) = \(FL^{3}\)/4wh3(flexural modulus) \(\delta\) = (394 lb)(7 in.)3(4)(1 in.)(0.3 in.)3(45 \(\times\) 10^{6} psi) = 0.0278 in.
* (c)A Brinell hardness measurement, using a 10-mm-diameter indenter and a 500 kg load, produces an indentation of 4.5 mm on an aluminum plate. Determine the Brinell hardness number HB of the metal. Solution: \(HB\) = \(\frac{500\;\mathrm{kg}}{(\pi\;/\;2)(10\;\mathrm{mm})[10-\sqrt{10^{2}\;-\;4.5^{2} }\;]}\) = 29.8
* (c)When a 3000 kg load is applied to a 10-mm-diameter ball in a Brinell test of a steel, an indentation of 3.1 mm is produced. Estimate the tensile strength of the steel. Solution: \(HB\) = \(\frac{3000\;\mathrm{kg}}{(\pi\;/\;2)(10\;\mathrm{mm})[10-\sqrt{10^{2}\;-\;3.1^{2 }}\;]}\) = 388 Tensile strength = 500 HB = (500)(388) = 194,000 psi

* 6-33 The following data were collected from a standard 0.505-in.-diameter test specimen of a copper alloy (initial length (\(\ell_{\rm o}\)) = 2.0 in.): Solution: \(\sigma\) = \(F\) / (\(\pi/4\))(0.505)\({}^{2}\) = \(F/0.2\) \(\varepsilon\) = (\(\ell-2\)) / 2After fracture, the gage length is 3.014 in. and the diameter is 0.374 in. Plot the data and calculate (a) the 0.2% offset yield strength, (b) the tensile strength, (c) the modulus of elasticity, (d) the %Elongation, (e) the %Reduction in area, (f) the engineering stress at fracture, (g) the true stress at fracture, and (h) the modulus of resilience.
(a) 0.2% offset yield strength = 45,000 psi
(b) tensile strength = 62,000 psi
(c) \(E\) = (30,000 - 0) / (0.001665 - 0) = 18 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi
(d) %Elongation = \(\frac{(3.014-2)}{2}\times 100\) = 50.7%
(e) %Reduction in area = \(\frac{(\pi/4)(0.505)^{2}-(\pi/4)(0.374)^{2}}{(\pi/4)(0.505)^{2}}\times 100 = 45.2\%\)
(f) engineering stress at fracture = 57,000 psi
(g) true stress at fracture = 11,400 lb / (\(\pi/4\))(0.374)\({}^{2}\) = 103,770 psi
(h) From the graph, yielding begins at about 37,500 psi. Thus:
\(\nu_{2}\)(yield strength)(strain at yield) = \(\nu_{2}\)(37,500)(0.002085) = 39.1 psi * 6-34 The following data were collected from a 0.4-in. diameter test specimen of polyvinyl chloride (\(\ell_{o}=2.0\) in.): Solution: \(\sigma=F/(\pi/4)(0.4)^{2}=F/0.1257\) \(\varepsilon=(\ell-2)\) / 2
\begin{tabular}{c c c c} \hline Load & Gage Length & Stress & Strain \\ (lb) & (in.) & (psi) & (in./in.) \\ \hline
0 & 2.00000 & 0 & 0.0 \\
300 & 2.00746 & 2,387 & 0.00373 \\
600 & 2.01496 & 4,773 & 0.00748 \\
900 & 2.02374 & 7,160 & 0.01187 \\
1200 & 2.032 & 9,547 & 0.016 \\
1500 & 2.046 & 11,933 & 0.023 \\
1660 & 2.070 (max load) & 13,206 & 0.035 \\
1600 & 2.094 & 12,729 & 0.047 \\
1420 & 2.12 (fracture) & 11,297 & 0.06 \\ \hline \end{tabular}
After fracture, the gage length is 2.09 in. and the diameter is 0.393 in. Plot the data and calculate (a) the 0.2% offset yield strength, (b) the tensile strength, (c) the modulus of elasticity, (d) the %Elongation, (e) the %Reduction in area, (f) the engineering stress at fracture, (g) the true stress at fracture, and (h) the modulus of resilience.
(a) 0.2% offset yield strength = 11,600 psi
(b) tensile strength = 12,729 psi
(c) \(E=(7160-0)\) / \((0.01187-0)\) = 603,000 psi
(d) %Elongation = \(\frac{(2.09-2)}{2}\times 100=4.5\%\)
(e) %Reduction in area = \(\frac{(\pi/4)(0.4)^{2}-(\pi/4)(0.393)^{2}}{(\pi/4)(0.4)^{2}}\times 100=3.5\%\)
(f) engineering stress at fracture = 11,297 psi
(g) true stress at fracture = 1420 lb / \((\pi/4)(0.393)^{2}\) = 11,706 psi
(h) From the figure, yielding begins near 9550 psi. Thus:
\({}^{1}\)2(yield strength)(strain at yield) = \({}^{1}\)2(9550)(0.016) = 76.4 psi * 6.35 The following data were collected from a 12-mm-diameter test specimen of magnesium (\(\ell_{\rm o}\) = 30.00 mm): Solution: \(\sigma=F\) / (\(\pi\)/4)(12 mm)\({}^{2}=F\)/113.1 \(\varepsilon\) = (\(\ell-30\))/30 
After fracture, the gage length is 32.61 mm and the diameter is 11.74 mm. Plot the data and calculate (a) the 0.2% offset yield strength, (b) the tensile strength, (c) the modulus of elasticity, (d) the %Elongation, (e) the %Reduction in area, (f) the engineering stress at fracture, (g) the true stress at fracture, and (h) the modulus of resilience.
(a) 0.2% offset yield strength = 186 MPa
(b) tensile strength = 238.7 MPa
(c) \(E=(132.6-0)\) / (0.00296 - 0) = 44,800 MPa = 44.8 GPa
(d) %Elongation = \(\frac{(32.61-30)}{30}\times 100=8.7\%\)
(e) %Reduction in area = \(\frac{(\pi/4)(12)^{2}-(\pi/4)(11.74)^{2}}{(\pi/4)(12)^{2}}\times 100=4.3\%\)
(f) engineering stress at fracture = 221 MPa
(g) true stress at fracture = 25,000 N / (\(\pi\)/4)(11.74)\({}^{2}\) = 231 MPa(h) From the figure, yielding begins near 138 MPa psi. Thus:
\({}^{1}\!\!z\)(yield strength)(strain at yield) = \({}^{1}\!\!z\)(138)(0.00296) = 0.2 MPa
\(6\)-\(36\)The following data were collected from a 20 mm diameter test specimen of a ductile cast iron (\(\ell_{\rm o}\) = 40.00 mm):
Solution: \(\sigma=F/(\pi/4)\)(20 mm)\({}^{2}\) = \(F/314.2\)
\(\varepsilon=(\ell-40)\)/40

0 & 40.0000 & 0 & 0.0 \\
25,000 & 40.0185 & 79.6 & 0.00046 \\
50,000 & 40.0370 & 159.2 & 0.000925 \\

90,000 & 40.20 & 286.5 & 0.005 \\

After fracture, the gage length is 47.42 mm and the diameter is 18.35 mm. Plot the data and calculate (a) the 0.2% offset yield strength, (b) the tensile strength, (c) the modulus of elasticity, (d) the %Elongation, (e) the %Reduction in area, (f) the engineering stress at fracture, (g) the true stress at fracture, and (h) the modulus of resilience.
(a) 0.2% offset yield strength = 274 MPa
(b) tensile strength = 417 MPa
(c) \(E=(238.7-0)\) / \((0.001388-0)\) = 172,000 MPa = 172 GPa
(d) %Elongation = \(\frac{(47.42-40)}{40}\times 100=18.55\%\)
(e) %Reduction in area = \(\frac{(\pi/4)(20)^{2}-(\pi/4)(18.35)^{2}}{(\pi/4)(20)^{2}}\times 100=15.8\%\)
[MISSING_PAGE_FAIL:62]
The applied stress is much less than the yield strength; therefore Hooke's law can be used.
The strain is \(\varepsilon=\sigma/E=3\),979 psi / (16 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi) = 0.00024868 in./in.
\[\frac{\ell_{f}-\ell_{a}}{\ell_{a}}=\frac{\ell_{f}-12\text{ in.}}{12\text{ in.}}=0.00024868\text{ in./in.}\]
\[\ell_{f}=12.00298\text{ in.}\]
From Poisson's ratio, \(\mu=-\varepsilon_{\text{lat}}/\varepsilon_{\text{long}}=0.3\)
\[\varepsilon_{\text{lat}}=-(0.3)(0.00024868)=-0.0000746\text{ in./in.}\]
\[\frac{d_{f}-d_{a}}{d_{f}}=\frac{d_{f}-0.4\text{ in.}}{0.4}=-0.0000746\text{ in./in.}\]
\[d_{f}=0.39997\text{ in.}\]
6-40(b)When a tensile load is applied to a 1.5-cm diameter copper bar, the diameter is reduced to 1.498-cm diameter. Determine the applied load, using the data in Table 6-3.
Solution:From Table 6-3, \(\mu=-\varepsilon_{\text{lat}}/\varepsilon_{\text{long}}=0.36\)
\[\varepsilon_{\text{lat}}=\frac{1.498-1.5}{1.5}=-0.001333\]
\[\varepsilon_{\text{long}}=-\varepsilon_{\text{lat}}/\mu=-(-0.001333)/0.36=0.0037 \text{ in./in.}\]
\[\sigma=E\varepsilon=(124.8\text{ GPa})(1000\text{ MPa/GPa})(0.0037\text{ in./in.})=462\text{ MPa}\]
\[F=\sigma A=(462\text{ MPa})(\pi/4)(15\text{ mm})^{2}=81,640\text{ N}\]
6-41A three-point bend test is performed on a block of ZrO2 that is 8 in. long, 0.50 in. wide, and 0.25 in. thick and is resting on two supports 4 in. apart. When a force of 400 lb is applied, the specimen deflects 0.037 in. and breaks. Calculate (a) the flexural strength and (b) the flexural modulus, assuming that no plastic deformation occurs. Solution: (a) flexural strength = 3FL/2wh^2 = (3)(400 lb)(4 in.) (2)(0.5 in.)(0.25 in.)^2 = 76,800 psi (b) flexural modulus = \(FL^{3}/4wh^3\delta\)
\[=\frac{(400\text{ lb})(4\text{ in.})^{3}}{(4)(0.5\text{ in.})(0.25\text{ in.})^{3}(0.037\text{ in.})}\]
\[=22.14\times 10^{6}\text{ psi}\]
6-42A three-point bend test is performed on a block of silicon carbide that is 10 cm long, 1.5 cm wide, and 0.6 cm thick and is resting on two supports 7.5 cm apart. The sample breaks when a deflection of 0.09 mm is recorded. Calculate (a) the force that caused the fracture and (b) the flexural strength. The flexural modulus for silicon carbide is 480 GPa. Assume that no plastic deformation occurs. Solution: (a) The force \(F\) required to produce a deflection of 0.09 mm is
\[F=(\text{flexural modulus})(4wh^{3}\delta)/L^{3}\]
\[F=(480,000\text{ MPa})(4)(15\text{ mm})(6\text{ mm})^{3}(0.09\text{ mm})/(75\text{ mm})^{3}\]
\[F=1327\text{ N}\]* (b) flexural strength = 3_FL_/2_wh_2 = (3)(1327 N)(75 mm)/(2)(15 mm)(6 mm)2 = 276 MPa
* (a)A thermosetting polymer containing glass beads is required to deflect 0.5 mm when a force of 500 N is applied. The polymer part is 2 cm wide, 0.5 cm thick, and 10 cm long. If the flexural modulus is 6.9 GPa, determine the minimum distance between the supports. Will the polymer fracture if its flexural strength is 85 MPa? Assume that no plastic deformation occurs. Solution: The minimum distance \(L\) between the supports can be calculated from the flexural modulus. \(L^{3}\) = 4_wh_3_( flexural modulus)/_F_ \(L^{3}\) = (4)(20 mm)(5 mm)(0.5 mm)(6.9 GPa)(1000 MPa/GPa) / 500 N \(L^{3}\) = 69,000 mm\({}^{3}\) or \(L\) = 41 mm The stress acting on the bar when a deflection of 0.5 mm is obtained is \(\sigma=3FL/2_{0}\)_wh_2 = (3)(500 N)(41 mm) / (2)(20 mm)(5 mm)2 = 61.5 MPa The applied stress is less than the flexural strength of 85 MPa; the polymer is not expected to fracture.
* (b)The flexural modulus of alumina is \(45\times 10^{6}\) psi and its flexural strength is 46,000 psi. A bar of alumina 0.3 in. thick, 1.0 in. wide, and 10 in. long is placed on supports 7 in. apart. Determine the amount of deflection at the moment the bar breaks, assuming that no plastic deformation occurs. Solution: The force required to break the bar is \(F\) = 2_wh_2(flexural strength)/3\(L\) \(F\) = (2)(1 in.)(0.3 in.)2(46,000 psi / (3)(7 in.) = 394 lb The deflection just prior to fracture is \(\delta\) = \(FL^{3}\)/4wh3(flexural modulus) \(\delta\) = (394 lb)(7 in.)3(4)(1 in.)(0.3 in.)3(45 \(\times\) 10^{6} psi) = 0.0278 in.
* (c)A Brinell hardness measurement, using a 10-mm-diameter indenter and a 500 kg load, produces an indentation of 4.5 mm on an aluminum plate. Determine the Brinell hardness number HB of the metal. Solution: \(HB\) = \(\frac{500\;\mathrm{kg}}{(\pi\;/\;2)(10\;\mathrm{mm})[10-\sqrt{10^{2}\;-\;4.5^{2} }\;]}\) = 29.8
* (c)When a 3000 kg load is applied to a 10-mm-diameter ball in a Brinell test of a steel, an indentation of 3.1 mm is produced. Estimate the tensile strength of the steel. Solution: \(HB\) = \(\frac{3000\;\mathrm{kg}}{(\pi\;/\;2)(10\;\mathrm{mm})[10-\sqrt{10^{2}\;-\;3.1^{2 }}\;]}\) = 388 Tensile strength = 500 HB = (500)(388) = 194,000 psi
* (c)The data below were obtained from a series of Charpy impact tests performed on four steels, each having a different manganese content. Plot the data and determine (a) the transition temperature (defined by the mean of the absorbed energies in the ductile and brittle regions) and (b) the transition temperature (defined as the temperature that provides 50 J absorbed energy). Plot the transition temperature versus manganese content and discuss the effect of manganese on the toughness of steel. What would be the minimum manganese allowed in the steel if a part is to be used at 0\({}^{\circ}\)C?
Solution:
\begin{tabular}{c c c c c} \hline \hline Test temperature & \multicolumn{4}{c}{Impact energy (J)} \\ \({}^{\circ}\)C & 0.30\% Mn & 0.39\% Mn & 1.01\% Mn & 1.55\% Mn \\ \hline \(-\)100 & 2 & 5 & 5 & 15 \\ \(-\) 75 & 2 & 5 & 7 & 25 \\ \(-\) 50 & 2 & 12 & 20 & 45 \\ \(-\) 25 & 10 & 25 & 40 & 70 \\ \(0\) & 30 & 55 & 75 & 110 \\ \(25\) & 60 & 100 & 110 & 135 \\ \(50\) & 105 & 125 & 130 & 140 \\ \(75\) & 130 & 135 & 135 & 140 \\ \(100\) & 130 & 135 & 135 & 140 \\ \hline \end{tabular}
(a) Transition temperatures defined by the mean of the absorbed energies are:
\begin{tabular}{c c c} \(0.30\%\) Mn: mean energy = \(2+(130+2)\)/2 = 68 J; & \(T=27^{\circ}\)C \\ \(0.39\%\) Mn: mean energy = \(5+(135+5)\)/2 = 75 J; & \(T=10^{\circ}\)C \\ \(1.01\%\) Mn: mean energy = \(5+(135+5)\)/2 = 75 J; & \(T=0^{\circ}\)C \\ \(1.55\%\) Mn: mean energy = \(15+(140+15)\)/2 = 92.5 J; \(T=-12^{\circ}\)C \\ \((b)\) Transition temperatures defined by 50 J are:
\begin{tabular}{c c c} \(0.30\%\) Mn: & \(T=15^{\circ}\)C \\ \(0.39\%\) Mn: & \(T=-5^{\circ}\)C \\ \(1.01\%\) Mn: & \(T=-15^{\circ}\)C \\ \(1.55\%\) Mn: & \(T=-45^{\circ}\)C \\ \hline \end{tabular}
