* 16--27 A polyester matrix with a tensile strength of 13,000 psi is reinforced with Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) fibers. What vol% fibers must be added to insure that the fibers carry 75% of the applied load? Solution: The tensile strength of the fibers is 300,000 psi and that of the polyester is 13,000 psi. From Example 16--8, and assuming a total area of one cm\({}^{2}\): \[\begin{array}{l}f=\frac{\sigma_{f}A_{f}}{\sigma_{f}A_{f}\,+\,\sigma_{m}A_{m }}=\,0.75\\ \frac{300,000A_{f}}{300,000A_{f}\,+\,13,000(1\,-\,A_{f})}=\,0.75\quad\mathrm{ or}\quad A_{f}=\,0.115\end{array}\] Assuming that the area and volume fractions are the same, the volume fraction of fibers is \(f_{\mathrm{alumina}}=0.115\)An epoxy matrix is reinforced with 40 vol% E-glass fibers to produce a 2-cm diameter composite that is to withstand a load of 25,000 N. Calculate the stress acting on each fiber. Solution: We can assume that the strains in the composite, matrix, and fibers are equal. Thus:
\[\epsilon_{c}=\epsilon_{m}=\epsilon_{f}=\sigma_{m}/E_{m}=\sigma_{f}/E_{f}\]
The modulus for the E-glass is 10.5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi and that for the epoxy is 0.4 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi. Therefore the ratio of the stresses is:
\[\sigma_{f}/\sigma_{m}=E_{f}/E_{m}=10.5\ \times\ 10^{6}/0.4\ \times\ 10^{6}=26.25\]
The fraction of the force carried by the fibers (as described in Example 16-8) is (assuming that area and volume fractions are equal):
\[f = \frac{\sigma_{f}A_{f}}{\sigma_{f}A_{f}+\sigma_{m}A_{m}}=\frac{A_{ f}}{A_{f}+(\sigma_{m}/\sigma_{f})A_{m}}\] \[= \frac{0.4}{0.4\ +\ (1/26.25)(0.6)}=\ 0.9459\]
Since the total force is 25,000 N, the force carried by the fibers is:
\[F_{f}=(0.9459)(25,000\ {\rm N})=\ 23,650\ {\rm N}\]
The cross-sectional area of the fibers is:
\[A_{f}=(f_{f})(\pi/4)d^{2}=(0.4)(\pi/4)(20\ {\rm mm})^{2}=\ 125.66\ {\rm mm}^{2}\]
Thus the stress is:
\[\sigma_{f}=23,650\ {\rm N}/125.66\ {\rm mm}^{2}=\ 188\ {\rm MPa}\]
A titanium alloy with a modulus of elasticity of 16 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi is used to make a 1000-lb part for a manned space vehicle. Determine the weight of a part having the same modulus of elasticity parallel to the fibers, if the part is made of (a) aluminum reinforced with boron fibers and (b) polyester (with a modulus of 650,000 psi) reinforced with high-modulus carbon fibers. (c) Compare the specific modulus for all three materials. Solution: The titanium alloy has a density of about 4.507 g/cm\({}^{3}=0.163\) lb/in.\({}^{3}\). The volume of the 1000 lb part is therefore
\[V_{\rm part}=1000/0.163=6135\ {\rm in.}^{3}\]
\[E_{c} = 16\ \times\ 10^{6}=f_{\rm B}E_{\rm B}\,+\,(1\ -f_{\rm B})E_{\rm AI}\] \[=f_{\rm B}(55\ \times\ 10^{6})\ +\ (1\ -f_{\rm B})(10\ \times\ 10^{6})\] \[f_{\rm B} = 0.133\]
\[\rho_{c} = (0.133)(2.36\ {\rm g/cm^{3}})\ +\ (0.867)(2.699\ {\rm g/cm^{3}})= \ 2.654\ {\rm g/cm^{3}}\] \[= 0.0958\ {\rm lb/in.}^{3}\]
To produce a 6135 in.\({}^{3}\) part of the composite, the part must weigh:
\[{\rm Weight}=(6135\ {\rm in.}^{3})(0.0958\ {\rm lb/in.}^{3})=\ 587.7\ {\rm lb}\]* \(E_{c}=\) 16 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}=f_{c}E_{c}\) + \((1-f_{c})E_{\rm PET}\) \(=\) \(f_{\rm V}(77\)\(\times\) 10\({}^{6})\) + \((1-f_{c})(0.65\)\(\times\) 10\({}^{6})\) \(f_{c}\) = 0.201 \(\rho_{c}=\) (0.201)(1.9 g/cm\({}^{3})\) + \((0.799)(1.28\) g/cm\({}^{3})\) = 1.405 g/cm \(=\) 0.0507 lb/in.\({}^{3}\) To produce a 6135 in.\({}^{3}\) part of the composite, the part must weigh: \({\rm Weight}=(6135\) in.\({}^{3})(0.0507\) lb/in.\({}^{3})\) = 311 lb
* The specific modulii of the three materials are: \({\rm Ti}\): \(E/\rho=\) 16 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi/0.163 lb/in.\({}^{3}\) = 9.82 \(\times\) 10\({}^{7}\) in. \({\rm B}\)-Al: \(E/\rho=\) 16 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi/0.0958 lb/in.\({}^{3}\) = 16.7 \(\times\) 10\({}^{7}\) in. \({\rm C}\)-PET: \(E/\rho=\) 16 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi/0.0507 lb/in.\({}^{3}\) = 31.6 \(\times\) 10\({}^{7}\) in.
* Short but aligned Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) fibers with a diameter of 20 \(\mu\)m are introduced into a 6,6- nylon matrix. The strength of the bond between the fibers and the matrix is estimated to be 1000 psi. Calculate the critical fiber length and compare with the case when 1-\(\mu\)m alumina whiskers are used instead of the coarser fibers. What is the minimum aspect ratio in each case? Solution: The critical fiber length is given by \(\ell_{c}=\sigma_{f}d/2\tau_{i}\). For the alumina fibers, \(\tau_{i}=\) 1000 psi = 6.897 MPa; \(d=\) 20 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-6}\) m; and \(\sigma_{f}=\) 300,000 psi = 2069 MPa. Thus, for alumina fibers: \(\ell_{c}=\) (2069 MPa)(20 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-6}\) m)/(2)(6.897 MPa) \(=\) 0.003 m = 0.3 cm \(\ell_{c}\)/\(d\) = 0.3 cm/20 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) cm = 150 For alumina whiskers, \(d=\) 1 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-6}\) m. The strength of the whiskers can be much higher than that of the fibers; 3,000,000 psi = 20,690 MPa can be achieved. Thus, for alumina whiskers: \(\ell_{c}=\) (20,690 MPa)(1 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-6}\) m)/(2)(6.897 MPa) = 0.0015 m \(=\) 0.15 cm \(\ell_{c}\)/\(d\) = 0.15 cm/1 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) cm = 1500 We prepare several epoxy matrix composites using different lengths of 3-\(\mu\)m-diameter ZrO\({}_{2}\) fibers and find that the strength of the composite increases with increasing fiber length up to 5 mm. For longer fibers, the strength is virtually unchanged. Estimate the strength of the bond between the fibers and the matrix. Solution: We do not expect much change in the strength when \(\ell>\) 15\(\ell_{c}\). Therefore: \(15\ell_{c}=\) 5 mm or \(\ell_{c}=\) 0.333 mm
In addition, \(\ell_{c}=\sigma_{f}d/2\tau_{i}=\) 0.333 mm
For ZrO\({}_{2}\) fibers, the tensile strength = 300,000 psi = 2069 MPa. Therefore: \(\tau_{i}=\sigma_{f}d/2\ell_{c}=\) (2069 MPa)(0.003 mm)/(2)(0.333 mm) = 9.32 MPa* 16-36 In one polymer-matrix composite, as produced discontinuous glass fibers are introduced directly into the matrix; in a second case, the fibers are first "sized." Discuss the effect this difference might have on the critical fiber length and the strength of the composite. Solution: By sizing the glass fibers, the surface is conditioned so that improved bonding between the fibers and the matrix is obtained. From Equation 16-9, we expect that improved bonding (\(\tau_{i}\)) will reduce the length of fibers required for achieving good strength. Improved bonding will also reduce pull-out of the fibers from the matrix. Therefore the sizing improves the strength and allows small fibers to still be effective.

question: What would the modulus be if the same size boron fiber could be produced without the tungsten precursor?
answer: The modulus would be 39.21 x 10^6 psi if the same size boron fiber could be produced without the tungsten precursor.
context: * 16-37 A Borsic fiber-reinforced aluminum composite is shown in Figure 16-18. Estimate the volume fractions of tungsten, boron, and the matrix for this composite. Calculate the modulus of elasticity parallel to the fibers for this composite. What would the modulus be if the same size boron fiber could be produced without the tungsten precursor? Solution: From the photograph, the diameter of the tungsten core is about 2 mm, the diameter of the boron fiber is 30 mm, and the distance between the centers of adjacent fibers is 33 mm. If we assume that the fibers produce a square arrangement (see sketch), then \[A_{\rm total} = (33\ {\rm mm})^{2}\,=\,1089\ {\rm mm}^{2}\] \[A_{\rm tungsten} = (\pi/4)(2\ {\rm mm})^{2}\,=\,3.14\ {\rm mm}^{2}\] \[A_{\rm boron} = (\pi/4)(30\ {\rm mm})^{2}\,-\,3.14\ {\rm mm}^{2}\,=\,703.72\ {\rm mm}^{2}\] \[A_{\rm Al} = 1089\,-\,3.14\,-\,703.72\,=\,382.14\ {\rm mm}^{2}\] We can then determine the volume fractions: \[f_{\rm tungsten} = 3.14/1089\,=\,0.0029\] \[f_{\rm boron} = 703.72/1089\,=\,0.6462\] \[f_{\rm Al} = 382.14/1089\,=\,\,0.3509\] We can now estimate the modulus of elasticity of the composite using the rule of mixtures: \[E_{\rm composite} = (0.0029)(59\ \times\ 10^{6})\ +\ (0.6462)(55\ \times\ 10^{6})\] \[+\ (0.3509)(10\ \times\ 10^{6})\ =\,39.22\ \times\ 10^{6}\,{\rm psi}\] If the tungsten filament was absent, then \(f_{\rm boron}=0.6491\) and the modulus is: \[E_{\rm composite} = (0.6491)(55\ \times\ 10^{6})\ +\ (0.3509)(10\ \times\ 10^{6})\] \[= 39.21\ \times\ 10^{6}\,{\rm psi}\] The tungsten makes virtually no difference in the stiffness of the overall composite. Its function is to serve as the precursor for the boron.

question: Calculate the modulus of elasticity of the composite parallel to the sheets.
context: * 16--46 A 0.01-cm-thick sheet of a polymer with a modulus of elasticity of 0.7 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi is sandwiched between two 4-mm-thick sheets of glass with a modulus of elasticity of 12 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi. Calculate the modulus of elasticity of the composite parallel and perpendicular to the sheets. Solution: The volume fractions are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}f_{\rm polymer}&=&0.01\;{\rm cm}/(0.01\;{\rm cm}\;+\;0.4 \;{\rm cm}\;+\;0.4\;{\rm cm})\;=\;0.01234\\ f_{\rm glass}&=&0.98765\\ \end{array}\] The modulus parallel to the laminate is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}E_{\rm parallel}&=&(0.01234)(0.7\;\times\;10^{6})\;+\;(0. 98765)(12\;\times\;10^{6})\\ &=&11.86\;\times\;10^{6}\;{\rm psi}\\ \end{array}\] Perpendicular to the laminate: \[\begin{array}{lcl}1/E_{\rm perpendicular}&=&0.01234/0.7\;\times\;10^{6}\;+ \;0.98765/12\;\times\;10^{6}\\ &=&0.09994\;\times\;10^{6}\\ E_{\rm perpendicular}&=&10.0\;\times\;10^{6}\;{\rm psi}\\ \end{array}\] This material is "safety" glass and is used in automobile windshields to keep the windshield from shattering.

question: Calculate the modulus of elasticity of the composite perpendicular to the sheets.
context: * 16--46 A 0.01-cm-thick sheet of a polymer with a modulus of elasticity of 0.7 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi is sandwiched between two 4-mm-thick sheets of glass with a modulus of elasticity of 12 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) psi. Calculate the modulus of elasticity of the composite parallel and perpendicular to the sheets. Solution: The volume fractions are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}f_{\rm polymer}&=&0.01\;{\rm cm}/(0.01\;{\rm cm}\;+\;0.4 \;{\rm cm}\;+\;0.4\;{\rm cm})\;=\;0.01234\\ f_{\rm glass}&=&0.98765\\ \end{array}\] The modulus parallel to the laminate is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}E_{\rm parallel}&=&(0.01234)(0.7\;\times\;10^{6})\;+\;(0. 98765)(12\;\times\;10^{6})\\ &=&11.86\;\times\;10^{6}\;{\rm psi}\\ \end{array}\] Perpendicular to the laminate: \[\begin{array}{lcl}1/E_{\rm perpendicular}&=&0.01234/0.7\;\times\;10^{6}\;+ \;0.98765/12\;\times\;10^{6}\\ &=&0.09994\;\times\;10^{6}\\ E_{\rm perpendicular}&=&10.0\;\times\;10^{6}\;{\rm psi}\\ \end{array}\] This material is "safety" glass and is used in automobile windshields to keep the windshield from shattering.

question: A U.S. quarter is 15/16 in. in diameter and is about 1/16 in. thick. Assuming copper costs about $1.10 per pound and nickel costs about $4.10 per pound. Compare the material cost in a composite quarter versus a quarter made entirely of nickel.
answer:
The total cost of the composite (for materials only) = $0.0291

2.
context:
* 16--47 A U.S. quarter is 15/16 in. in diameter and is about 1/16 in. thick. Assuming copper costs about $1.10 per pound and nickel costs about $4.10 per pound. Compare the material cost in a composite quarter versus a quarter made entirely of nickel. Solution: In a quarter, the thickness (and hence the volume) ratio is 1/6 Ni: 2/3 Cu: 1/6 Ni. The volume fraction of each is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}f_{\rm Cu}&=&0.667&f_{\rm Ni}\;=\;0.333\\ \end{array}\] The volume of the quarter, as well as the copper and nickel, are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}V_{\rm quarter}&=&(\pi/4)(15/16\;{\rm in.})^{2}(1/16\;{ \rm in.})\;=\;0.04314\;{\rm in.}^{3}\;=\;0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ V_{\rm Cu}&=&(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(0.667)\;=\;0.4716\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ V_{\rm Ni}&=&(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(0.333)\;=\;0.2354\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ \end{array}\] The weights of copper and nickel in the coin are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}W_{\rm Cu}&=&(0.4716\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.93\;{\rm g/cm}^{3}) \;=\;4.211\;{\rm g}\;=\;0.00928\;{\rm lb}\\ W_{\rm Ni}&=&(0.2354\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.902\;{\rm g/cm}^{3})\;=\;2.0955\;{\rm g} \;=\;0.004616\;{\rm lb}\\ \end{array}\] The cost of each material in the coin is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\$/{\rm Cu}&=&(0.00925\;{\rm lb})(\$1.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$ 0.0102\\ \$/{\rm Ni}&=&(0.004616\;{\rm lb})(\$4.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$0.0189\\ \end{array}\] The total cost of the composite (for materials only) \(=\$0.0291\) If the entire coin were made of nickel, then \[\begin{array}{lcl}(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.902\;{\rm g/cm}^{3})(1/454\;{\rm g /lb})(\$4.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$0.0568\\ \end{array}\] By using the composite coin, the cost of the materials is about half that of a pure nickel coin, yet the coin appears to have the nickel (or silvery) color.
Calculate the density of a honeycomb structure composed of the following elements. The two 2-mm-thick cover sheets are produced using an epoxy matrix containing 55 vol% E-glass fibers. The aluminium honeycomb is 2 cm thick; the cells are in the shape of 0.5 cm squares and the walls of the cells are 0.1 mm thick. Estimate the density of the structure. Compare the weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb compared to a solid aluminum panel with the same dimensions.
\begin{tabular}{l l} Solution: & Each cell of aluminum can be considered to be a hollow square shape where the dimensions of the cell are 0.5 cm \(\times\) 0.5 cm \(\times\) 2 cm, with a wall thickness belonging uniquely to that cell of 0.1 mm\(/2=0.05\) mm \(=0.005\) cm. \\  & \(V_{\rm Al}=(4\) sides\()(0.005\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2\) cm\()=0.02\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The cover sheet dimensions that just cover the single cell described above are 0.5 cm \(\times\) 0.5 cm \(\times\) 2 mm \(=0.2\) cm. The volume is: \\  & \(V_{\rm cover}=(2\) sheets\()(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(0.2\) cm\()=0.1\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The total "height" of the cell, including the cover sheets, is 2 cm \(+\) 2(0.2 cm) \(=2.4\) cm. The total volume of the cell is: \\  & \(V_{\rm total}=(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2.4\) cm\()=0.6\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The volume fractions of these constituents are: \\  & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}=\,0.02/0.6\,=\,0.0333\) \\  & \(f_{\rm cover}=\,0.1/0.6\,=\,0.1667\) \\  & \(f_{\rm void}=\,0.80\) \\ \end{tabular}
The densities of the three constituents can be determined. The density of the aluminum in the cells is 2.699 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the density of the void space within the cells is zero. But the cover sheets are themselves composites:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm cover}=\) & \(f_{\rm glass}\,\rho_{\rm glass}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}parry}\,\rho_{\rm{e}parry}=(0.55)(2. 55\) g/cm\({}^{3})\) \\  & \(+\,(0.45)(1.25\) g/cm\({}^{3})=1.965\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
Therefore the overall density of the honeycomb structure is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,\rho_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}ver}\,\rho_{\rm{e} cover}\,+\,f_{\rm void}\,\rho_{\rm void}\) \\  & \(=\,(0.0333)(2.699)\,+\,(0.1667)(1.965)\,+\,(0.80)(0)\) \\  & \(=\,0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
The weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,20,\)016 g \\  & \(=\,20.016\) kg \(=\,44.1\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
If the panel were made of solid aluminum, with the same dimensions, the panel would weigh:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm solid}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(2.669\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,129,\)552 g \\  & \(=\,129.552\) kg \(=\,285\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
The weight savings using the honeycomb are enormous.
Construction Materials
* A sample of wood with dimensions 3 in. \(\times\) 4 in. \(\times\) 12 in. has a dry density of 0.35 g/cm\({}^{3}\). (a) Calculate the number of gallons of water that must be absorbed by the sample to contain 120% water. (b) Calculate the density after the wood absorbs this amount of water. Solution: \[V=3\ \times\ 4\ \times\ 12\ =\ 144\ \text{in.}^{3}=2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}\] \[\text{dry weight}=0.35\ \times\ 2359.7=825.9\ \text{g}\] \[\text{@120\% water}=\frac{\text{weight of water}}{\text{weight of dry wood}}\ \times\ 100\]
* water \[=(1.2)(825.9)=991\ \text{g}=2.183\ \text{lb}\] \[=(2.183\ \text{lb})(7.48\ \text{gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\ \text{lb/ft}^{3}=0.262\ \text{gal}\]
* If the volume remains the same, then \[\text{density}=\frac{825.9\ \text{g of dry wood}\ +\ 991\ \text{g of water}}{2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}}=0.77\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\]
* The density of a sample of oak is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\). Calculate (a) the density of completely dry oak and (b) the percent water in the original sample. Solution: \[\rho_{12\text{w water}}=0.68\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\quad(\text{Table\ 17--1})\]
* Therefore, in 100 cm\({}^{3}\) of wood at 12% H\({}_{2}\)O, there are 68 g. \[12\%\ \text{water}=\frac{\text{green weight}\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}=\frac{68\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}\times\ 100\] \[\text{dry weight}=68/1.12=60.71\ \text{g}\]
* When the density is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\), there are 90 g of green wood per 100 cm\({}^{3}\). The water is therefore 90 \(-\) 60.71 g, or 29.29 g. \[\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\,=\frac{90\;\mathrm{g}\;-\;60.71\;\mathrm{g}}{60.71\; \mathrm{g}}\times\,100\,=\,48.2\%\]
* Boards of map 1 in. thick, 6 in. wide, and 16 ft. long are used as the flooring for a 60 ft \(\times\) 60 ft hall. The boards were cut from logs with a tangential-longitudinal cut. The floor is laid when the boards have a moisture content of 12%. After some particularly humid days, the moisture content in the boards increases to 45%. Determine the dimensional change in the flooring parallel to the boards and perpendicular to the boards. What will happen to the floor? How can this problem be corrected? Solution: Perpendicular: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00353\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;maple}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,x_{0}[c(M_{f}-M_{i})]\,=\,6[0.00353(45\,-\,12)]\,=\,0.699 \;\mathrm{in.}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm{6}\;\mathrm{in.}\] Over a 60 ft span: \[\Delta x\,=\,\frac{(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})(0.699\;\mathrm{in.} )}{6\;\mathrm{in.}}\,=\,83.9\;\mathrm{in.}\] The floor will therefore buckle due to the large amount of expansion of the boards perpendicular to the flooring. Parallel: For most woods, only about a 0.2% change in dimensions occurs longitudinally. Thus the total change in the length of the boards will be about \[\Delta y\,=\,(0.002)(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})\,=\,1.44\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* A wall 30 feet long is built using radial-longitudinal cuts of 5-inch wide pine, with the boards arranged in a vertical fashion. The wood contains a moisture content of 55% when the wall is built; however the humidity level in the room is maintained to give 45% moisture in the wood. Determine the dimensional changes in the wood boards and estimate the size of the gaps that will be produced as a consequence of these changes. Solution: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00141\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;pine}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})[(0.00141\; \mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O})(45\,-\,55)]\] \[\qquad=\,-5.076\;\mathrm{in.}\] The total number of boards in the width of the wall is: \[\#\;\mathrm{of\;boards}\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})/5\;\mathrm{ in./board}\,=\,72\;\mathrm{boards}\] Therefore there are 71 gaps between the boards. The average width of the gaps is: \[\mathrm{gap}\,=\,5.076\;\mathrm{in./71\;\mathrm{gaps}}\,=\,0.0715\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* We have been asked to prepare 100 yd\({}^{3}\) of normal concrete using a volume ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate of 1 : 2 : 4. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is to be 0.5. The sand contains 6 wt% water and the coarse aggregate contains 3 wt% water. No entrained air is expected. (a) Determine the number of sacks of cement that must be ordered, the tons of sand and aggregate required, and the amount of water needed. (b) Calculate the total weight of the concrete per cubic yard. (c) What is the weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate?
Solution: First we can determine the volume of each material on a "sack" basis, keeping in mind the 1 : 2 : 4 volume ratio of solids and the 0.5 water-cement weight ratio:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{cement}&=&(1\mbox{ sack})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})/190\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(2)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(4)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(0.5)(94\mbox{ lb})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})&=&0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{total volume of materials/sack}&=&4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{In 100 yd}^{3},\mbox{ or }(100\mbox{ yd}^{3})(27\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{yd}^{3})\mbox{:}\\ \mbox{cement}&=&2700\mbox{ ft}^{3}/4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\,=\,640\mbox{ sacks}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(160\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&101,376\mbox{ lb}\,=\,50.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(170\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&215,424\mbox{ lb}\,=\,107.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\,=\,30,072\mbox{ lb}\quad\mbox{or}\\ &=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})\,=\,3,605\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
But we must make adjustments for the water that is already present in the sand and aggregate. There is 6% water in the sand and 3% water in the aggregate. We can either multiply the dry sand by 1.06, or divide the dry sand by 0.94, to obtain the amount of wet sand that we need to order.
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wet sand}&=&(101,376\mbox{ lb})(1.06)\,=\,107,459\mbox{ lb}\,=\,53.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in sand}&=&107,459\,-\,101,376\,=\,6083\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{wet aggregate}&=&(215,424\mbox{ lb})(1.03)\,=\,221,887\mbox{ lb}\,=\,110.9\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in aggregate}&=&221,887\,-\,215,424\,=\,6463\mbox{ lb}\end{array}\]
The actual amount of water that should be added to the concrete mix is:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{water}&=&30,072\,-\,6083\,-\,6463\,=\,17,526\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{gal water}&=&(17,526\mbox{ lb})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}\\ &=&2101\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
Therefore:
1. The ingredients of the concrete mix are: 640 sacks of cement 53.7 tons of sand 110.9 tons of aggregate 2101 gal of water 2. The total weight per yd\({}^{3}\) is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wt}/\mbox{yd}^{3}&=&\frac{(640\mbox{ sacks})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})\,+\,107,459\,+\,221,887\,+\,17,526}{100\mbox{ yd}^{3}}\\ &=&4070\mbox{ lb/yd}^{3}\end{array}\]3. The cement-sand-aggregate ratio, on a weight basis, is: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{ratio}&=&(640\text{ sacks})(94\text{ lb/sack})\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847 lb}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887 lb}\\ &=&60,\text{160}\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887}\\ &=&1\text{:}\,17\text{:}\,\text{9}\,\text{:}\,3.69\end{array}\]
* We plan to prepare 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\) of concrete using a 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is 0.45. The sand contains 3 wt% water, the coarse aggregate contains 2 wt% water, and 5% entrained air is expected. Determine the number of sacks of cement, tons of sand, and coarse aggregate, and gallons of water required. Solution: First, we can determine the volume of each material required, using the 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 ratio to determine the weights per sack of cement and dividing by the density to determine the volume. Per sack of cement: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement:}&94\text{ lb/sack}/190\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{sand:}&(2.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/160\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{aggregate:}&(4.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/170\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{water:}&(0.45)(94\text{ lb/sack})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ &\text{Volume per sack}&=&5.130\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\end{array}\]
But 5% of the concrete is expected to be entrained air. The volume of air "\(x\)" per sack of cement is:
\[x/(5.130\,+\,x)\,=\,0.05\quad\text{or}\quad x\,=\,0.27\text{ ft}^{3}\]
Therefore the total volume of concrete per sack is:
Volume of concrete \(=\,5.130\,+\,0.27\,=\,5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\)
In 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\)\(=\,270\text{ ft}^{3}\):
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&270\text{ ft}^{3}/5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\,=\,50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(160\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,11,\text{752 lb}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(170\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,21,\text{148 lb}\\ \text{water}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,2,\text{115 lb}\end{array}\]
But we must also adjust for the water present in the wet sand (3%) and wet aggregate (2%). For example, to find the amount of wet sand, we could either multiply the dry sand by 1.03 or divide by 0.97:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{wet sand}&=&11,\text{752 lb}/0.97\,=\,12,\text{115 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,363\text{ lb}\\ \text{wet aggregate}&=&21,\text{148 lb}/0.98\,=\,21,\text{580 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,432\text{ lb}\end{array}\]
Therefore, the ingredients for the concrete mix include:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&12,\text{115 lb}\,=\,6.06\text{ tons}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&21,\text{580 lb}\,=\,10.8\text{ tons}\\ \text{water}&=&2115\,-\,363\,-\,432\,=\,1320\text{ lb}\\ &=&(1320\text{ lb})(7.48\text{ gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}\,=\,158\text{ gal}\end{array}\]* 18-1 A current of 10 A is passed through a 1-mm-diameter wire 1000 m long. Calculate the power loss if the wire is made of (a) aluminum, (b) silicon, and (c) silicon carbide. (See Table 18-1). Solution: Power \(=I^{2}R=I^{2}\ell/\sigma A=(10\,A)^{2}(100,\!000\;\mathrm{cm})/(\pi/4)(0.1\; \mathrm{cm})^{2}\sigma\) Power \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/\sigma\) The electrical conductivity of each material is given in Table 18-1: 1. \(\mathrm{P_{Al}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/3.77\;\times\;10^{5}=3380\;\mathrm{watt}\) 2. \(\mathrm{P_{Si}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/5\;\times\;10^{-6}=2.546\;\times\;10^{14 }\;\mathrm{watt}\) 3. \(\mathrm{P_{SSC}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/10^{-1}\;\mathrm{to}\;10^{-2}\) \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{to}\;1.273\;\times\;10^{11}\;\mathrm{watt}\)

question: Calculate the density of a honeycomb structure composed of the following elements. The two 2-mm-thick cover sheets are produced using an epoxy matrix containing 55 vol% E-glass fibers. The aluminium honeycomb is 2 cm thick; the cells are in the shape of 0.5 cm squares and the walls of the cells are 0.1 mm thick. Estimate the density of the structure. Compare the weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb compared to a solid aluminum panel with the same dimensions.
answer:
The density of the honeycomb structure = 0.417 g/cm\(^3\)

context:
* 16--47 A U.S. quarter is 15/16 in. in diameter and is about 1/16 in. thick. Assuming copper costs about $1.10 per pound and nickel costs about $4.10 per pound. Calculate the density of a honeycomb structure composed of the following elements. The two 2-mm-thick cover sheets are produced using an epoxy matrix containing 55 vol% E-glass fibers. The aluminium honeycomb is 2 cm thick; the cells are in the shape of 0.5 cm squares and the walls of the cells are 0.1 mm thick. Estimate the density of the structure. Compare the weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb compared to a solid aluminum panel with the same dimensions.
\begin{tabular}{l l} Solution: & Each cell of aluminum can be considered to be a hollow square shape where the dimensions of the cell are 0.5 cm \(\times\) 0.5 cm \(\times\) 2 cm, with a wall thickness belonging uniquely to that cell of 0.1 mm\(/2=0.05\) mm \(=0.005\) cm. \\  & \(V_{\rm Al}=(4\) sides\()(0.005\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2\) cm\()=0.02\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The cover sheet dimensions that just cover the single cell described above are 0.5 cm \(\times\) 0.5 cm \(\times\) 2 mm \(=0.2\) cm. The volume is: \\  & \(V_{\rm cover}=(2\) sheets\()(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(0.2\) cm\()=0.1\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The total "height" of the cell, including the cover sheets, is 2 cm \(+\) 2(0.2 cm) \(=2.4\) cm. The total volume of the cell is: \\  & \(V_{\rm total}=(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2.4\) cm\()=0.6\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The volume fractions of these constituents are: \\  & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}=\,0.02/0.6\,=\,0.0333\) \\  & \(f_{\rm cover}=\,0.1/0.6\,=\,0.1667\) \\  & \(f_{\rm void}=\,0.80\) \\ \end{tabular}
The densities of the three constituents can be determined. The density of the aluminum in the cells is 2.699 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the density of the void space within the cells is zero. But the cover sheets are themselves composites:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm cover}=\) & \(f_{\rm glass}\,\rho_{\rm glass}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}parry}\,\rho_{\rm{e}parry}=(0.55)(2. 55\) g/cm\({}^{3})\) \\  & \(+\,(0.45)(1.25\) g/cm\({}^{3})=1.965\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
Therefore the overall density of the honeycomb structure is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,\rho_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}ver}\,\rho_{\rm{e} cover}\,+\,f_{\rm void}\,\rho_{\rm void}\) \\  & \(=\,(0.0333)(2.699)\,+\,(0.1667)(1.965)\,+\,(0.80)(0)\) \\  & \(=\,0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
The weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,20,\)016 g \\  & \(=\,20.016\) kg \(=\,44.1\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
If the panel were made of solid aluminum, with the same dimensions, the panel would weigh:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm solid}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(2.669\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,129,\)552 g \\  & \(=\,129.552\) kg \(=\,285\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
The weight savings using the honeycomb are enormous.
Construction Materials
* A sample of wood with dimensions 3 in. \(\times\) 4 in. \(\times\) 12 in. has a dry density of 0.35 g/cm\({}^{3}\). (a) Calculate the number of gallons of water that must be absorbed by the sample to contain 120% water. (b) Calculate the density after the wood absorbs this amount of water. Solution: \[V=3\ \times\ 4\ \times\ 12\ =\ 144\ \text{in.}^{3}=2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}\] \[\text{dry weight}=0.35\ \times\ 2359.7=825.9\ \text{g}\] \[\text{@120\% water}=\frac{\text{weight of water}}{\text{weight of dry wood}}\ \times\ 100\]
* water \[=(1.2)(825.9)=991\ \text{g}=2.183\ \text{lb}\] \[=(2.183\ \text{lb})(7.48\ \text{gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\ \text{lb/ft}^{3}=0.262\ \text{gal}\]
* If the volume remains the same, then \[\text{density}=\frac{825.9\ \text{g of dry wood}\ +\ 991\ \text{g of water}}{2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}}=0.77\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\]
* The density of a sample of oak is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\). Calculate (a) the density of completely dry oak and (b) the percent water in the original sample. Solution: \[\rho_{12\text{w water}}=0.68\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\quad(\text{Table\ 17--1})\]
* Therefore, in 100 cm\({}^{3}\) of wood at 12% H\({}_{2}\)O, there are 68 g. \[12\%\ \text{water}=\frac{\text{green weight}\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}=\frac{68\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}\times\ 100\] \[\text{dry weight}=68/1.12=60.71\ \text{g}\]
* When the density is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\), there are 90 g of green wood per 100 cm\({}^{3}\). The water is therefore 90 \(-\) 60.71 g, or 29.29 g. \[\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\,=\frac{90\;\mathrm{g}\;-\;60.71\;\mathrm{g}}{60.71\; \mathrm{g}}\times\,100\,=\,48.2\%\]
* Boards of map 1 in. thick, 6 in. wide, and 16 ft. long are used as the flooring for a 60 ft \(\times\) 60 ft hall. The boards were cut from logs with a tangential-longitudinal cut. The floor is laid when the boards have a moisture content of 12%. After some particularly humid days, the moisture content in the boards increases to 45%. Determine the dimensional change in the flooring parallel to the boards and perpendicular to the boards. What will happen to the floor? How can this problem be corrected? Solution: Perpendicular: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00353\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;maple}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,x_{0}[c(M_{f}-M_{i})]\,=\,6[0.00353(45\,-\,12)]\,=\,0.699 \;\mathrm{in.}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm{6}\;\mathrm{in.}\] Over a 60 ft span: \[\Delta x\,=\,\frac{(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})(0.699\;\mathrm{in.} )}{6\;\mathrm{in.}}\,=\,83.9\;\mathrm{in.}\] The floor will therefore buckle due to the large amount of expansion of the boards perpendicular to the flooring. Parallel: For most woods, only about a 0.2% change in dimensions occurs longitudinally. Thus the total change in the length of the boards will be about \[\Delta y\,=\,(0.002)(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})\,=\,1.44\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* A wall 30 feet long is built using radial-longitudinal cuts of 5-inch wide pine, with the boards arranged in a vertical fashion. The wood contains a moisture content of 55% when the wall is built; however the humidity level in the room is maintained to give 45% moisture in the wood. Determine the dimensional changes in the wood boards and estimate the size of the gaps that will be produced as a consequence of these changes. Solution: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00141\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;pine}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})[(0.00141\; \mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O})(45\,-\,55)]\] \[\qquad=\,-5.076\;\mathrm{in.}\] The total number of boards in the width of the wall is: \[\#\;\mathrm{of\;boards}\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})/5\;\mathrm{ in./board}\,=\,72\;\mathrm{boards}\] Therefore there are 71 gaps between the boards. The average width of the gaps is: \[\mathrm{gap}\,=\,5.076\;\mathrm{in./71\;\mathrm{gaps}}\,=\,0.0715\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* We have been asked to prepare 100 yd\({}^{3}\) of normal concrete using a volume ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate of 1 : 2 : 4. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is to be 0.5. The sand contains 6 wt% water and the coarse aggregate contains 3 wt% water. No entrained air is expected. (a) Determine the number of sacks of cement that must be ordered, the tons of sand and aggregate required, and the amount of water needed. (b) Calculate the total weight of the concrete per cubic yard. (c) What is the weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate?
Solution: First we can determine the volume of each material on a "sack" basis, keeping in mind the 1 : 2 : 4 volume ratio of solids and the 0.5 water-cement weight ratio:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{cement}&=&(1\mbox{ sack})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})/190\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(2)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(4)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(0.5)(94\mbox{ lb})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})&=&0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{total volume of materials/sack}&=&4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{In 100 yd}^{3},\mbox{ or }(100\mbox{ yd}^{3})(27\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{yd}^{3})\mbox{:}\\ \mbox{cement}&=&2700\mbox{ ft}^{3}/4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\,=\,640\mbox{ sacks}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(160\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&101,376\mbox{ lb}\,=\,50.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(170\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&215,424\mbox{ lb}\,=\,107.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\,=\,30,072\mbox{ lb}\quad\mbox{or}\\ &=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})\,=\,3,605\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
But we must make adjustments for the water that is already present in the sand and aggregate. There is 6% water in the sand and 3% water in the aggregate. We can either multiply the dry sand by 1.06, or divide the dry sand by 0.94, to obtain the amount of wet sand that we need to order.
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wet sand}&=&(101,376\mbox{ lb})(1.06)\,=\,107,459\mbox{ lb}\,=\,53.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in sand}&=&107,459\,-\,101,376\,=\,6083\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{wet aggregate}&=&(215,424\mbox{ lb})(1.03)\,=\,221,887\mbox{ lb}\,=\,110.9\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in aggregate}&=&221,887\,-\,215,424\,=\,6463\mbox{ lb}\end{array}\]
The actual amount of water that should be added to the concrete mix is:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{water}&=&30,072\,-\,6083\,-\,6463\,=\,17,526\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{gal water}&=&(17,526\mbox{ lb})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}\\ &=&2101\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
Therefore:
1. The ingredients of the concrete mix are: 640 sacks of cement 53.7 tons of sand 110.9 tons of aggregate 2101 gal of water 2. The total weight per yd\({}^{3}\) is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wt}/\mbox{yd}^{3}&=&\frac{(640\mbox{ sacks})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})\,+\,107,459\,+\,221,887\,+\,17,526}{100\mbox{ yd}^{3}}\\ &=&4070\mbox{ lb/yd}^{3}\end{array}\]3. The cement-sand-aggregate ratio, on a weight basis, is: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{ratio}&=&(640\text{ sacks})(94\text{ lb/sack})\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847 lb}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887 lb}\\ &=&60,\text{160}\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887}\\ &=&1\text{:}\,17\text{:}\,\text{9}\,\text{:}\,3.69\end{array}\]
* We plan to prepare 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\) of concrete using a 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is 0.45. The sand contains 3 wt% water, the coarse aggregate contains 2 wt% water, and 5% entrained air is expected. Determine the number of sacks of cement, tons of sand, and coarse aggregate, and gallons of water required. Solution: First, we can determine the volume of each material required, using the 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 ratio to determine the weights per sack of cement and dividing by the density to determine the volume. Per sack of cement: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement:}&94\text{ lb/sack}/190\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{sand:}&(2.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/160\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{aggregate:}&(4.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/170\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{water:}&(0.45)(94\text{ lb/sack})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ &\text{Volume per sack}&=&5.130\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\end{array}\]
But 5% of the concrete is expected to be entrained air. The volume of air "\(x\)" per sack of cement is:
\[x/(5.130\,+\,x)\,=\,0.05\quad\text{or}\quad x\,=\,0.27\text{ ft}^{3}\]
Therefore the total volume of concrete per sack is:
Volume of concrete \(=\,5.130\,+\,0.27\,=\,5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\)
In 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\)\(=\,270\text{ ft}^{3}\):
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&270\text{ ft}^{3}/5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\,=\,50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(160\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,11,\text{752 lb}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(170\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,21,\text{148 lb}\\ \text{water}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,2,\text{115 lb}\end{array}\]
But we must also adjust for the water present in the wet sand (3%) and wet aggregate (2%). For example, to find the amount of wet sand, we could either multiply the dry sand by 1.03 or divide by 0.97:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{wet sand}&=&11,\text{752 lb}/0.97\,=\,12,\text{115 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,363\text{ lb}\\ \text{wet aggregate}&=&21,\text{148 lb}/0.98\,=\,21,\text{580 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,432\text{ lb}\end{array}\]
Therefore, the ingredients for the concrete mix include:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&12,\text{115 lb}\,=\,6.06\text{ tons}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&21,\text{580 lb}\,=\,10.8\text{ tons}\\ \text{water}&=&2115\,-\,363\,-\,432\,=\,1320\text{ lb}\\ &=&(1320\text{ lb})(7.48\text{ gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}\,=\,158\text{ gal}\end{array}\]* 18-1 A current of 10 A is passed through a 1-mm-diameter wire 1000 m long. Calculate the power loss if the wire is made of (a) aluminum, (b) silicon, and (c) silicon carbide. (See Table 18-1). Solution: Power \(=I^{2}R=I^{2}\ell/\sigma A=(10\,A)^{2}(100,\!000\;\mathrm{cm})/(\pi/4)(0.1\; \mathrm{cm})^{2}\sigma\) Power \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/\sigma\) The electrical conductivity of each material is given in Table 18-1: 1. \(\mathrm{P_{Al}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/3.77\;\times\;10^{5}=3380\;\mathrm{watt}\) 2. \(\mathrm{P_{Si}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/5\;\times\;10^{-6}=2.546\;\times\;10^{14 }\;\mathrm{watt}\) 3. \(\mathrm{P_{SSC}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/10^{-1}\;\mathrm{to}\;10^{-2}\) \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{to}\;1.273\;\times\;10^{11}\;\mathrm{watt}\)

question: A wall 30 feet long is built using radial-longitudinal cuts of 5-inch wide pine, with the boards arranged in a vertical fashion. The wood contains a moisture content of 55% when the wall is built; however the humidity level in the room is maintained to give 45% moisture in the wood. Determine the dimensional changes in the wood boards and estimate the size of the gaps that will be produced as a consequence of these changes.
answer:
The dimensional change in the width of the wall = -5.076 in. The average width of the gaps = 0.0715 in.

7.
context:
* 16--47 A U.S. quarter is 15/16 in. in diameter and is about 1/16 in. thick. Assuming copper costs about $1.10 per pound and nickel costs about $4.10 per pound. Compare the material cost in a composite quarter versus a quarter made entirely of nickel. Solution: In a quarter, the thickness (and hence the volume) ratio is 1/6 Ni: 2/3 Cu: 1/6 Ni. The volume fraction of each is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}f_{\rm Cu}&=&0.667&f_{\rm Ni}\;=\;0.333\\ \end{array}\] The volume of the quarter, as well as the copper and nickel, are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}V_{\rm quarter}&=&(\pi/4)(15/16\;{\rm in.})^{2}(1/16\;{ \rm in.})\;=\;0.04314\;{\rm in.}^{3}\;=\;0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ V_{\rm Cu}&=&(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(0.667)\;=\;0.4716\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ V_{\rm Ni}&=&(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(0.333)\;=\;0.2354\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ \end{array}\] The weights of copper and nickel in the coin are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}W_{\rm Cu}&=&(0.4716\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.93\;{\rm g/cm}^{3}) \;=\;4.211\;{\rm g}\;=\;0.00928\;{\rm lb}\\ W_{\rm Ni}&=&(0.2354\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.902\;{\rm g/cm}^{3})\;=\;2.0955\;{\rm g} \;=\;0.004616\;{\rm lb}\\ \end{array}\] The cost of each material in the coin is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\$/{\rm Cu}&=&(0.00925\;{\rm lb})(\$1.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$ 0.0102\\ \$/{\rm Ni}&=&(0.004616\;{\rm lb})(\$4.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$0.0189\\ \end{array}\] The total cost of the composite (for materials only) \(=\$0.0291\) If the entire coin were made of nickel, then \[\begin{array}{lcl}(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.902\;{\rm g/cm}^{3})(1/454\;{\rm g /lb})(\$4.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$0.0568\\ \end{array}\] By using the composite coin, the cost of the materials is about half that of a pure nickel coin, yet the coin appears to have the nickel (or silvery) color.

The wood contains a moisture content of 55% when the wall is built; however the humidity level in the room is maintained to give 45% moisture in the wood. Determine the dimensional changes in the wood boards and estimate the size of the gaps that will be produced as a consequence of these changes. Solution: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00141\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;pine}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})[(0.00141\; \mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O})(45\,-\,55)]\] \[\qquad=\,-5.076\;\mathrm{in.}\] The total number of boards in the width of the wall is: \[\#\;\mathrm{of\;boards}\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})/5\;\mathrm{ in./board}\,=\,72\;\mathrm{boards}\] Therefore there are 71 gaps between the boards. The average width of the gaps is: \[\mathrm{gap}\,=\,5.076\;\mathrm{in./71\;\mathrm{gaps}}\,=\,0.0715\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* We have been asked to prepare 100 yd\({}^{3}\) of normal concrete using a volume ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate of 1 : 2 : 4. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is to be 0.5. The sand contains 6 wt% water and the coarse aggregate contains 3 wt% water. No entrained air is expected. (a) Determine the number of sacks of cement that must be ordered, the tons of sand and aggregate required, and the amount of water needed. (b) Calculate the total weight of the concrete per cubic yard. (c) What is the weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate?
Solution: First we can determine the volume of each material on a "sack" basis, keeping in mind the 1 : 2 : 4 volume ratio of solids and the 0.5 water-cement weight ratio:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{cement}&=&(1\mbox{ sack})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})/190\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(2)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(4)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(0.5)(94\mbox{ lb})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})&=&0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{total volume of materials/sack}&=&4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{In 100 yd}^{3},\mbox{ or }(100\mbox{ yd}^{3})(27\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{yd}^{3})\mbox{:}\\ \mbox{cement}&=&2700\mbox{ ft}^{3}/4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\,=\,640\mbox{ sacks}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(160\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&101,376\mbox{ lb}\,=\,50.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(170\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&215,424\mbox{ lb}\,=\,107.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\,=\,30,072\mbox{ lb}\quad\mbox{or}\\ &=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})\,=\,3,605\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
But we must make adjustments for the water that is already present in the sand and aggregate. There is 6% water in the sand and 3% water in the aggregate. We can either multiply the dry sand by 1.06, or divide the dry sand by 0.94, to obtain the amount of wet sand that we need to order.
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wet sand}&=&(101,376\mbox{ lb})(1.06)\,=\,107,459\mbox{ lb}\,=\,53.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in sand}&=&107,459\,-\,101,376\,=\,6083\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{wet aggregate}&=&(215,424\mbox{ lb})(1.03)\,=\,221,887\mbox{ lb}\,=\,110.9\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in aggregate}&=&221,887\,-\,215,424\,=\,6463\mbox{ lb}\end{array}\]
The actual amount of water that should be added to the concrete mix is:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{water}&=&30,072\,-\,6083\,-\,6463\,=\,17,526\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{gal water}&=&(17,526\mbox{ lb})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}\\ &=&2101\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
Therefore:
1. The ingredients of the concrete mix are: 640 sacks of cement 53.7 tons of sand 110.9 tons of aggregate 2101 gal of water 2. The total weight per yd\({}^{3}\) is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wt}/\mbox{yd}^{3}&=&\frac{(640\mbox{ sacks})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})\,+\,107,459\,+\,221,887\,+\,17,526}{100\mbox{ yd}^{3}}\\ &=&4070\mbox{ lb/yd}^{3}\end{array}\]3. The cement-sand-aggregate ratio, on a weight basis, is: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{ratio}&=&(640\text{ sacks})(94\text{ lb/sack})\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847 lb}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887 lb}\\ &=&60,\text{160}\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887}\\ &=&1\text{:}\,17\text{:}\,\text{9}\,\text{:}\,3.69\end{array}\]
* We plan to prepare 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\) of concrete using a 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is 0.45. The sand contains 3 wt% water, the coarse aggregate contains 2 wt% water, and 5% entrained air is expected. Determine the number of sacks of cement, tons of sand, and coarse aggregate, and gallons of water required. Solution: First, we can determine the volume of each material required, using the 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 ratio to determine the weights per sack of cement and dividing by the density to determine the volume. Per sack of cement: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement:}&94\text{ lb/sack}/190\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{sand:}&(2.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/160\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{aggregate:}&(4.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/170\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{water:}&(0.45)(94\text{ lb/sack})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ &\text{Volume per sack}&=&5.130\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\end{array}\]
But 5% of the concrete is expected to be entrained air. The volume of air "\(x\)" per sack of cement is:
\[x/(5.130\,+\,x)\,=\,0.05\quad\text{or}\quad x\,=\,0.27\text{ ft}^{3}\]
Therefore the total volume of concrete per sack is:
Volume of concrete \(=\,5.130\,+\,0.27\,=\,5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\)
In 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\)\(=\,270\text{ ft}^{3}\):
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&270\text{ ft}^{3}/5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\,=\,50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(160\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,11,\text{752 lb}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(170\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,21,\text{148 lb}\\ \text{water}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,2,\text{115 lb}\end{array}\]
But we must also adjust for the water present in the wet sand (3%) and wet aggregate (2%). For example, to find the amount of wet sand, we could either multiply the dry sand by 1.03 or divide by 0.97:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{wet sand}&=&11,\text{752 lb}/0.97\,=\,12,\text{115 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,363\text{ lb}\\ \text{wet aggregate}&=&21,\text{148 lb}/0.98\,=\,21,\text{580 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,432\text{ lb}\end{array}\]
Therefore, the ingredients for the concrete mix include:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&12,\text{115 lb}\,=\,6.06\text{ tons}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&21,\text{580 lb}\,=\,10.8\text{ tons}\\ \text{water}&=&2115\,-\,363\,-\,432\,=\,1320\text{ lb}\\ &=&(1320\text{ lb})(7.48\text{ gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}\,=\,158\text{ gal}\end{array}\]* 18-1 A current of 10 A is passed through a 1-mm-diameter wire 1000 m long. Calculate the power loss if the wire is made of (a) aluminum, (b) silicon, and (c) silicon carbide. (See Table 18-1). Solution: Power \(=I^{2}R=I^{2}\ell/\sigma A=(10\,A)^{2}(100,\!000\;\mathrm{cm})/(\pi/4)(0.1\; \mathrm{cm})^{2}\sigma\) Power \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/\sigma\) The electrical conductivity of each material is given in Table 18-1: 1. \(\mathrm{P_{Al}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/3.77\;\times\;10^{5}=3380\;\mathrm{watt}\) 2. \(\mathrm{P_{Si}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/5\;\times\;10^{-6}=2.546\;\times\;10^{14 }\;\mathrm{watt}\) 3. \(\mathrm{P_{SSC}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/10^{-1}\;\mathrm{to}\;10^{-2}\) \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{to}\;1.273\;\times\;10^{11}\;\mathrm{watt}\)

question: We have been asked to prepare 100 yd\({}^{3}\) of normal concrete using a volume ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate of 1 : 2 : 4. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is to be 0.5. The sand contains 6 wt% water and the coarse aggregate contains 3 wt% water. No entrained air is expected. (a) Determine the number of sacks of cement that must be ordered, the tons of sand and aggregate required, and the amount of water needed. (b) Calculate the total weight of the concrete per cubic yard. (c) What is the weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate?
answer:
(a) The amount of water needed = 3,605 gal (b) The total weight of the concrete per cubic yard = 4070 lb/yd\({}^{3}\) (c) The weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate is 1 : 17 : 9 : 3.69

context:
* 16--47 A U.S. quarter is 15/16 in. in diameter and is about 1/16 in. thick. Assuming copper costs about $1.10 per pound and nickel costs about $4.10 per pound. Compare the material cost in a composite quarter versus a quarter made entirely of nickel. Solution: In a quarter, the thickness (and hence the volume) ratio is 1/6 Ni: 2/3 Cu: 1/6 Ni. The volume fraction of each is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}f_{\rm Cu}&=&0.667&f_{\rm Ni}\;=\;0.333\\ \end{array}\] The volume of the quarter, as well as the copper and nickel, are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}V_{\rm quarter}&=&(\pi/4)(15/16\;{\rm in.})^{2}(1/16\;{ \rm in.})\;=\;0.04314\;{\rm in.}^{3}\;=\;0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ V_{\rm Cu}&=&(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(0.667)\;=\;0.4716\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ V_{\rm Ni}&=&(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(0.333)\;=\;0.2354\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ \end{array}\] The weights of copper and nickel in the coin are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}W_{\rm Cu}&=&(0.4716\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.93\;{\rm g/cm}^{3}) \;=\;4.211\;{\rm g}\;=\;0.00928\;{\rm lb}\\ W_{\rm Ni}&=&(0.2354\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.902\;{\rm g/cm}^{3})\;=\;2.0955\;{\rm g} \;=\;0.004616\;{\rm lb}\\ \end{array}\] The cost of each material in the coin is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\$/{\rm Cu}&=&(0.00925\;{\rm lb})(\$1.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$ 0.0102\\ \$/{\rm Ni}&=&(0.004616\;{\rm lb})(\$4.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$0.0189\\ \end{array}\] The total cost of the composite (for materials only) \(=\$0.0291\) If the entire coin were made of nickel, then \[\begin{array}{lcl}(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.902\;{\rm g/cm}^{3})(1/454\;{\rm g /lb})(\$4.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$0.0568\\ \end{array}\] By using the composite coin, the cost of the materials is about half that of a pure nickel coin, yet the coin appears to have the nickel (or silvery) color.
Calculate the density of a honeycomb structure composed of the following elements. The two 2-mm-thick cover sheets are produced using an epoxy matrix containing 55 vol% E-glass fibers. The aluminium honeycomb is 2 cm thick; the cells are in the shape of 0.5 cm squares and the walls of the cells are 0.1 mm thick. Estimate the density of the structure. Compare the weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb compared to a solid aluminum panel with the same dimensions.
\begin{tabular}{l l} Solution: & Each cell of aluminum can be considered to be a hollow square shape where the dimensions of the cell are 0.5 cm \(\times\) 0.5 cm \(\times\) 2 cm, with a wall thickness belonging uniquely to that cell of 0.1 mm\(/2=0.05\) mm \(=0.005\) cm. \\  & \(V_{\rm Al}=(4\) sides\()(0.005\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2\) cm\()=0.02\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The cover sheet dimensions that just cover the single cell described above are 0.5 cm \(\times\) 0.5 cm \(\times\) 2 mm \(=0.2\) cm. The volume is: \\  & \(V_{\rm cover}=(2\) sheets\()(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(0.2\) cm\()=0.1\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The total "height" of the cell, including the cover sheets, is 2 cm \(+\) 2(0.2 cm) \(=2.4\) cm. The total volume of the cell is: \\  & \(V_{\rm total}=(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2.4\) cm\()=0.6\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The volume fractions of these constituents are: \\  & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}=\,0.02/0.6\,=\,0.0333\) \\  & \(f_{\rm cover}=\,0.1/0.6\,=\,0.1667\) \\  & \(f_{\rm void}=\,0.80\) \\ \end{tabular}
The densities of the three constituents can be determined. The density of the aluminum in the cells is 2.699 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the density of the void space within the cells is zero. But the cover sheets are themselves composites:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm cover}=\) & \(f_{\rm glass}\,\rho_{\rm glass}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}parry}\,\rho_{\rm{e}parry}=(0.55)(2. 55\) g/cm\({}^{3})\) \\  & \(+\,(0.45)(1.25\) g/cm\({}^{3})=1.965\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
Therefore the overall density of the honeycomb structure is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,\rho_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}ver}\,\rho_{\rm{e} cover}\,+\,f_{\rm void}\,\rho_{\rm void}\) \\  & \(=\,(0.0333)(2.699)\,+\,(0.1667)(1.965)\,+\,(0.80)(0)\) \\  & \(=\,0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
The weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,20,\)016 g \\  & \(=\,20.016\) kg \(=\,44.1\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
If the panel were made of solid aluminum, with the same dimensions, the panel would weigh:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm solid}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(2.669\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,129,\)552 g \\  & \(=\,129.552\) kg \(=\,285\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
The weight savings using the honeycomb are enormous.
Construction Materials
* A sample of wood with dimensions 3 in. \(\times\) 4 in. \(\times\) 12 in. has a dry density of 0.35 g/cm\({}^{3}\). (a) Calculate the number of gallons of water that must be absorbed by the sample to contain 120% water. (b) Calculate the density after the wood absorbs this amount of water. Solution: \[V=3\ \times\ 4\ \times\ 12\ =\ 144\ \text{in.}^{3}=2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}\] \[\text{dry weight}=0.35\ \times\ 2359.7=825.9\ \text{g}\] \[\text{@120\% water}=\frac{\text{weight of water}}{\text{weight of dry wood}}\ \times\ 100\]
* water \[=(1.2)(825.9)=991\ \text{g}=2.183\ \text{lb}\] \[=(2.183\ \text{lb})(7.48\ \text{gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\ \text{lb/ft}^{3}=0.262\ \text{gal}\]
* If the volume remains the same, then \[\text{density}=\frac{825.9\ \text{g of dry wood}\ +\ 991\ \text{g of water}}{2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}}=0.77\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\]
* The density of a sample of oak is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\). Calculate (a) the density of completely dry oak and (b) the percent water in the original sample. Solution: \[\rho_{12\text{w water}}=0.68\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\quad(\text{Table\ 17--1})\]
* Therefore, in 100 cm\({}^{3}\) of wood at 12% H\({}_{2}\)O, there are 68 g. \[12\%\ \text{water}=\frac{\text{green weight}\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}=\frac{68\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}\times\ 100\] \[\text{dry weight}=68/1.12=60.71\ \text{g}\]
* When the density is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\), there are 90 g of green wood per 100 cm\({}^{3}\). The water is therefore 90 \(-\) 60.71 g, or 29.29 g. \[\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\,=\frac{90\;\mathrm{g}\;-\;60.71\;\mathrm{g}}{60.71\; \mathrm{g}}\times\,100\,=\,48.2\%\]
* Boards of map 1 in. thick, 6 in. wide, and 16 ft. long are used as the flooring for a 60 ft \(\times\) 60 ft hall. The boards were cut from logs with a tangential-longitudinal cut. The floor is laid when the boards have a moisture content of 12%. After some particularly humid days, the moisture content in the boards increases to 45%. Determine the dimensional change in the flooring parallel to the boards and perpendicular to the boards. What will happen to the floor? How can this problem be corrected? Solution: Perpendicular: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00353\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;maple}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,x_{0}[c(M_{f}-M_{i})]\,=\,6[0.00353(45\,-\,12)]\,=\,0.699 \;\mathrm{in.}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm{6}\;\mathrm{in.}\] Over a 60 ft span: \[\Delta x\,=\,\frac{(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})(0.699\;\mathrm{in.} )}{6\;\mathrm{in.}}\,=\,83.9\;\mathrm{in.}\] The floor will therefore buckle due to the large amount of expansion of the boards perpendicular to the flooring. Parallel: For most woods, only about a 0.2% change in dimensions occurs longitudinally. Thus the total change in the length of the boards will be about \[\Delta y\,=\,(0.002)(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})\,=\,1.44\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* A wall 30 feet long is built using radial-longitudinal cuts of 5-inch wide pine, with the boards arranged in a vertical fashion. The wood contains a moisture content of 55% when the wall is built; however the humidity level in the room is maintained to give 45% moisture in the wood. The average width of the gaps is: \[\mathrm{gap}\,=\,5.076\;\mathrm{in./71\;\mathrm{gaps}}\,=\,0.0715\;\mathrm{in.}\]

Volume of concrete \(=\,5.130\,+\,0.27\,=\,5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\)
In 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\)\(=\,270\text{ ft}^{3}\):
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&270\text{ ft}^{3}/5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\,=\,50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(160\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,11,\text{752 lb}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(170\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,21,\text{148 lb}\\ \text{water}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,2,\text{115 lb}\end{array}\]
But we must also adjust for the water present in the wet sand (3%) and wet aggregate (2%). For example, to find the amount of wet sand, we could either multiply the dry sand by 1.03 or divide by 0.97:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{wet sand}&=&11,\text{752 lb}/0.97\,=\,12,\text{115 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,363\text{ lb}\\ \text{wet aggregate}&=&21,\text{148 lb}/0.98\,=\,21,\text{580 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,432\text{ lb}\end{array}\]
Therefore, the ingredients for the concrete mix include:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&12,\text{115 lb}\,=\,6.06\text{ tons}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&21,\text{580 lb}\,=\,10.8\text{ tons}\\ \text{water}&=&2115\,-\,363\,-\,432\,=\,1320\text{ lb}\\ &=&(1320\text{ lb})(7.48\text{ gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}\,=\,158\text{ gal}\end{array}\]* 18-1 A current of 10 A is passed through a 1-mm-diameter wire 1000 m long. Calculate the power loss if the wire is made of (a) aluminum, (b) silicon, and (c) silicon carbide. (See Table 18-1). Solution: Power \(=I^{2}R=I^{2}\ell/\sigma A=(10\,A)^{2}(100,\!000\;\mathrm{cm})/(\pi/4)(0.1\; \mathrm{cm})^{2}\sigma\) Power \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/\sigma\) The electrical conductivity of each material is given in Table 18-1: 1. \(\mathrm{P_{Al}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/3.77\;\times\;10^{5}=3380\;\mathrm{watt}\) 2. \(\mathrm{P_{Si}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/5\;\times\;10^{-6}=2.546\;\times\;10^{14 }\;\mathrm{watt}\) 3. \(\mathrm{P_{SSC}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/10^{-1}\;\mathrm{to}\;10^{-2}\) \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{to}\;1.273\;\times\;10^{11}\;\mathrm{watt}\)

question: We plan to prepare 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\) of concrete using a 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is 0.45. The sand contains 3 wt% water, the coarse aggregate contains 2 wt% water, and 5% entrained air is expected. Determine the number of sacks of cement, tons of sand, and coarse aggregate, and gallons of water required.
answer:
The number of sacks of cement that must be ordered = 50 sacks. The tons of sand required = 6.06 tons. The tons of coarse aggregate required = 10.8 tons. The gallons of water needed = 158 gal.

context:
* 16--47 A U.S. quarter is 15/16 in. in diameter and is about 1/16 in. thick. Assuming copper costs about $1.10 per pound and nickel costs about $4.10 per pound. Compare the material cost in a composite quarter versus a quarter made entirely of nickel. Solution: In a quarter, the thickness (and hence the volume) ratio is 1/6 Ni: 2/3 Cu: 1/6 Ni. The volume fraction of each is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}f_{\rm Cu}&=&0.667&f_{\rm Ni}\;=\;0.333\\ \end{array}\] The volume of the quarter, as well as the copper and nickel, are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}V_{\rm quarter}&=&(\pi/4)(15/16\;{\rm in.})^{2}(1/16\;{ \rm in.})\;=\;0.04314\;{\rm in.}^{3}\;=\;0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ V_{\rm Cu}&=&(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(0.667)\;=\;0.4716\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ V_{\rm Ni}&=&(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(0.333)\;=\;0.2354\;{\rm cm}^{3}\\ \end{array}\] The weights of copper and nickel in the coin are: \[\begin{array}{lcl}W_{\rm Cu}&=&(0.4716\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.93\;{\rm g/cm}^{3}) \;=\;4.211\;{\rm g}\;=\;0.00928\;{\rm lb}\\ W_{\rm Ni}&=&(0.2354\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.902\;{\rm g/cm}^{3})\;=\;2.0955\;{\rm g} \;=\;0.004616\;{\rm lb}\\ \end{array}\] The cost of each material in the coin is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\$/{\rm Cu}&=&(0.00925\;{\rm lb})(\$1.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$ 0.0102\\ \$/{\rm Ni}&=&(0.004616\;{\rm lb})(\$4.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$0.0189\\ \end{array}\] The total cost of the composite (for materials only) \(=\$0.0291\) If the entire coin were made of nickel, then \[\begin{array}{lcl}(0.707\;{\rm cm}^{3})(8.902\;{\rm g/cm}^{3})(1/454\;{\rm g /lb})(\$4.10/{\rm lb})\;=\$0.0568\\ \end{array}\] By using the composite coin, the cost of the materials is about half that of a pure nickel coin, yet the coin appears to have the nickel (or silvery) color.
Calculate the density of a honeycomb structure composed of the following elements. The two 2-mm-thick cover sheets are produced using an epoxy matrix containing 55 vol% E-glass fibers. The aluminium honeycomb is 2 cm thick; the cells are in the shape of 0.5 cm squares and the walls of the cells are 0.1 mm thick. Estimate the density of the structure. Compare the weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb compared to a solid aluminum panel with the same dimensions.
\begin{tabular}{l l} Solution: & Each cell of aluminum can be considered to be a hollow square shape where the dimensions of the cell are 0.5 cm \(\times\) 0.5 cm \(\times\) 2 cm, with a wall thickness belonging uniquely to that cell of 0.1 mm\(/2=0.05\) mm \(=0.005\) cm. \\  & \(V_{\rm Al}=(4\) sides\()(0.005\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2\) cm\()=0.02\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The cover sheet dimensions that just cover the single cell described above are 0.5 cm \(\times\) 0.5 cm \(\times\) 2 mm \(=0.2\) cm. The volume is: \\  & \(V_{\rm cover}=(2\) sheets\()(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(0.2\) cm\()=0.1\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The total "height" of the cell, including the cover sheets, is 2 cm \(+\) 2(0.2 cm) \(=2.4\) cm. The total volume of the cell is: \\  & \(V_{\rm total}=(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2.4\) cm\()=0.6\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The volume fractions of these constituents are: \\  & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}=\,0.02/0.6\,=\,0.0333\) \\  & \(f_{\rm cover}=\,0.1/0.6\,=\,0.1667\) \\  & \(f_{\rm void}=\,0.80\) \\ \end{tabular}
The densities of the three constituents can be determined. The density of the aluminum in the cells is 2.699 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the density of the void space within the cells is zero. But the cover sheets are themselves composites:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm cover}=\) & \(f_{\rm glass}\,\rho_{\rm glass}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}parry}\,\rho_{\rm{e}parry}=(0.55)(2. 55\) g/cm\({}^{3})\) \\  & \(+\,(0.45)(1.25\) g/cm\({}^{3})=1.965\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
Therefore the overall density of the honeycomb structure is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,\rho_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}ver}\,\rho_{\rm{e} cover}\,+\,f_{\rm void}\,\rho_{\rm void}\) \\  & \(=\,(0.0333)(2.699)\,+\,(0.1667)(1.965)\,+\,(0.80)(0)\) \\  & \(=\,0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
The weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,20,\)016 g \\  & \(=\,20.016\) kg \(=\,44.1\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
If the panel were made of solid aluminum, with the same dimensions, the panel would weigh:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm solid}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(2.669\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,129,\)552 g \\  & \(=\,129.552\) kg \(=\,285\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
The weight savings using the honeycomb are enormous.
Construction Materials
* A sample of wood with dimensions 3 in. \(\times\) 4 in. \(\times\) 12 in. has a dry density of 0.35 g/cm\({}^{3}\). (a) Calculate the number of gallons of water that must be absorbed by the sample to contain 120% water. (b) Calculate the density after the wood absorbs this amount of water. Solution: \[V=3\ \times\ 4\ \times\ 12\ =\ 144\ \text{in.}^{3}=2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}\] \[\text{dry weight}=0.35\ \times\ 2359.7=825.9\ \text{g}\] \[\text{@120\% water}=\frac{\text{weight of water}}{\text{weight of dry wood}}\ \times\ 100\]
* water \[=(1.2)(825.9)=991\ \text{g}=2.183\ \text{lb}\] \[=(2.183\ \text{lb})(7.48\ \text{gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\ \text{lb/ft}^{3}=0.262\ \text{gal}\]
* If the volume remains the same, then \[\text{density}=\frac{825.9\ \text{g of dry wood}\ +\ 991\ \text{g of water}}{2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}}=0.77\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\]
* The density of a sample of oak is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\). Calculate (a) the density of completely dry oak and (b) the percent water in the original sample. Solution: \[\rho_{12\text{w water}}=0.68\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\quad(\text{Table\ 17--1})\]
* Therefore, in 100 cm\({}^{3}\) of wood at 12% H\({}_{2}\)O, there are 68 g. \[12\%\ \text{water}=\frac{\text{green weight}\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}=\frac{68\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}\times\ 100\] \[\text{dry weight}=68/1.12=60.71\ \text{g}\]
* When the density is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\), there are 90 g of green wood per 100 cm\({}^{3}\). The water is therefore 90 \(-\) 60.71 g, or 29.29 g. \[\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\,=\frac{90\;\mathrm{g}\;-\;60.71\;\mathrm{g}}{60.71\; \mathrm{g}}\times\,100\,=\,48.2\%\]
* Boards of map 1 in. thick, 6 in. wide, and 16 ft. long are used as the flooring for a 60 ft \(\times\) 60 ft hall. The boards were cut from logs with a tangential-longitudinal cut. The floor is laid when the boards have a moisture content of 12%. After some particularly humid days, the moisture content in the boards increases to 45%. Determine the dimensional change in the flooring parallel to the boards and perpendicular to the boards. What will happen to the floor? How can this problem be corrected? Solution: Perpendicular: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00353\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;maple}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,x_{0}[c(M_{f}-M_{i})]\,=\,6[0.00353(45\,-\,12)]\,=\,0.699 \;\mathrm{in.}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm{6}\;\mathrm{in.}\] Over a 60 ft span: \[\Delta x\,=\,\frac{(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})(0.699\;\mathrm{in.} )}{6\;\mathrm{in.}}\,=\,83.9\;\mathrm{in.}\] The floor will therefore buckle due to the large amount of expansion of the boards perpendicular to the flooring. Parallel: For most woods, only about a 0.2% change in dimensions occurs longitudinally. Thus the total change in the length of the boards will be about \[\Delta y\,=\,(0.002)(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})\,=\,1.44\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* A wall 30 feet long is built using radial-longitudinal cuts of 5-inch wide pine, with the boards arranged in a vertical fashion. The wood contains a moisture content of 55% when the wall is built; however the humidity level in the room is maintained to give 45% moisture in the wood. Determine the dimensional changes in the wood boards and estimate the size of the gaps that will be produced as a consequence of these changes. Solution: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00141\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;pine}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})[(0.00141\; \mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O})(45\,-\,55)]\] \[\qquad=\,-5.076\;\mathrm{in.}\] The total number of boards in the width of the wall is: \[\#\;\mathrm{of\;boards}\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})/5\;\mathrm{ in./board}\,=\,72\;\mathrm{boards}\] Therefore there are 71 gaps between the boards. The average width of the gaps is: \[\mathrm{gap}\,=\,5.076\;\mathrm{in./71\;\mathrm{gaps}}\,=\,0.0715\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* We have been asked to prepare 100 yd\({}^{3}\) of normal concrete using a volume ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate of 1 : 2 : 4. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is to be 0.5. The sand contains 6 wt% water and the coarse aggregate contains 3 wt% water. No entrained air is expected. (a) Determine the number of sacks of cement that must be ordered, the tons of sand and aggregate required, and the amount of water needed. (b) Calculate the total weight of the concrete per cubic yard. (c) What is the weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate?
Solution: First we can determine the volume of each material on a "sack" basis, keeping in mind the 1 : 2 : 4 volume ratio of solids and the 0.5 water-cement weight ratio:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{cement}&=&(1\mbox{ sack})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})/190\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(2)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(4)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(0.5)(94\mbox{ lb})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})&=&0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{total volume of materials/sack}&=&4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{In 100 yd}^{3},\mbox{ or }(100\mbox{ yd}^{3})(27\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{yd}^{3})\mbox{:}\\ \mbox{cement}&=&2700\mbox{ ft}^{3}/4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\,=\,640\mbox{ sacks}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(160\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&101,376\mbox{ lb}\,=\,50.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(170\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&215,424\mbox{ lb}\,=\,107.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\,=\,30,072\mbox{ lb}\quad\mbox{or}\\ &=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})\,=\,3,605\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
But we must make adjustments for the water that is already present in the sand and aggregate. There is 6% water in the sand and 3% water in the aggregate. We can either multiply the dry sand by 1.06, or divide the dry sand by 0.94, to obtain the amount of wet sand that we need to order.
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wet sand}&=&(101,376\mbox{ lb})(1.06)\,=\,107,459\mbox{ lb}\,=\,53.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in sand}&=&107,459\,-\,101,376\,=\,6083\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{wet aggregate}&=&(215,424\mbox{ lb})(1.03)\,=\,221,887\mbox{ lb}\,=\,110.9\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in aggregate}&=&221,887\,-\,215,424\,=\,6463\mbox{ lb}\end{array}\]
The actual amount of water that should be added to the concrete mix is:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{water}&=&30,072\,-\,6083\,-\,6463\,=\,17,526\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{gal water}&=&(17,526\mbox{ lb})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}\\ &=&2101\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
Therefore:
1. The ingredients of the concrete mix are: 640 sacks of cement 53.7 tons of sand 110.9 tons of aggregate 2101 gal of water 2. The total weight per yd\({}^{3}\) is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wt}/\mbox{yd}^{3}&=&\frac{(640\mbox{ sacks})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})\,+\,107,459\,+\,221,887\,+\,17,526}{100\mbox{ yd}^{3}}\\ &=&4070\mbox{ lb/yd}^{3}\end{array}\]3. The cement-sand-aggregate ratio, on a weight basis, is: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{ratio}&=&(640\text{ sacks})(94\text{ lb/sack})\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847 lb}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887 lb}\\ &=&60,\text{160}\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887}\\ &=&1\text{:}\,17\text{:}\,\text{9}\,\text{:}\,3.69\end{array}\]
* We plan to prepare 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\) of concrete using a 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is 0.45. The sand contains 3 wt% water, the coarse aggregate contains 2 wt% water, and 5% entrained air is expected. Determine the number of sacks of cement, tons of sand, and coarse aggregate, and gallons of water required. Solution: First, we can determine the volume of each material required, using the 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 ratio to determine the weights per sack of cement and dividing by the density to determine the volume. Per sack of cement: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement:}&94\text{ lb/sack}/190\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{sand:}&(2.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/160\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{aggregate:}&(4.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/170\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{water:}&(0.45)(94\text{ lb/sack})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ &\text{Volume per sack}&=&5.130\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\end{array}\]
But 5% of the concrete is expected to be entrained air. The volume of air "\(x\)" per sack of cement is:
\[x/(5.130\,+\,x)\,=\,0.05\quad\text{or}\quad x\,=\,0.27\text{ ft}^{3}\]
Therefore the total volume of concrete per sack is:
Volume of concrete \(=\,5.130\,+\,0.27\,=\,5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\)
In 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\)\(=\,270\text{ ft}^{3}\):
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&270\text{ ft}^{3}/5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\,=\,50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(160\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,11,\text{752 lb}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(170\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,21,\text{148 lb}\\ \text{water}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,2,\text{115 lb}\end{array}\]
But we must also adjust for the water present in the wet sand (3%) and wet aggregate (2%). For example, to find the amount of wet sand, we could either multiply the dry sand by 1.03 or divide by 0.97:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{wet sand}&=&11,\text{752 lb}/0.97\,=\,12,\text{115 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,363\text{ lb}\\ \text{wet aggregate}&=&21,\text{148 lb}/0.98\,=\,21,\text{580 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,432\text{ lb}\end{array}\]
Therefore, the ingredients for the concrete mix include:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&12,\text{115 lb}\,=\,6.06\text{ tons}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&21,\text{580 lb}\,=\,10.8\text{ tons}\\ \text{water}&=&2115\,-\,363\,-\,432\,=\,1320\text{ lb}\\ &=&(1320\text{ lb})(7.48\text{ gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}\,=\,158\text{ gal}\end{array}\]* 18-1 A current of 10 A is passed through a 1-mm-diameter wire 1000 m long. Calculate the power loss if the wire is made of (a) aluminum, (b) silicon, and (c) silicon carbide. (See Table 18-1). Solution: Power \(=I^{2}R=I^{2}\ell/\sigma A=(10\,A)^{2}(100,\!000\;\mathrm{cm})/(\pi/4)(0.1\; \mathrm{cm})^{2}\sigma\) Power \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/\sigma\) The electrical conductivity of each material is given in Table 18-1: 1. \(\mathrm{P_{Al}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/3.77\;\times\;10^{5}=3380\;\mathrm{watt}\) 2. \(\mathrm{P_{Si}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/5\;\times\;10^{-6}=2.546\;\times\;10^{14 }\;\mathrm{watt}\) 3. \(\mathrm{P_{SSC}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/10^{-1}\;\mathrm{to}\;10^{-2}\) \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{to}\;1.273\;\times\;10^{11}\;\mathrm{watt}\)

question: A current of 10 A is passed through a 1-mm-diameter wire 1000 m long. Calculate the power loss if the wire is made of (a) aluminum, (b) silicon, and (c) silicon carbide.
answer: (a) The power loss for aluminum wire = 3380 watt (b) The power loss for silicon wire = 2.546 x 10\(^{14}\) watt (c) The power loss for silicon carbide wire = 1.273 x 10\(^{10}\) to 1.273 x 10\(^{11}\) watt
