The total volume of the cell is: \\  & \(V_{\rm total}=(0.5\) cm\()(0.5\) cm\()(2.4\) cm\()=0.6\) cm\({}^{3}\) \\  & The volume fractions of these constituents are: \\  & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}=\,0.02/0.6\,=\,0.0333\) \\  & \(f_{\rm cover}=\,0.1/0.6\,=\,0.1667\) \\  & \(f_{\rm void}=\,0.80\) \\ \end{tabular}
The densities of the three constituents can be determined. The density of the aluminum in the cells is 2.699 g/cm\({}^{3}\) and the density of the void space within the cells is zero. But the cover sheets are themselves composites:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm cover}=\) & \(f_{\rm glass}\,\rho_{\rm glass}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}parry}\,\rho_{\rm{e}parry}=(0.55)(2. 55\) g/cm\({}^{3})\) \\  & \(+\,(0.45)(1.25\) g/cm\({}^{3})=1.965\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
Therefore the overall density of the honeycomb structure is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(\rho_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \(f_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,\rho_{\rm Al\,in\,Cell}\,+\,f_{\rm{e}ver}\,\rho_{\rm{e} cover}\,+\,f_{\rm void}\,\rho_{\rm void}\) \\  & \(=\,(0.0333)(2.699)\,+\,(0.1667)(1.965)\,+\,(0.80)(0)\) \\  & \(=\,0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3}\) \\ \end{tabular}
The weight of a 1 m \(\times\) 2 m panel of the honeycomb is:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm honeycomb}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(0.417\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,20,\)016 g \\  & \(=\,20.016\) kg \(=\,44.1\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
If the panel were made of solid aluminum, with the same dimensions, the panel would weigh:
\begin{tabular}{l l} \(W_{\rm solid}=\) & \((2.4\) cm\()(100\) cm\()(200\) cm\()(2.669\) g/cm\({}^{3})=\,129,\)552 g \\  & \(=\,129.552\) kg \(=\,285\) lb \\ \end{tabular}
The weight savings using the honeycomb are enormous.
Construction Materials
* A sample of wood with dimensions 3 in. \(\times\) 4 in. \(\times\) 12 in. has a dry density of 0.35 g/cm\({}^{3}\). (a) Calculate the number of gallons of water that must be absorbed by the sample to contain 120% water. (b) Calculate the density after the wood absorbs this amount of water. Solution: \[V=3\ \times\ 4\ \times\ 12\ =\ 144\ \text{in.}^{3}=2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}\] \[\text{dry weight}=0.35\ \times\ 2359.7=825.9\ \text{g}\] \[\text{@120\% water}=\frac{\text{weight of water}}{\text{weight of dry wood}}\ \times\ 100\]
* water \[=(1.2)(825.9)=991\ \text{g}=2.183\ \text{lb}\] \[=(2.183\ \text{lb})(7.48\ \text{gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\ \text{lb/ft}^{3}=0.262\ \text{gal}\]
* If the volume remains the same, then \[\text{density}=\frac{825.9\ \text{g of dry wood}\ +\ 991\ \text{g of water}}{2359.7\ \text{cm}^{3}}=0.77\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\]
* The density of a sample of oak is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\). Calculate (a) the density of completely dry oak and (b) the percent water in the original sample. Solution: \[\rho_{12\text{w water}}=0.68\ \text{g/cm}^{3}\quad(\text{Table\ 17--1})\]
* Therefore, in 100 cm\({}^{3}\) of wood at 12% H\({}_{2}\)O, there are 68 g. \[12\%\ \text{water}=\frac{\text{green weight}\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}=\frac{68\ -\ \text{dry weight}}{\text{dry weight}}\times\ 100\] \[\text{dry weight}=68/1.12=60.71\ \text{g}\]
* When the density is 0.90 g/cm\({}^{3}\), there are 90 g of green wood per 100 cm\({}^{3}\). The water is therefore 90 \(-\) 60.71 g, or 29.29 g. \[\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\,=\frac{90\;\mathrm{g}\;-\;60.71\;\mathrm{g}}{60.71\; \mathrm{g}}\times\,100\,=\,48.2\%\]
* Boards of map 1 in. thick, 6 in. wide, and 16 ft. long are used as the flooring for a 60 ft \(\times\) 60 ft hall. The boards were cut from logs with a tangential-longitudinal cut. The floor is laid when the boards have a moisture content of 12%. After some particularly humid days, the moisture content in the boards increases to 45%. Determine the dimensional change in the flooring parallel to the boards and perpendicular to the boards. What will happen to the floor? How can this problem be corrected? Solution: Perpendicular: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00353\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;maple}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,x_{0}[c(M_{f}-M_{i})]\,=\,6[0.00353(45\,-\,12)]\,=\,0.699 \;\mathrm{in.}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm{6}\;\mathrm{in.}\] Over a 60 ft span: \[\Delta x\,=\,\frac{(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})(0.699\;\mathrm{in.} )}{6\;\mathrm{in.}}\,=\,83.9\;\mathrm{in.}\] The floor will therefore buckle due to the large amount of expansion of the boards perpendicular to the flooring. Parallel: For most woods, only about a 0.2% change in dimensions occurs longitudinally. Thus the total change in the length of the boards will be about \[\Delta y\,=\,(0.002)(60\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})\,=\,1.44\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* A wall 30 feet long is built using radial-longitudinal cuts of 5-inch wide pine, with the boards arranged in a vertical fashion. The wood contains a moisture content of 55% when the wall is built; however the humidity level in the room is maintained to give 45% moisture in the wood. Determine the dimensional changes in the wood boards and estimate the size of the gaps that will be produced as a consequence of these changes. Solution: \[\mathrm{c_{tangential}}\,=\,0.00141\;\mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\% \,\mathrm{H_{2}O}\;\mathrm{for\;pine}\] \[\Delta x\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})[(0.00141\; \mathrm{in./in.}\cdot\,\%\,\mathrm{H_{2}O})(45\,-\,55)]\] \[\qquad=\,-5.076\;\mathrm{in.}\] The total number of boards in the width of the wall is: \[\#\;\mathrm{of\;boards}\,=\,(30\;\mathrm{ft})(12\;\mathrm{in./ft})/5\;\mathrm{ in./board}\,=\,72\;\mathrm{boards}\] Therefore there are 71 gaps between the boards. The average width of the gaps is: \[\mathrm{gap}\,=\,5.076\;\mathrm{in./71\;\mathrm{gaps}}\,=\,0.0715\;\mathrm{in.}\]
* We have been asked to prepare 100 yd\({}^{3}\) of normal concrete using a volume ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate of 1 : 2 : 4. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is to be 0.5. The sand contains 6 wt% water and the coarse aggregate contains 3 wt% water. No entrained air is expected. (a) Determine the number of sacks of cement that must be ordered, the tons of sand and aggregate required, and the amount of water needed. (b) Calculate the total weight of the concrete per cubic yard. (c) What is the weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate?
Solution: First we can determine the volume of each material on a "sack" basis, keeping in mind the 1 : 2 : 4 volume ratio of solids and the 0.5 water-cement weight ratio:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{cement}&=&(1\mbox{ sack})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})/190\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(2)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(4)(0.495\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})&=&1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(0.5)(94\mbox{ lb})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})&=&0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{total volume of materials/sack}&=&4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\\ \mbox{In 100 yd}^{3},\mbox{ or }(100\mbox{ yd}^{3})(27\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{yd}^{3})\mbox{:}\\ \mbox{cement}&=&2700\mbox{ ft}^{3}/4.218\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack}\,=\,640\mbox{ sacks}\\ \mbox{sand}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.990\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(160\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&101,376\mbox{ lb}\,=\,50.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{aggregate}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(1.980\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(170\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\\ &=&215,424\mbox{ lb}\,=\,107.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water}&=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3})\,=\,30,072\mbox{ lb}\quad\mbox{or}\\ &=&(640\mbox{ sacks})(0.753\mbox{ ft}^{3}/\mbox{sack})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})\,=\,3,605\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
But we must make adjustments for the water that is already present in the sand and aggregate. There is 6% water in the sand and 3% water in the aggregate. We can either multiply the dry sand by 1.06, or divide the dry sand by 0.94, to obtain the amount of wet sand that we need to order.
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wet sand}&=&(101,376\mbox{ lb})(1.06)\,=\,107,459\mbox{ lb}\,=\,53.7\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in sand}&=&107,459\,-\,101,376\,=\,6083\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{wet aggregate}&=&(215,424\mbox{ lb})(1.03)\,=\,221,887\mbox{ lb}\,=\,110.9\mbox{ tons}\\ \mbox{water in aggregate}&=&221,887\,-\,215,424\,=\,6463\mbox{ lb}\end{array}\]
The actual amount of water that should be added to the concrete mix is:
\[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{water}&=&30,072\,-\,6083\,-\,6463\,=\,17,526\mbox{ lb}\\ \mbox{gal water}&=&(17,526\mbox{ lb})(7.48\mbox{ gal}/\mbox{ft}^{3})/62.4\mbox{ lb/ft}^{3}\\ &=&2101\mbox{ gal}\end{array}\]
Therefore:
1. The ingredients of the concrete mix are: 640 sacks of cement 53.7 tons of sand 110.9 tons of aggregate 2101 gal of water 2. The total weight per yd\({}^{3}\) is: \[\begin{array}{lcl}\mbox{wt}/\mbox{yd}^{3}&=&\frac{(640\mbox{ sacks})(94\mbox{ lb/sack})\,+\,107,459\,+\,221,887\,+\,17,526}{100\mbox{ yd}^{3}}\\ &=&4070\mbox{ lb/yd}^{3}\end{array}\]3. The cement-sand-aggregate ratio, on a weight basis, is: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{ratio}&=&(640\text{ sacks})(94\text{ lb/sack})\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847 lb}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887 lb}\\ &=&60,\text{160}\,\text{:}\,107,\text{847}\,\text{:}\,221,\text{887}\\ &=&1\text{:}\,17\text{:}\,\text{9}\,\text{:}\,3.69\end{array}\]
* We plan to prepare 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\) of concrete using a 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 weight ratio of cement-sand-coarse aggregate. The water-cement ratio (by weight) is 0.45. The sand contains 3 wt% water, the coarse aggregate contains 2 wt% water, and 5% entrained air is expected. Determine the number of sacks of cement, tons of sand, and coarse aggregate, and gallons of water required. Solution: First, we can determine the volume of each material required, using the 1 : 2.5 : 4.5 ratio to determine the weights per sack of cement and dividing by the density to determine the volume. Per sack of cement: \[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement:}&94\text{ lb/sack}/190\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.495\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{sand:}&(2.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/160\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{aggregate:}&(4.5)(94\text{ lb/sack})/170\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ \text{water:}&(0.45)(94\text{ lb/sack})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}&=&0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\\ &\text{Volume per sack}&=&5.130\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\end{array}\]
But 5% of the concrete is expected to be entrained air. The volume of air "\(x\)" per sack of cement is:
\[x/(5.130\,+\,x)\,=\,0.05\quad\text{or}\quad x\,=\,0.27\text{ ft}^{3}\]
Therefore the total volume of concrete per sack is:
Volume of concrete \(=\,5.130\,+\,0.27\,=\,5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\)
In 10 \(\text{yd}^{3}\)\(=\,270\text{ ft}^{3}\):
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&270\text{ ft}^{3}/5.400\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack}\,=\,50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(1.469\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(160\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,11,\text{752 lb}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(2.488\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(170\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,21,\text{148 lb}\\ \text{water}&=&(50\text{ sacks})(0.678\text{ ft}^{3}/\text{sack})(62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3})\,\,=\,2,\text{115 lb}\end{array}\]
But we must also adjust for the water present in the wet sand (3%) and wet aggregate (2%). For example, to find the amount of wet sand, we could either multiply the dry sand by 1.03 or divide by 0.97:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{wet sand}&=&11,\text{752 lb}/0.97\,=\,12,\text{115 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,363\text{ lb}\\ \text{wet aggregate}&=&21,\text{148 lb}/0.98\,=\,21,\text{580 lb};\quad\text{H}_{2}\text{O}\,=\,432\text{ lb}\end{array}\]
Therefore, the ingredients for the concrete mix include:
\[\begin{array}{rl}\text{cement}&=&50\text{ sacks}\\ \text{sand}&=&12,\text{115 lb}\,=\,6.06\text{ tons}\\ \text{aggregate}&=&21,\text{580 lb}\,=\,10.8\text{ tons}\\ \text{water}&=&2115\,-\,363\,-\,432\,=\,1320\text{ lb}\\ &=&(1320\text{ lb})(7.48\text{ gal/ft}^{3})/62.4\text{ lb/ft}^{3}\,=\,158\text{ gal}\end{array}\]* 18-1 A current of 10 A is passed through a 1-mm-diameter wire 1000 m long. Calculate the power loss if the wire is made of (a) aluminum, (b) silicon, and (c) silicon carbide. (See Table 18-1). Solution: Power \(=I^{2}R=I^{2}\ell/\sigma A=(10\,A)^{2}(100,\!000\;\mathrm{cm})/(\pi/4)(0.1\; \mathrm{cm})^{2}\sigma\) Power \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/\sigma\) The electrical conductivity of each material is given in Table 18-1: 1. \(\mathrm{P_{Al}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/3.77\;\times\;10^{5}=3380\;\mathrm{watt}\) 2. \(\mathrm{P_{Si}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/5\;\times\;10^{-6}=2.546\;\times\;10^{14 }\;\mathrm{watt}\) 3. \(\mathrm{P_{SSC}}=1.273\;\times\;10^{9}/10^{-1}\;\mathrm{to}\;10^{-2}\) \(=1.273\;\times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{to}\;1.273\;\times\;10^{11}\;\mathrm{watt}\)

question: What is the maximum length of the 2-mm-diameter copper wire if the power lost needs to be less than 250 W when a 5-A current is flowing through it?
context: * 18-4 The power lost in a 2-mm-diameter copper wire is to be less than 250 W when a 5-A current is flowing in the circuit. What is the maximum length of the wire? Solution: \(P=I^{2}R=I^{2}\ell/\sigma A=250\;\mathrm{W}\) \(\ell=250\,\sigma A/I^{2}=(250)(5.98\;\times\;10^{5})(\pi/4)(0.2)^{2}/(5)^{2}\) \(=1.88\;\times\;10^{5}\;\mathrm{cm}=1.88\;\mathrm{km}\)

question: A current density of 100,000 A/cm\({}^{2}\) is applied to a gold wire 50 m in length. The resistance of the wire is found to be 2 ohm. Calculate the diameter of the wire and the voltage applied to the wire.
answer:
The diameter of the wire is 0.0865 cm and the voltage applied to the wire is 1174 V.

context:
* 18-5 A current density of 100,000 A/cm\({}^{2}\) is applied to a gold wire 50 m in length. The resistance of the wire is found to be 2 ohm. Calculate the diameter of the wire and the voltage applied to the wire. Solution: \(J=I/A=\sigma V/\ell=100,\!000\;\mathrm{A/cm}^{2}\) \(V=100,\!000\;\ell/\sigma=(100,\!000)(5000\;\mathrm{cm})/4.26\;\times\;10^{5}=1 174\;\mathrm{V}\)From Ohm's law, \(I=V/R=1174/2=587\) A
\[A=I/J=587/100,000=0.00587\;{\rm cm}^{2}\] \[(\pi/4)d^{2}=0.00587\quad{\rm or}\quad d^{2}=0.00747\quad{\rm or} \quad d=0.0865\;{\rm cm}\]
* We would like to produce a 5000-ohm resistor from boron-carbide fibers having a diameter of 0.1 mm. What is the required length of the fibers? Solution: The electrical conductivity is 1 to 2 \({\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\). \[R=\ell/\sigma A=5000\;{\rm ohm}\] \[{\rm If\ the\ conductivity\ is\ 1\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}}\] \[\ell=R\sigma A=(5000)(1\;{\rm ohm\ cm})(\pi/4)(0.01\;{\rm cm})^{2}=0. 393\;{\rm cm}\] \[{\rm If\ the\ conductivity\ is\ 2\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}}\] \[\ell=R\sigma A=(5000)(2\;{\rm ohm\ cm})(\pi/4)(0.01\;{\rm cm})^{2}=0. 785\;{\rm cm}\] The fibers should be 0.393 to 0.785 cm in length.
* Suppose we estimate that the mobility of electrons in silver is 75 \({\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm V}\cdot{\rm s}\). Estimate the fraction of the valence electrons that are carrying an electrical charge. Solution: The total number of valence electrons is: \[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(4\;{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(1\;{\rm electron}/{\rm atom})}{ \big{(}4.0862\,\times\,10^{-8}\;{\rm cm}\big{)}^{3}}=5.86\,\times\,10^{22}\] The number of charge carriers is: \[n=\sigma/q\mu=(6.80\,\times\,10^{5})/(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19})(75)=5. 67\,\times\,10^{22}\] The fraction of the electrons that carry the electrical charge is: \[n/n_{\rm T}=5.67\,\times\,10^{22}/5.86\,\times\,10^{22}=0.968\]
* A current density of 5000 A/cm\({}^{2}\) is applied to a magnesium wire. If half of the valence electrons serve as charge carriers, calculate the average drift velocity of the electrons. Solution: The total number of valence electrons is: \[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(2\;{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(2\;{\rm electrons}/{\rm atom})}{(3.2087\,\times\,10^{-8})^{2}(5.209\,\times\,10^{-8}){\rm cos}\;30}=8.61\,\times\,1 0^{22}\] The actual number of charge carriers is then 4.305 \(\times\,10^{22}\). \[\vec{v}=J/nq=(5000\;{\rm A}/{\rm cm}^{2})/(4.305\,\times\,10^{22})(1.6\,\times \,10^{-19})\] \[=0.7259\;{\rm cm}/{\rm s}\]
* We apply a voltage of 10 V to an aluminum wire 2 mm in diameter and 20 m long. If 10% of the valence electrons carry the electrical charge, calculate the average drift velocity of the electrons in km/h and miles/h. Solution: The total number of valence electrons is: \[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(4\;{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(1\;{\rm electron}/{\rm atom})}{ \big{(}4.0862\,\times\,10^{-8}\;{\rm cm}\big{)}^{3}}=5.86\,\times\,10^{22}\] The number of charge carriers is: \[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(4\;{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(1\;{\rm electron}/{\rm atom})}{ \big{(}4.
\[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(4\ {\rm atoms/cell})(3\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(4.04958\ {\rm\times 10^{-8}\,cm})^{3}}= 1.81\ {\rm\times 10^{23}/cm^{3}}\]
The number of electrons carrying the electrical charge is one-tenth of the total number, or 1.81 \({\rm\times 10^{22}\ {\rm electrons/cm}^{3}}\). The electric field is
\[\xi=V/\ell=10\ {\rm V/}2000\ {\rm cm}=0.005\ {\rm V/cm}\]
\[\sigma\xi=nq\overline{v}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \overline{v}=\sigma\xi/nq\]
\[\overline{v}=(3.77\ {\rm\times 10^{5}})(0.005)/(1.81\ {\rm\times 10^{22}})(1.6\ {\rm\times 10^{-19}})=0.651\ {\rm cm/s}\]
\[\overline{v}=(0.651\ {\rm cm/s})(3600\ {\rm s/h})/10^{5}\ {\rm cm/km})=0.0234\ {\rm km/h}\]
\[\overline{v}=(0.651\ {\rm cm/s})(3600\ {\rm s/h})(1\ {\rm in./2.54\ {\rm cm }})(1\ {\rm ft/12\ in.})(1\ {\rm mile/5280\ ft})\]
\[=0.0146\ {\rm miles/h}\]

question: We would like to produce a 5000-ohm resistor from boron-carbide fibers having a diameter of 0.1 mm. What is the required length of the fibers?
answer:
The required length of the fibers is 0.393 to 0.785 cm.

* 18-5 A current density of 100,000 A/cm\({}^{2}\) is applied to a gold wire 50 m in length. The resistance of the wire is found to be 2 ohm. Calculate the diameter of the wire and the voltage applied to the wire. Solution: \(J=I/A=\sigma V/\ell=100,\!000\;\mathrm{A/cm}^{2}\) \(V=100,\!000\;\ell/\sigma=(100,\!000)(5000\;\mathrm{cm})/4.26\;\times\;10^{5}=1 174\;\mathrm{V}\)From Ohm's law, \(I=V/R=1174/2=587\) A
\[A=I/J=587/100,000=0.00587\;{\rm cm}^{2}\] \[(\pi/4)d^{2}=0.00587\quad{\rm or}\quad d^{2}=0.00747\quad{\rm or} \quad d=0.0865\;{\rm cm}\]
* We would like to produce a 5000-ohm resistor from boron-carbide fibers having a diameter of 0.1 mm. What is the required length of the fibers? Solution: The electrical conductivity is 1 to 2 \({\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\). \[R=\ell/\sigma A=5000\;{\rm ohm}\] \[{\rm If\ the\ conductivity\ is\ 1\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}}\] \[\ell=R\sigma A=(5000)(1\;{\rm ohm\ cm})(\pi/4)(0.01\;{\rm cm})^{2}=0. 393\;{\rm cm}\] \[{\rm If\ the\ conductivity\ is\ 2\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}}\] \[\ell=R\sigma A=(5000)(2\;{\rm ohm\ cm})(\pi/4)(0.01\;{\rm cm})^{2}=0. 785\;{\rm cm}\] The fibers should be 0.393 to 0.785 cm in length.
* Suppose we estimate that the mobility of electrons in silver is 75 \({\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm V}\cdot{\rm s}\). Estimate the fraction of the valence electrons that are carrying an electrical charge. Solution: The total number of valence electrons is: \[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(4\;{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(1\;{\rm electron}/{\rm atom})}{ \big{(}4.0862\,\times\,10^{-8}\;{\rm cm}\big{)}^{3}}=5.86\,\times\,10^{22}\] The number of charge carriers is: \[n=\sigma/q\mu=(6.80\,\times\,10^{5})/(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19})(75)=5. 67\,\times\,10^{22}\] The fraction of the electrons that carry the electrical charge is: \[n/n_{\rm T}=5.67\,\times\,10^{22}/5.86\,\times\,10^{22}=0.968\]
* A current density of 5000 A/cm\({}^{2}\) is applied to a magnesium wire. If half of the valence electrons serve as charge carriers, calculate the average drift velocity of the electrons. Solution: The total number of valence electrons is: \[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(2\;{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(2\;{\rm electrons}/{\rm atom})}{(3.2087\,\times\,10^{-8})^{2}(5.209\,\times\,10^{-8}){\rm cos}\;30}=8.61\,\times\,1 0^{22}\] The actual number of charge carriers is then 4.305 \(\times\,10^{22}\). \[\vec{v}=J/nq=(5000\;{\rm A}/{\rm cm}^{2})/(4.305\,\times\,10^{22})(1.6\,\times \,10^{-19})\] \[=0.7259\;{\rm cm}/{\rm s}\]
* We apply a voltage of 10 V to an aluminum wire 2 mm in diameter and 20 m long. If 10% of the valence electrons carry the electrical charge, calculate the average drift velocity of the electrons in km/h and miles/h. Solution: The total number of valence electrons is: \[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(4\;{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(1\;{\rm electron}/{\rm atom})}{ \big{(}4.0862\,\times\,10^{-8}\;{\rm cm}\big{)}^{3}}=5.86\,\times\,10^{22}\] The number of charge carriers is: \[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(4\;{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(1\;{\rm electron}/{\rm atom})}{ \big{(}4.
\[n_{\rm T}=\frac{(4\ {\rm atoms/cell})(3\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(4.04958\ {\rm\times 10^{-8}\,cm})^{3}}= 1.81\ {\rm\times 10^{23}/cm^{3}}\]
The number of electrons carrying the electrical charge is one-tenth of the total number, or 1.81 \({\rm\times 10^{22}\ {\rm electrons/cm}^{3}}\). The electric field is
\[\xi=V/\ell=10\ {\rm V/}2000\ {\rm cm}=0.005\ {\rm V/cm}\]
\[\sigma\xi=nq\overline{v}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \overline{v}=\sigma\xi/nq\]
\[\overline{v}=(3.77\ {\rm\times 10^{5}})(0.005)/(1.81\ {\rm\times 10^{22}})(1.6\ {\rm\times 10^{-19}})=0.651\ {\rm cm/s}\]
\[\overline{v}=(0.651\ {\rm cm/s})(3600\ {\rm s/h})/10^{5}\ {\rm cm/km})=0.0234\ {\rm km/h}\]
\[\overline{v}=(0.651\ {\rm cm/s})(3600\ {\rm s/h})(1\ {\rm in./2.54\ {\rm cm }})(1\ {\rm ft/12\ in.})(1\ {\rm mile/5280\ ft})\]
\[=0.0146\ {\rm miles/h}\]

question: What is the current density in the arc during welding?
context:
**18-10**: In a welding process, a current of 400 A flows through the arc when the voltage is 35 V. The length of the arc is about 0.1 in. and the average diameter of the arc is about 0.18 in. Calculate the current density in the arc, the electric field across the arc, and the electrical conductivity of the hot gases in the arc during welding.
Solution: \[R=V/I=35\ {\rm V/400\ A}=0.0875\ {\rm ohm}\]
The electrical conductivity of the gases in the arc is:
\[\sigma=\ell/RA=\frac{(0.1\ {\rm in.})(2.54\ {\rm cm/in.})}{(0.0875\ {\rm ohm})(\pi/4)(0.18\ {\rm in. \times\ 2.54\ {\rm cm/in.}})^{2}}\]
\[=17.68\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\ {\rm cm}^{-1}\]
The current density \(J\) is:
\[J=I/A=400\ {\rm A/(\pi/4)(0.18\ {\rm in. \times\ 2.54\ {\rm cm/in.}})^{2}}=2436\ {\rm A/cm}^{2}\]
The electric field is:
\[\xi=V/\ell=35\ {\rm V/(0.18\ {\rm in.})(2.54\ {\rm cm/in.})}=76.6\ {\rm V/cm}\]

question: Calculate the electrical conductivity of nickel at \(-50^{\circ}\)C and at \(+500^{\circ}\)C.
answer: At \(+500^{\circ}\)C, the electrical conductivity of nickel is \(0.34\ {\rm\times\ 10^{5}\,ohm^{-1}\cdot cm ^{-1}}\) and at \(-50^{\circ}\)C, it is \(3.03\ {\rm\times\ 10^{5}\,ohm^{-1} \cdot cm^{-1}}\).

question: The electrical resistivity of pure chromium is found to be 18 \({\rm\times\ 10^{-6}\,ohm\cdot cm}\). Estimate the temperature at which the resistivity measurement was made.
answer: The temperature at which the resistivity measurement was made is \(156.8^{\circ}C\).
context:
**18-13**: The electrical resistivity of pure chromium is found to be 18 \({\rm\times\ 10^{-6}\,ohm\cdot cm}\). Estimate the temperature at which the resistivity measurement was made.
Solution: \[\rho_{\rm room}=12.9\ {\rm\times\ 10^{-6}\,ohm\cdot cm}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ {\rm a =\ 0.0030\ {\rm ohm\cdot cm/^{\circ}C}}\]
\[18\ {\rm\times\ 10^{-6}}=(12.9\ {\rm\times\ 10^{-6}})[1\ +(0.0030)(T\ -\ 25)]\]
\[1.395\ -\ 1 =(0.003)(T\ -\ 25)\]
\[T=156.8^{\circ}C\]

The electrical resistivity of a beryllium alloy containing 5 at% of an alloying element is found to be 50 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-6}\)ohm \(\cdot\) cm at 400\({}^{\circ}\)C. Determine the contributions to resistivity due to temperature and due to impurities by finding the expected resistivity of pure beryllium at 400\({}^{\circ}\)C, the resistivity due to impurities, and the defect resistivity coefficient. What would be the electrical resistivity if the beryllium contained 10 at% of the alloying element at 200\({}^{\circ}\)C? Solution: From the data in Table 18-3, the resistivity at 400\({}^{\circ}\)C should be: \(\rho_{\tau}=(4\,\times\,10^{-6})[1\,+\,(0.025)(400\,-\,25)]=41.5\,\times\,10^{-6}\) Consequently the resistance due to impurities is: \(\rho\,=\,\rho_{\tau}\,+\,\rho_{d}\) \(50\,\times\,10^{-6}\,=\,41.5\,\times\,10^{-6}\,+\,\rho_{d}\) \(\rho_{d}\) \(=\,8.5\,\times\,10^{-6}\,\)ohm \(\cdot\) cm Since there are 5 at% impurities present, \(x=0.05\), and the defect resistivity coefficient is: \(\rho_{d}=\) bx(1\,-\,x) or \(b\,=\,\rho_{d}/x(1\,-\,x)\) \(b\,=\,8.5\,\times\,10^{-6}/(0.05)(1\,-\,0.05)=178.9\,\times\,10^{-6}\,\)ohm \(\cdot\) cm The resistivity at 200\({}^{\circ}\)C in an alloy containing 10 at% impurities is: \(\rho_{200}\,=\,\rho_{\tau}\,+\,\rho_{d}\) \(=\,(4\,\times\,10^{-6})[1\,+\,(0.025)(200\,-\,25)]\,+\,178.9\) \(\times\,10^{-6}(0.1)(1\,-\,0.1)\) \(=\,21.5\,\times\,10^{-6}\,+\,16.1\,\times\,10^{-6}\,=\,37.6\,\times\,10^{-6}\, \,\)ohm \(\cdot\) cm

question: Is Equation 18-7 valid for the copper-zinc system? If so, calculate the defect resistivity coefficient for zinc in copper.
context:
**18-17**: Is Equation 18-7 valid for the copper-zinc system? If so, calculate the defect resistivity coefficient for zinc in copper. (See Figure 18-11.) Solution: The conductivity and resistivity of pure copper are: \(\sigma=\) 5.98 \(\times\) 10\({}^{5}\) or \(\rho\,=\,1/\sigma\,=\,0.167\,\times\,10^{-5}\,\)ohm \(\cdot\) cm For 10 wt% Zn in copper: \(x_{\rm Zn}=\frac{(10/65.38)}{(10/65.38)\,+\,(90/63.54)}=\,0.0975\) \(x_{\rm Zn}(1\,-\,x_{\rm Zn})=(0.0975)(1\,-\,0.0975)=\,0.088\) From Figure 18-11(a), the conductivity of the Cu-10% Zn alloy at zero deformation is about 44% that of pure copper, or \(\sigma=(5.98\,\times\,10^{5})(0.44)\,=\,2.63\,\times\,10^{5}\) \(\rho\,=\,1/\sigma\,=\,0.38\,\times\,10^{-5}\) \(\Delta\rho\,=\,0.38\,\times\,10^{-5}\,-\,0.167\,\times\,10^{-5}=\,0.213\,\times\,10 ^{-5}\)* [18] \(\rm{GaV_{3}}\) is to operate as a superconductor in liquid helium (at 4 K). The \(T_{c}\) is 16.8 K and \(H_{o}\) is 350,000 oersted. What is the maximum magnetic field that can be applied to the material? Solution: \(T_{c}\) = 16.8 K \(H_{o}\) = 350,000 oersted \(H_{c}\) = \(H_{o}[\,1\,-\,(T/T_{c})^{2}]\) = 350,000[\(\,1\,-\,(4/16.8)^{2}]\) = 330,159 oersted \(\rm{Nb_{3}Sn}\) and \(\rm{GaV_{3}}\) are candidates for a superconductive application when the magnetic field is 150,000 oersted. Which would require the lower temperature in order to be superconductive? Solution: 150,000 = \(H_{o}[\,1\,-\,(T/T_{c})^{2}]\) For \(\rm{Nb_{3}Sn}\): 150,000 = 250,000[\(\,1\,-\,(T/18.05)^{2}]\) \(T\) = 11.42 K \(\rm{For}\) GaV\({}_{3}\): 150,000 = 350,000[\(\,1\,-\,(T/16.8)^{2}]\) \(T\) = 12.7 K
* [18] \(\rm{A}\) filament of \(\rm{Nb_{3}Sn}\) 0.05 mm in diameter operates in a magnetic field of 1000 oersted at 4 K. What is the maximum current that can be applied to the filament in order for the material to behave as a superconductor? Solution: From Figure 18-12, the maximum current density for \(\rm{Nb_{3}Sn}\) in a field of 1000 oersted is about 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) A/cm\({}^{2}\). \(I\) = \(JA\) = (2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) A/cm\({}^{2}\))(\(\pi\)/4)(0.005 cm)\({}^{2}\) = 39.3 A * 18-22 Assume that most of the electrical charge transferred in MgO is caused by the diffusion of Mg\({}^{2+}\) ions. Determine the mobility and electrical conductivity of MgO at 25\({}^{\circ}\)C and at 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C. (See Table 5-1.) Solution: At 25\({}^{\circ}\)C = 298 K: \[D_{\rm Mg} = 0.249\ {\rm exp}[\,-\,\)79,000/(1.987)(25 \(\,+\,\)273)]\] \[= 2.84\ \times\ 10^{-57}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm s}\] \[\mu = \frac{ZqD}{{\rm k}T}=\frac{(2)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(2.84\ \times\ 10^{-59})}{(1.38\ \times\ 10^{-23})(298)}\] \[= 2.21\ \times\ 10^{-59}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm V}\ {\rm s}\] We can determine that the lattice parameter for MgO is 3.96 A (since \(a_{\rm o}\ \times\ 2r_{\rm Mg}+\ 2r_{\rm O}\)). There are four Mg ions per unit cell, so the number of Mg ions per cm\({}^{3}\) is: \[n = (4)/(3.96\ \times\ 10^{-8})^{3}\ =\ 6.44\ \times\ 10^{22}/{\rm cm}^{3}\] \[\sigma = nZq\mu=(6.44\ \times\ 10^{22})(2)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(2.21\ \times\ 10^{-57})\] \[= 45.5\ \times\ 10^{-54}\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\ {\rm cm}^{-1}\] At 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C = 1773 K: \[D_{\rm Mg} = 0.249\ {\rm exp}[\,-\,\)79,000/(1.987)(1500\ +\ 273)]\] \[= 4.54\ \times\ 10^{-11}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm s}\] \[\mu = \frac{(2)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(4.54\ \times\ 10^{-11})}{(1.38\ \times\ 10^{-23})(1773)}=5.94\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm V}\ {\rm s}\] \[n = (4)/(3.96\ \times\ 10^{-8})^{3}\ =\ 6.44\ \times\ 10^{22}/{\rm cm}^{3}\] \[\sigma = (6.44\ \times\ 10^{22})(2)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(5.94\ \times\ 10^{-10})\] \[= 1.22\ \times\ 10^{-5}\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\ {\rm cm}^{-1}\] Conductivity increases about fifty orders of magnitude when the temperature increases to 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C.

Solution: 150,000 = \(H_{o}[\,1\,-\,(T/T_{c})^{2}]\) For \(\rm{Nb_{3}Sn}\): 150,000 = 250,000[\(\,1\,-\,(T/18.05)^{2}]\) \(T\) = 11.42 K \(\rm{For}\) GaV\({}_{3}\): 150,000 = 350,000[\(\,1\,-\,(T/16.8)^{2}]\) \(T\) = 12.7 K
* [18] \(\rm{A}\) filament of \(\rm{Nb_{3}Sn}\) 0.05 mm in diameter operates in a magnetic field of 1000 oersted at 4 K. What is the maximum current that can be applied to the filament in order for the material to behave as a superconductor? Solution: From Figure 18-12, the maximum current density for \(\rm{Nb_{3}Sn}\) in a field of 1000 oersted is about 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) A/cm\({}^{2}\). \(I\) = \(JA\) = (2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) A/cm\({}^{2}\))(\(\pi\)/4)(0.005 cm)\({}^{2}\) = 39.3 A * 18-22 Assume that most of the electrical charge transferred in MgO is caused by the diffusion of Mg\({}^{2+}\) ions. Determine the mobility and electrical conductivity of MgO at 25\({}^{\circ}\)C and at 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C. (See Table 5-1.) Solution: At 25\({}^{\circ}\)C = 298 K: \[D_{\rm Mg} = 0.249\ {\rm exp}[\,-\,\)79,000/(1.987)(25 \(\,+\,\)273)]\] \[= 2.84\ \times\ 10^{-57}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm s}\] \[\mu = \frac{ZqD}{{\rm k}T}=\frac{(2)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(2.84\ \times\ 10^{-59})}{(1.38\ \times\ 10^{-23})(298)}\] \[= 2.21\ \times\ 10^{-59}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm V}\ {\rm s}\] We can determine that the lattice parameter for MgO is 3.96 A (since \(a_{\rm o}\ \times\ 2r_{\rm Mg}+\ 2r_{\rm O}\)). There are four Mg ions per unit cell, so the number of Mg ions per cm\({}^{3}\) is: \[n = (4)/(3.96\ \times\ 10^{-8})^{3}\ =\ 6.44\ \times\ 10^{22}/{\rm cm}^{3}\] \[\sigma = nZq\mu=(6.44\ \times\ 10^{22})(2)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(2.21\ \times\ 10^{-57})\] \[= 45.5\ \times\ 10^{-54}\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\ {\rm cm}^{-1}\] At 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C = 1773 K: \[D_{\rm Mg} = 0.249\ {\rm exp}[\,-\,\)79,000/(1.987)(1500\ +\ 273)]\] \[= 4.54\ \times\ 10^{-11}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm s}\] \[\mu = \frac{(2)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(4.54\ \times\ 10^{-11})}{(1.38\ \times\ 10^{-23})(1773)}=5.94\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm V}\ {\rm s}\] \[n = (4)/(3.96\ \times\ 10^{-8})^{3}\ =\ 6.44\ \times\ 10^{22}/{\rm cm}^{3}\] \[\sigma = (6.44\ \times\ 10^{22})(2)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(5.94\ \times\ 10^{-10})\] \[= 1.22\ \times\ 10^{-5}\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\ {\rm cm}^{-1}\] Conductivity increases about fifty orders of magnitude when the temperature increases to 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C.

question: Assume that most of the electrical charge transferred in Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) is caused by the diffusion of Al\({}^{3+}\) ions. Determine the mobility and electrical conductivity of Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) at 500\({}^{\circ}\)C and at 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C.
answer: At 500\({}^{\circ}\)C, the electrical conductivity of Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) is \(1.66\ \times\ 10^{-25}\) ohm\({}^{-1}\) cm\({}^{-1}\), and at 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C, the electrical conductivity is \(1.11\ \times\ 10^{-7}\) ohm\({}^{-1}\) cm\({}^{-1}\).
context:
* 18-23 Assume that most of the electrical charge transferred in Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) is caused by the diffusion of Al\({}^{3+}\) ions. Determine the mobility and electrical conductivity of Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) at 500\({}^{\circ}\)C and at 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C. (See Table 5-1.) Solution: At 500\({}^{\circ}\)C = 773 K: \[D_{\rm Al} = 28\ {\rm exp}[\,-\,\)114,000/(1.987)(773)]\ =\ 1.63\ \times\ 10^{-31}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm s}\] \[\mu = \frac{ZqD}{{\rm k}T}=\frac{(3)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(1.63\ \times\ 10^{-31})}{(1. 38\ \times\ 10^{-23})(773)}\] \[= 7.3\ \times\ 10^{-30}\ {\rm cm}^{2}/{\rm V}\ {\rm s}\] Example 14-1 showed that there are 12 Al ions per unit cell. The volume of the unit cell is 253.82\(\ \times\ 10^{-24}\ {\rm cm}^{3}\). Thus the number of Al ions per cm\({}^{3}\) is: \[n = 12/253.82\ \times\ 10^{-24}\ =\ 4.73\ \times\ 10^{22}/{\rm cm}^{3}\] \[\sigma = nAq\mu=(4.73\ \times\ 10^{22})(3)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(7.3\ \times\ 10^{-30})\] \[= 1.66\ \times\ 10^{-25}\ {\rm ohm}^{-1}\ {\rm cm}^{-1}\]At 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C = 1773 K:
\[D_{\rm Al} = 28\ {\rm exp}[-114,000/(1.987)(1773)]\ =\ 2.48\ \times\ 10^{-13}\ {\rm cm^{2}/s}\] \[\mu = \frac{(3)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(2.48\ \times\ 10^{-13})}{(1.38\ \times\ 10^{-23})(1773)}=4.87\ \times\ 10^{-12}\ {\rm cm^{2}/V\cdot s}\] \[n = 12/253.82\ \times\ 10^{-24}\ =\ 4.73\ \times\ 10^{22}/{\rm cm^{3}}\] \[\sigma = (4.73\ \times\ 10^{22})(3)(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(4.87\ \times\ 10^{-12})\] \[= 1.11\ \times\ 10^{-7}\ {\rm ohm^{-1}\cdot cm^{-1}}\] Conductivity increases about 18 orders of magnitude when the temperature increases to 1500\({}^{\circ}\)C.
Calculate the electrical conductivity of a fiber-reinforced polyethylene part that is reinforced with 20 vol% of continuous, aligned nickel fibers.
\[\begin{array}{ll}\mbox{Solution:}&\mbox{From Table 18--1, $\sigma_{\rm PE}$ = \ $10^{-15}$ and $\sigma_{\rm Ni}$ = \ $1.46\ \times\ 10^{5}$}\\ &\mbox{$\sigma_{\rm composite}$ = $f_{\rm PE}$ \sigma_{\rm PE}$ + $f_{\rm Ni}$ \sigma_{\rm Ni}$ = \ $(0.8)(10^{-15})\ +\ $(0.2)(1.46\ \times\ 10^{5})$}\\ &\mbox{$= \ $0.292\ \times\ 10^{5}$\ {\rm ohm^{-1}\cdot cm^{-1}}$}\end{array}\]
For germanium, silicon, and tin, compare, at 25\({}^{\circ}\)C, (a) the number of charge carriers per cubic centimeter, (b) the fraction of the total electrons in the valence band that are excited into the conduction band, and (c) the constant \(n_{\rm o}\).
For germanium:
\[n_{\rm Ge}=\frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(4\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(5.6575\ \times\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm })^{3}}=1.767\ \times\ 10^{23}/{\rm cm^{3}}\]
From Table 18--6, we can find the conductivity and mobilities for germanium. The number of excited electrons is then:
\[\begin{array}{ll}n_{\rm conduction}&=\ \sigma/q(\mu_{\rm e}\ +\ \mu_{\rm u})= 0.02/(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(3800\ +\ 1820)\\ &=\ 2.224\ \times\ 10^{13}\\ \mbox{fraction}&=\ 2.224\ \times\ 10^{13}/1.767\ \times\ 10^{23}=1.259\ \times\ 10^{-10}\\ &n_{\rm o}&=\ \mbox{$n/{\rm exp}(-E_{\rm g}/2{\rm k}T)$}\\ &=\ 2.224\ \times\ 10^{13}/{\rm exp}[\ -0.67/(2)(8.63\ \times\ 10^{-5})(298)]\\ &=\ 1.017\ \times\ 10^{19}\end{array}\]
For silicon:
\[\begin{array}{ll}n_{\rm Si}&=\ \frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(4\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(5.4307\ \times\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm })^{3}}=1.998\ \times\ 10^{23}/{\rm cm^{3}}\\ &n_{\rm conduction}&=\ \sigma/q(\mu_{\rm e}\ +\ \mu_{\rm u})=5\ \times\ 10^{-6}/(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(1900\ +\ 500)\\ &=\ 1.302\ \times\ 10^{10}\\ &\mbox{fraction}&=\ 1.302\ \times\ 10^{10}/1.998\ \times\ 10^{23}=6.517\ \times\ 10^{-14}\\ &n_{\rm o}&=\ \mbox{$n/{\rm exp}(-E_{\rm g}/2{\rm k}T)$}\\ &=\ 1.302\ \times\ 10^{10}/{\rm exp}[\ -1.107/(2)(8.63\ \times\ 10^{-5})(298)]\\ &=\ 2.895\ \times\ 10^{19}\end{array}\]
For tin:
\[n_{\rm Sn}=\frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(4\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(6.4912\ \times\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm })^{3}}=1.170\ \times\ 10^{23}/{\rm cm^{3}}\]\[n_{\rm conduction} = \sigma/q(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h})\,=\,0.9\,\times\,10^{5}/(1.6\,\times\,10 ^{-19})(2500\,+\,2400)\] \[= 1.148\,\times\,10^{20}\] fraction = 1.148 \(\times\,10^{20}/1.170\,\times\,10^{23}\,=\,9.812\,\times\,10^{-4}\) \[n_{\rm o} = n/{\rm exp}(-E_{g^{\prime}}/2{\rm k}T)\] \[= 1.148\,\times\,10^{20}/{\rm exp}[\,-0.08/(2)(8.63\,\times\,10^{-5} )(298)]\] \[= 5.44\,\times\,10^{20}\]
* For germanium, silicon, and tin, compare the temperature required to double the electrical conductivity from the room temperature value. Solution: For germanium, we wish to increase the conductivity from 0.02 to 0.04 \({\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\). From Problem 18-33, \(n_{\rm o}\,=\,1.017\,\times\,10^{19}\): \[\sigma=nq(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h})\,=\,n_{\rm o}q(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h}){\rm exp }(-E_{g}/2{\rm k}T)\] \[0.04=(1.017\,\times\,10^{19})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19})(3800\,+\,18 20)\] \[\exp[\,-0.67/(2)(8.63\,\times\,10^{-5})T]\] \[4.374\,\times\,10^{-6}=\,{\rm exp}(-3882/T)\quad{\rm or}\quad T= \,325\,\,{\rm K}\,=\,42^{\circ}{\rm C}\] For silicon, we wish to increase the conductivity from 5 \(\times\,10^{-6}\) to 10 \(\times\,10^{-6}\)\({\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\). From Problem 18-21, \(n_{\rm o}\,=\,2.895\,\times\,10^{19}\): \[\sigma=nq(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h})\,=\,n_{\rm o}q(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h}){\rm exp }(-E_{g}/2{\rm k}T)\] \[10\,\times\,10^{-6}=(2.895\,\times\,10^{19})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19 })(1900\,+\,500)\] \[\exp[\,-1.107/(2)(8.63\,\times\,10^{-5})T]\] \[8.995\,\times\,10^{-10}=\,{\rm exp}(-6414/T)\] \[-20.829\,=\,-6414/T\quad{\rm or}\quad T=\,308\,\,{\rm K}\,=\,35 ^{\circ}{\rm C}\] For tin, we wish to increase the conductivity from 0.9 \(\times\,10^{5}\) to 1.8 \(\times\,10^{5}\)\({\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\). From Problem 18-21, \(n_{\rm o}\,=\,5.44\,\times\,10^{20}\): \[\sigma=nq(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h})\,=\,n_{\rm o}q(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h}){\rm exp }(-E_{g}/2{\rm k}T)\] \[1.8\,\times\,10^{5}=(5.44\,\times\,10^{20})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19 })(2500\,+\,2400)\] \[\exp[\,-0.08/(2)(8.63\,\times\,10^{-5})T]\] \[0.422\,=\,{\rm exp}(-463.499/T)\] \[-0.863\,=\,-463.499/T\quad{\rm or}\quad T=\,537\,\,{\rm K}\,=\,26 4^{\circ}{\rm C}\]
* Determine the electrical conductivity of silicon when 0.0001 at% antimony is added as a dopant and compare it to the electrical conductivity when 0.0001 at% indium is added. Solution: 0.0001 at% = 1 impurity atom per 10\({}^{6}\) host atoms. For antimony additions (an \(n\)-type semiconductor): \[n=\frac{(8\,\,{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(1\,\,{\rm Sb\,\,atom}/10^{6}\,\,{\rm Si \,atoms})}{(5.4307\,\times\,10^{-8}\,{\rm cm})^{3}}=\,5\,\times\,10^{16}\] \[\sigma=nq\mu_{e}=(5\,\times\,10^{16})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19})(1900)= 15.2\,\,{\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\]For indium additions (a \(p\)-type semiconductor):
\[n=\frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(1\ {\rm In\ atom/10^{6}\ Si\ atoms})}{(5.4307 \times\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm})^{3}}=\ 5\ \times\ 10^{16}\]
\[\sigma=\ nq\mu=(5\ {\times}\ 10^{16})(1.6\ {\times}\ 10^{-19})(500)=\ 4.0\ {\rm ohm^{-1}\cdot cm^{-1}}\]

Calculate the electrical conductivity of a fiber-reinforced polyethylene part that is reinforced with 20 vol% of continuous, aligned nickel fibers.
\[\begin{array}{ll}\mbox{Solution:}&\mbox{From Table 18--1, $\sigma_{\rm PE}$ = \ $10^{-15}$ and $\sigma_{\rm Ni}$ = \ $1.46\ \times\ 10^{5}$}\\ &\mbox{$\sigma_{\rm composite}$ = $f_{\rm PE}$ \sigma_{\rm PE}$ + $f_{\rm Ni}$ \sigma_{\rm Ni}$ = \ $(0.8)(10^{-15})\ +\ $(0.2)(1.46\ \times\ 10^{5})$}\\ &\mbox{$= \ $0.292\ \times\ 10^{5}$\ {\rm ohm^{-1}\cdot cm^{-1}}$}\end{array}\]
For germanium, silicon, and tin, compare, at 25\({}^{\circ}\)C, (a) the number of charge carriers per cubic centimeter, (b) the fraction of the total electrons in the valence band that are excited into the conduction band, and (c) the constant \(n_{\rm o}\).
For germanium:
\[n_{\rm Ge}=\frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(4\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(5.6575\ \times\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm })^{3}}=1.767\ \times\ 10^{23}/{\rm cm^{3}}\]
From Table 18--6, we can find the conductivity and mobilities for germanium. The number of excited electrons is then:
\[\begin{array}{ll}n_{\rm conduction}&=\ \sigma/q(\mu_{\rm e}\ +\ \mu_{\rm u})= 0.02/(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(3800\ +\ 1820)\\ &=\ 2.224\ \times\ 10^{13}\\ \mbox{fraction}&=\ 2.224\ \times\ 10^{13}/1.767\ \times\ 10^{23}=1.259\ \times\ 10^{-10}\\ &n_{\rm o}&=\ \mbox{$n/{\rm exp}(-E_{\rm g}/2{\rm k}T)$}\\ &=\ 2.224\ \times\ 10^{13}/{\rm exp}[\ -0.67/(2)(8.63\ \times\ 10^{-5})(298)]\\ &=\ 1.017\ \times\ 10^{19}\end{array}\]
For silicon:
\[\begin{array}{ll}n_{\rm Si}&=\ \frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(4\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(5.4307\ \times\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm })^{3}}=1.998\ \times\ 10^{23}/{\rm cm^{3}}\\ &n_{\rm conduction}&=\ \sigma/q(\mu_{\rm e}\ +\ \mu_{\rm u})=5\ \times\ 10^{-6}/(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})(1900\ +\ 500)\\ &=\ 1.302\ \times\ 10^{10}\\ &\mbox{fraction}&=\ 1.302\ \times\ 10^{10}/1.998\ \times\ 10^{23}=6.517\ \times\ 10^{-14}\\ &n_{\rm o}&=\ \mbox{$n/{\rm exp}(-E_{\rm g}/2{\rm k}T)$}\\ &=\ 1.302\ \times\ 10^{10}/{\rm exp}[\ -1.107/(2)(8.63\ \times\ 10^{-5})(298)]\\ &=\ 2.895\ \times\ 10^{19}\end{array}\]
For tin:
\[n_{\rm Sn}=\frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(4\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(6.4912\ \times\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm })^{3}}=1.170\ \times\ 10^{23}/{\rm cm^{3}}\]\[n_{\rm conduction} = \sigma/q(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h})\,=\,0.9\,\times\,10^{5}/(1.6\,\times\,10 ^{-19})(2500\,+\,2400)\] \[= 1.148\,\times\,10^{20}\] fraction = 1.148 \(\times\,10^{20}/1.170\,\times\,10^{23}\,=\,9.812\,\times\,10^{-4}\) \[n_{\rm o} = n/{\rm exp}(-E_{g^{\prime}}/2{\rm k}T)\] \[= 1.148\,\times\,10^{20}/{\rm exp}[\,-0.08/(2)(8.63\,\times\,10^{-5} )(298)]\] \[= 5.44\,\times\,10^{20}\]
* For germanium, silicon, and tin, compare the temperature required to double the electrical conductivity from the room temperature value. Solution: For germanium, we wish to increase the conductivity from 0.02 to 0.04 \({\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\). From Problem 18-33, \(n_{\rm o}\,=\,1.017\,\times\,10^{19}\): \[\sigma=nq(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h})\,=\,n_{\rm o}q(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h}){\rm exp }(-E_{g}/2{\rm k}T)\] \[0.04=(1.017\,\times\,10^{19})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19})(3800\,+\,18 20)\] \[\exp[\,-0.67/(2)(8.63\,\times\,10^{-5})T]\] \[4.374\,\times\,10^{-6}=\,{\rm exp}(-3882/T)\quad{\rm or}\quad T= \,325\,\,{\rm K}\,=\,42^{\circ}{\rm C}\] For silicon, we wish to increase the conductivity from 5 \(\times\,10^{-6}\) to 10 \(\times\,10^{-6}\)\({\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\). From Problem 18-21, \(n_{\rm o}\,=\,2.895\,\times\,10^{19}\): \[\sigma=nq(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h})\,=\,n_{\rm o}q(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h}){\rm exp }(-E_{g}/2{\rm k}T)\] \[10\,\times\,10^{-6}=(2.895\,\times\,10^{19})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19 })(1900\,+\,500)\] \[\exp[\,-1.107/(2)(8.63\,\times\,10^{-5})T]\] \[8.995\,\times\,10^{-10}=\,{\rm exp}(-6414/T)\] \[-20.829\,=\,-6414/T\quad{\rm or}\quad T=\,308\,\,{\rm K}\,=\,35 ^{\circ}{\rm C}\] For tin, we wish to increase the conductivity from 0.9 \(\times\,10^{5}\) to 1.8 \(\times\,10^{5}\)\({\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\). From Problem 18-21, \(n_{\rm o}\,=\,5.44\,\times\,10^{20}\): \[\sigma=nq(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h})\,=\,n_{\rm o}q(\mu_{e}\,+\,\mu_{h}){\rm exp }(-E_{g}/2{\rm k}T)\] \[1.8\,\times\,10^{5}=(5.44\,\times\,10^{20})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19 })(2500\,+\,2400)\] \[\exp[\,-0.08/(2)(8.63\,\times\,10^{-5})T]\] \[0.422\,=\,{\rm exp}(-463.499/T)\] \[-0.863\,=\,-463.499/T\quad{\rm or}\quad T=\,537\,\,{\rm K}\,=\,26 4^{\circ}{\rm C}\]
* Determine the electrical conductivity of silicon when 0.0001 at% antimony is added as a dopant and compare it to the electrical conductivity when 0.0001 at% indium is added. Solution: 0.0001 at% = 1 impurity atom per 10\({}^{6}\) host atoms. For antimony additions (an \(n\)-type semiconductor): \[n=\frac{(8\,\,{\rm atoms}/{\rm cell})(1\,\,{\rm Sb\,\,atom}/10^{6}\,\,{\rm Si \,atoms})}{(5.4307\,\times\,10^{-8}\,{\rm cm})^{3}}=\,5\,\times\,10^{16}\] \[\sigma=nq\mu_{e}=(5\,\times\,10^{16})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19})(1900)= 15.2\,\,{\rm ohm}^{-1}\cdot{\rm cm}^{-1}\]For indium additions (a \(p\)-type semiconductor):
\[n=\frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(1\ {\rm In\ atom/10^{6}\ Si\ atoms})}{(5.4307 \times\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm})^{3}}=\ 5\ \times\ 10^{16}\]
\[\sigma=\ nq\mu=(5\ {\times}\ 10^{16})(1.6\ {\times}\ 10^{-19})(500)=\ 4.0\ {\rm ohm^{-1}\cdot cm^{-1}}\]

question: Estimate the electrical conductivity of silicon doped with 0.0002 at% arsenic at 600\({}^{\circ}\)C, which is above the exhaustion plateau in the conductivity-temparature curve.
context:
**18-37**: Estimate the electrical conductivity of silicon doped with 0.0002 at% arsenic at 600\({}^{\circ}\)C, which is above the exhaustion plateau in the conductivity-temparature curve. Solution: \[n_{\rm d}=\frac{(8\ {\rm atoms/cell})(2\ {\rm As\ atoms/10^{6}\ Si\ atoms})}{(5. 4307\ {\times}\ 10^{-8}\ {\rm cm})^{3}}=\ 9.99\ {\times}\ 10^{16}\]
From Problem 18-21, \(n_{\rm o}=2.895\ {\times}\ 10^{19}\)
\[\sigma_{600}=\ n_{\rm d}q\mu_{e}\ +\ q(\mu_{e}\ +\ \mu_{h})n_{\rm o }{\rm exp}(-E_{g}/2{\rm k}T)\]
\[=(9.99\ {\times}\ 10^{16})(1.6\ {\times}\ 10^{-19})(1900)\ +\ (1.6\ {\times}\ 10^{-19})(1900 \ +\ 500)\]
\[\hskip 14.226378pt(2.895\ {\times}\ 10^{19}){\rm exp}[-1.107/(2)(8.63\ {\times}\ 10^{-5})(873)]\]
\[\hskip 14.226378pt=\ 30.37\ +\ 7.167\ =\ 37.537\ {\rm ohm^{-1}\cdot cm^{-1}}\]

question: Calculate the displacement of the electrons or ions for the following conditions: 1. electronic polarization in nickel of 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-7}\) C/m\({}^{2}\) 2. electronic polarization in aluminum of 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-8}\) C/m\({}^{2}\) 3. ionic polarization in NaCl of 4.3 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-8}\) C/m\({}^{2}\) 4. ionic polarization in ZnS of 5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-8}\) C/m\({}^{2}\)
answer:
The displacement of the electrons or ions for the given conditions are: 
1. For nickel: 4.84 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-19}\) m
2. For aluminum: 1.603 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-19}\) m
3. For NaCl: 1.12 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-17}\) m
4. For ZnS: 8.22 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-18}\) m
context: * 18-48 Calculate the displacement of the electrons or ions for the following conditions: 1. electronic polarization in nickel of 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-7}\) C/m\({}^{2}\) 2. electronic polarization in aluminum of 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-8}\) C/m\({}^{2}\) 3. ionic polarization in NaCl of 4.3 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-8}\) C/m\({}^{2}\) 4. ionic polarization in ZnS of 5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-8}\) C/m\({}^{2}\) Solution: \(n\) is the number of charge centers per m\({}^{3}\): 1. For FCC nickel, \(a_{\rm o}=3.5167\) A and the atomic number is 28: \[n = \frac{(4\ {\rm atoms/cell})(28\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(3.5167\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ {\rm m })^{3}}=\ 2.58\ \times\ 10^{30}\] \[d = P/nq\] \[= (2\ \times\ 10^{-7}\ {\rm C/m^{2}})/(2.58\ \times\ 10^{30}\ {\rm m })(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19}\ {\rm C/electron})\] \[d = 4.84\ \times\ 10^{-19}\ {\rm m}\] 2. For FCC aluminum, \(a_{\rm o}=4.04988\) A and the atomic number is 13: \[n = \frac{(4\ {\rm atoms/cell})(13\ {\rm electrons/atom})}{(4.04988\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ { \rm m})^{3}}=\ 0.78\ \times\ 10^{30}\] \[d = P/nq\ = (2\ \times\ 10^{-8})/(0.78\ \times\ 10^{30})(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})\] \[d = 1.603\ \times\ 10^{-19}\ {\rm m}\] 3. For NaCl, \(a_{\rm o}=5.5\) A and there is one charge per ion. There are 4 of each type of ion per cell. The lattice parameter is: \[a_{\rm o} = 2r_{\rm Na}\ +\ 2r_{\rm Cl}=2(0.97)\ +\ 2(1.81)=\ 5.56\ {\rm\AA}\] \[n = \frac{(4\ {\rm Na\ ions/cell})(1\ {\rm charge/ion})}{(5.56\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ { \rm m})^{3}}=\ 0.024\ \times\ 10^{30}\] \[d = P/nq\ = (4.3\ \times\ 10^{-8})/(0.024\ \times\ 10^{30})(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})\] \[d = 1.12\ \times\ 10^{-17}\ {\rm m}\] 4. For ZnS, \(a_{\rm o}=5.96\) A and there are two charges per ion. There are 4 of each type of ion per cell. The lattice parameter is: \[a_{\rm o} = (4r_{\rm Zn}\ +\ 4r_{\rm S})/\sqrt{3}=[(4)(0.74)\ +\ (4)(1.84)]/ \sqrt{3}=5.96\ {\rm\AA}\] \[n = \frac{(4\ {\rm ZnS\ ions/cell})(2\ {\rm charge/ion})}{(5.96\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ {\rm m})^{3}}=\ 0. 038\ \times\ 10^{30}\] \[d = P/nq\ = (5\ \times\ 10^{-8})/(0.038\ \times\ 10^{30})(1.6\ \times\ 10^{-19})\] \[d = 8.22\ \times\ 10^{-18}\ {\rm m}.\]

question: A 2-mm-thick alumina dielectric is used in a 60-Hz circuit. Calculate the voltage required to produce a polarization of 5 \(\times\ 10^{-7}\) C/m\({}^{2}\).
context:
* 18-49 A 2-mm-thick alumina dielectric is used in a 60-Hz circuit. Calculate the voltage required to produce a polarization of 5 \(\times\ 10^{-7}\) C/m\({}^{2}\). Solution: \[P = (\kappa\ -\ 1)\varepsilon_{\rm o}\xi=(\kappa\ -\ 1)\varepsilon_{\rm o }V/\ell\quad{\rm where}\ \ell=2\ {\rm mm}=0.002\ {\rm m}\] \[5\ \times\ 10^{-7} = (9\ -\ 1)(8.85\ \times\ 10^{-12})V/2\ \times\ 10^{-3}\] \[V = 14.1\ {\rm volts}\]* 18-50 Suppose we are able to produce a polarization of 5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-5}\) C/cm\({}^{2}\) in a cube (5 mm side) of barium titanate. What voltage is produced? Solution: \(P=(\kappa\,-\,1)e_{o}\xi=(\kappa\,-\,1)e_{o}V/\ell\) where \(\ell\,=\,5\) mm = 0.005 m 5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-5}\,=\,(3000\,-\,1)(8.85\,\times\,10^{-12})V/0.005\) \(V=\,9.4\) volts

* 18-51 Calculate the thickness of polyethylene required to store the maximum charge in a 24,000-V circuit without breakdown. Solution: \(\xi_{\rm max}\,=\,20\,\times\,10^{6}\) V/m = 24,000/\(\ell\) \(\ell\,=\,0.0012\) m = 1.2 mm

question: We would like to construct a barium titanate device with a 0.1-in. diameter that will produce a voltage of 250 V when a 5 pound force is applied. How thick should the device be?
context: * 18-61 We would like to construct a barium titanate device with a 0.1-in. diameter that will produce a voltage of 250 V when a 5 pound force is applied. How thick should the device be? Solution: \(E=\,10\,\times\,10^{6}\) psi \(d=\,(100\,\times\,10^{-12}\) m/V\()(100\) cm/m\()(1\) in./2.54 cm\()\) \(=\,3.937\,\times\,10^{-9}\) in./V If \(t\,=\) thickness of the device, \(F\) is the applied force, and \(A\) is the area of the device, then: \(\xi=\,V/t\,=\,g\sigma\,=\,\sigma/Ed\,=\,F/AEd\) \(t=\,VAEd/F\) \(=\,(250\) V\()(\pi/4)(0.1\) in.)\({}^{2}(10\,\times\,10^{6}\) psi\()(3.937\,\times\,10^{-9}\) in./V\()/5 lb = 0.0155 in.

## Chapter 19 Magnetic Materials
6 Calculate and compare the maximum magnetization we would expect in iron, nickel, cobalt, and gadolinium. There are seven electrons in the 4\(f\) level of gadolinium.
Solution: Iron: The number of atoms/m\({}^{3}\) is:
\[\frac{2\ \mathrm{atoms/cell}}{(2.866\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ \mathrm{m})^{3}}=0.085 \times\ 10^{30}\ \mathrm{atoms/m^{3}}\]
\[M=(0.085\ \times\ 10^{30})(4\ \mathrm{magnetons/atom})(9.27\ \times\ 10^{-24}\ \mathrm{A\cdot m^{2}})\]
\[=3.15\ \times\ 10^{6}\ \mathrm{A/m}=39,600\ \mathrm{oersted}\]
Nickel: The number of atoms/m\({}^{3}\) is:
\[\frac{4\ \mathrm{atoms/cell}}{(3.5167\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ \mathrm{m})^{3}}=0.09197 \times\ 10^{30}\ \mathrm{atoms/m^{3}}\]
\[M=(0.09197\ \times\ 10^{30})(2\ \mathrm{magnetons/atom})(9.27\ \times\ 10^{-24}\ \mathrm{A\cdot m^{2}})\]
\[=1.705\ \times\ 10^{6}\ \mathrm{A/m}=21,430\ \mathrm{oersted}\]
\[\frac{2\ \mathrm{atoms/cell}}{(2.5071\ \times\ 10^{-10}\ \mathrm{m})^{2}(4.0686 \times\ 10^{-10})\mathrm{cos}\ 30}\]
\[=0.0903\ \times\ 10^{30}\ \mathrm{atoms/m^{3}}\]
\[M=(0.0903\ \times\ 10^{30})(3\ \mathrm{magnetons/atom})(9.27\ \times\ 10^{-24}\ \mathrm{A\cdot m^{2}})\]
\[=2.51\ \times\ 10^{6}\ \mathrm{A/m}=31,560\ \mathrm{oersted}\]* 19-11 An alloy of nickel and cobalt is to be produced to give a magnetization of 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) A/m. The crystal structure of the alloy is FCC with a lattice parameter of 0.3544 nm. Determine the atomic percent cobalt required, assuming no interaction between the nickel and cobalt. Solution: Let \(f_{\rm Ni}\) be the atomic fraction of nickel; 1 \(-\)\(f_{\rm Ni}\) is then the atomic fraction of cobalt. The numbers of Bohr magnetons per cubic meter due to nickel and to cobalt atoms are: Ni: (4 atoms/cell)(2 magnetons/atom)\(f_{\rm Ni}\)/(3.544 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-10}\) m)\({}^{3}\) \(=\) 0.1797 \(\times\) 10\({}^{30}\)\(f_{\rm Ni}\) Co: (4 atoms/cell)(3 magnetons/atom)(1 \(-\)\(f_{\rm Ni}\))/(3.544 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-10}\) m)\({}^{3}\) \(=\) 0.2696 \(\times\) 10\({}^{30}\)(1 \(-\)\(f_{\rm Ni}\)) \(M=[(0.1797 \times\) 10\({}^{30})f_{\rm Ni}+(0.2696 \times\) 10\({}^{30})(1 \(-\)\(f_{\rm Ni}\))](9.27 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-24}\)) \(M=-0.833 \times\) 10\({}^{6}\)\(f_{\rm Ni}+2.499\)\(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\)\(=\) 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) \(f_{\rm Ni}=0.60\)\(f_{\rm Co}=0.40\)

question: Estimate the magnetization that might be produced in an alloy containing nickel and 70 at% copper, assuming that no interaction occurs.
context: * 19-12 Estimate the magnetization that might be produced in an alloy containing nickel and 70 at% copper, assuming that no interaction occurs. Solution: We can estimate the lattice parameter of the alloy from those of the pure nickel and copper and their atomic fractions: \(a_{\rm o}=(0.3)(3.294)\) + \((0.7)(3.6151)\) = 3.52 A If the copper does not provide magnetic moments that influence magnetization, then \(M=\frac{(4\ {\rm atoms/cell})(0.3\ {\rm fraction\ Ni})(2 magnetons/Ni atom)(9.27 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-24}\)) \((3.52\)\(\times\) 10\({}^{-10}\) m)\({}^{3}\) \(=\) 0.51 \(\times\) 10\({}^{6}\) A/m \(=\) 6410 oersted

question: Suppose we replace 10% of the Fe\({}^{2+}\) ions in magnetite with Cu\({}^{2+}\) ions. Determine the total magnetic moment per cubic centimeter.
context: * 19-40 Suppose we replace 10% of the Fe\({}^{2+}\) ions in magnetite with Cu\({}^{2+}\) ions. Determine the total magnetic moment per cubic centimeter. Solution: From Example 19-6, the lattice parameter is 8.37 A. \[V_{\text{unit cell}}=(8.37\,\times\,10^{-8}\,\text{cm})^{3} = 5.86\,\times\,10^{-22}\,\text{cm}^{3}\] \[= 5.86\,\times\,10^{-28}\,\text{m}^{3}\] In the tetrahedral sites, the fraction of copper atoms is 0.1, while the fraction of Fe\({}^{2+}\) ions is 0.9. The magnetic moment is then: moment \[= \frac{(8\text{ subcells})[\,0.1\,\text{Cu}(1\text{ magneton})\,+\,0.9\,\text{Fe}(4\text{ magneton})](9.27\,\times\,10^{-24}\text{A}\cdot\text{m}^{2})}{5.86\,\times\,10^{-28}\,\text{m}^{3}}\] moment \[= 4.68\,\times\,10^{5}\,\text{A}\cdot\text{m}^{2}/\text{m}^{3}=4.68\, \times\,10^{5}\,\text{A}/\text{m}\,=\,0.468\,\text{A}\cdot\text{m}^{2}/\text{ cm}^{3}\]

question: Suppose that the total magnetic moment per cubic meter in a spinel structure in which Ni\({}^{2+}\) ions have replaced a portion of the Fe\({}^{2+}\) ions is 4.6 \(\times\) 10\({}^{5}\,\text{A}/\text{m}\). Calculate the fraction of the Fe\({}^{2+}\) ions that have been replaced.
context: * 19-41 Suppose that the total magnetic moment per cubic meter in a spinel structure in which Ni\({}^{2+}\) ions have replaced a portion of the Fe\({}^{2+}\) ions is 4.6 \(\times\) 10\({}^{5}\,\text{A}/\text{m}\). Calculate the fraction of the Fe\({}^{2+}\) ions that have been replaced and the wt% Ni present in the spinel. Solution: From Example 19-6, the volume of the unit cell is 5.86 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-28}\,\text{m}^{3}\). If we let \(x\) be the fraction of the tetrahedral sites occupied by nickel, then \((1\,-\,x)\) is the fraction of the sites occupied by iron. Then: moment \[= 4.6\,\times\,10^{5}=\frac{(8)[(x)(2\text{ magnetons})\,+\,(1\,-\,x)(4\text{ magnetons})](9.27\,\times\,10^{-24})}{5.86\,\times\,10^{-28}\,\text{m}^{3}}\] \[x = 0.185\] Thus the number of each type of atom or ion in the unit cell is: oxygen: \[(4\text{ atoms/subcell})(8\text{ subcells})\,=\,32\] Fe\({}^{3+}\): \[(2\text{ ions/subcell})(8\text{ subcells})\,=\,16\] Fe\({}^{2+}\): \[(0.815)(1\text{ ion/subcell})(8\text{ subcells})\,=\,6.52\] Ni\({}^{2+}\): \[(0.185)(1\text{ ion/subcell})(8\text{ subcells})\,=\,1.48\] The total number of ions in the unit cell is 56; the atomic fraction of each ion is: \[f_{\text{oxygen}}=\,32/56\,=\,0.5714 f_{\text{Fe}^{2+}}\,=\,16/56\,=\,0.2857\] \[f_{\text{Fe}^{2+}}=\,6.52/56\,=\,0.1164 f_{\text{Ni}^{2+}}\,=\,1.48/56\,=\,0.0264\] The weight percent nickel is (using the molecular weights of oxygen, iron and nickel): \[\%\,\text{Ni} = \frac{(0.0264)(58.71)}{(0.5714)(16)\,+\,(0.2857)(55.847)\,+\,(0.1 164)(55.847)\,+\,(0.0264)(58.71)}\] \[= 4.68\,\text{ wt}\%\]* 20-10 A beam of photons strikes a material at an angle of \(25^{\circ}\) to the normal of the surface. Which, if any, of the materials listed in Table 20-1 could cause the beam of photons to continue at an angle of 18 to \(20^{\circ}\) from the normal of the material's surface? Solution: Assuming that the beam originally is passing through air or a vacuum, \(n=\sin\theta i/\sin\theta t=\sin 25^{\circ}/\sin\beta\) To exit at an angle of \(18^{\circ}\): \(n=\sin 25^{\circ}/\sin 18^{\circ}=0.4226/0.3090=1.367\) To exit at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\): \(n=\sin 25^{\circ}/\sin 20^{\circ}=0.4226/0.3420=1.236\) In Table 20-1, only ice, water, and Teflon have an index of refraction between 1.236 and 1.367.

question: A laser beam passing through air strikes a 5-cm thick polystyrene block at a \(20^{\circ}\) angle to the normal of the block. By what distance is the beam displaced from its original path when the beam reaches the opposite side of the block?
context:
* 20-11 A laser beam passing through air strikes a 5-cm thick polystyrene block at a \(20^{\circ}\) angle to the normal of the block. By what distance is the beam displaced from its original path when the beam reaches the opposite side of the block? Solution: The index of refraction for polystyrene is 1.60. Since the incident angle \(\theta i\) is \(20^{\circ}\), the angle of the beam as it passes through the polystyrene block will be: \(n=\sin\theta i/\sin\theta t=\sin 20^{\circ}/\sin\theta t=1.6\) \(\sin\theta t=0.3420/1.6=0.2138\) \(\theta t=12.35^{\circ}\)From the sketch, we can find the displacement of the beam expected if no refraction occurs:
\[\tan\,20^{\circ}\,=\,x/5\quad\text{or}\quad x\,=\,5\,\tan\,20^{\circ}\,=\,(5)(0.3 640)\,=\,1.820\text{ cm}\]
We can also find the displacement of the beam when refraction occurs:
\[\tan\,12.35^{\circ}\,=\,y/5\quad\text{or}\quad y\,=\,5\,\tan\,12.35^{\circ}\,= \,(5)(0.2189)\,=\,1.095\text{ cm}\]
Because of refraction, the beam is displaced \(1.820\,-\,1.095\,=\,0.725\text{ cm}\) from its path had no refraction occurred.
* A beam of photons passes through air and strikes a soda-lime glass that is part of an aquarium containing water. What fraction of the beam is reflected by the front face of the glass? What fraction of the remaining beam is reflected by the back face of the glass? Solution: The fraction of the beam reflected by the front face is: \[R\,=\,\left(\frac{n_{glass}\,-\,n_{air}}{n_{glass}\,+\,n_{air}}\right)^{2}\,= \,\left(\frac{1.50\,-\,1.00}{1.50\,+\,1.00}\right)^{2}\,=\,0.04\] The fraction of the remaining beam reflected from the back face of the glass is: \[R\,=\,\left(\frac{n_{water}\,-\,n_{glass}}{n_{water}\,+\,n_{glass}}\right)^{2} \,=\,\left(\frac{1.33\,-\,1.50}{1.33\,+\,1.50}\right)^{2}\,=\,0.0036\]
* We find that 20% of the original intensity of a beam of photons is transmitted from air through a 1-cm thick-material having a dielectric constant of 2.3 and back into air. Determine the fraction of the beam that is (a) reflected at the front surface, (b) absorbed in the material, and (c) reflected at the back surface. (d) Determine the linear absorption coefficient of the photons in the material. Solution: The dielectric material has an index of refraction of: \[m\,=\,\sqrt{\kappa}\,=\,\sqrt{2.3}\,=\,1.5166\]
* The fraction of the beam reflected at the front surface is: \[R\,=\,\left(\frac{n_{material}\,-\,n_{air}}{n_{material}\,+\,n_{air}}\right)^{2} \,=\,\left(\frac{1.5166\,-\,1.00}{1.5166\,+\,1.00}\right)^{2}\,=\,0.04214\]
* The fraction transmitted through the material is 0.2; therefore the linear absorption coefficient of the materials is: \[I_{\text{J}}/I_{\text{o}} =\,(1\,-\,R)^{2}\text{exp}(-\alpha x)\] \[=\,(1\,-\,0.04214)^{2}\text{exp}\left[\,-\alpha(1\text{ cm})\right]\,=\,0.20\]
\[\exp(-\alpha) = 0.21798\] \[-\alpha = \ln(0.21798)=\,-1.523\] \[\alpha = 1.523\ \mathrm{cm}^{-1}\] After reflection, the intensity of the remaining beam is \[I_{\mathrm{after\,reflection}}=\,1\,-\,0.04215\,=\,0.95785I_{\mathrm{o}}\] Before reflection at the back surface, the intensity of the beam is: \[I_{\mathrm{after\,absorption}}=\,0.95785\exp\left[(-1.523)(1)\right]=\,0.2089I_{ \mathrm{o}}\] The fraction of the beam that is absorbed is therefore \[I_{\mathrm{absorbed}}=\,0.95785\,-\,0.2089\,=\,0.74895I_{\mathrm{o}}\] 3. The fraction of the beam reflected off the back surface is: \[I_{\mathrm{o}}=\,I_{\mathrm{reflected,\,front}}+\,I_{\mathrm{absorbed }}+\,I_{\mathrm{reflected,\,back}}+\,I_{\mathrm{transmitted}}\] \[I_{\mathrm{o}}=\,0.04214I_{\mathrm{o}}\,+\,0.74895I_{\mathrm{o}}+\,I_{ \mathrm{reflected,\,back}}+\,0.20I_{\mathrm{o}}\] \[I_{\mathrm{reflected,\,back}}=\,0.0089I_{\mathrm{o}}\] 4. See part b; \(\alpha=1.523\ \mathrm{cm}^{-1}\)
* A beam of photons in air strikes a composite material consisting of a 1-cm-thick sheet of polyethylene and a 2-cm-thick sheet of soda-line glass. The incident beam is \(10^{\circ}\) from the normal of the composite. Determine the angle of the beam with respect to the normal as the beam (a) passes through the polyethylene, (b) passes through the glass, and (c) passes through air on the opposite side of the composite. (d) By what distance is the beam displaced from its original path when it emerges from the composite? Solution: The figure shows how the beam changes directions, and the amount that the beam is displaced from the normal to the point of entry, as it passes through each interface.
* As the beam passes from air into polyethylene (which has an index of refraction of 1.52), \[\sin\theta_{t} = \sin\theta_{i}/n=\,\sin\,10^{\circ}/1.52=0.1736/1.52=0.1142\] \[\theta_{t} = 6.6^{\circ}\]

question: We find that 20% of the original intensity of a beam of photons is transmitted from air through a 1-cm thick-material having a dielectric constant of 2.3 and back into air. Determine the fraction of the beam that is (a) reflected at the front surface, (b) absorbed in the material, and (c) reflected at the back surface.
answer:
a) Fraction reflected at the front surface: 0.04214
   b) Fraction absorbed in the material: 0.74895
   c) Fraction reflected at the back surface: 0.0089
   d) Linear absorption coefficient: 1.523 cm\(^{-1}\)

   (Answer for a, b, and c are provided)

question: Determine the time required for the intensity of calcium tungstate to decrease to 1% of the original intensity after the stimulus is removed.
context: * 20-25 Calcium tungstate (CaWO\({}_{d}\)) has a relaxation time of 4 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-6}\) s. Determine the time required for the intensity of this phosphorescent material to decrease to 1% of the original intensity after the stimulus is removed. Solution: \[\ln(I/I_{\mathrm{o}}) = -t/\tau\] \[\ln(0.01) = -t/4\,\times\,10^{-6}\,\mathrm{s}\] \[-4.605 = -t/4\,\times\,10^{-6}\] \[t = 18.4\,\times\,10^{-6}\,\mathrm{s}\]

question: Determine the approximate energy transition if the Nd : YAG serves as a laser, producing a wavelength of 532 nm. What color would the laser beam possess?
answer:
The approximate energy transition is 2.333 eV, and the laser beam would possess a green color.

2.
context:
* 20-30 By appropriately doping yttrium aluminum garnet with neodymium, electrons are excited within the 4\(f\) energy shell of the Nd atoms. Determine the approximate energy transition if the Nd : YAG serves as a laser, producing a wavelength of 532 nm. What color would the laser beam possess? Solution: The energy transition is: \[E=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\,\times\,10^{10} \,\mathrm{cm/s})}{(532\,\times\,10^{-9}\,\mathrm{m})(100\,\,\mathrm{cm/m})(1.6 \,\times\,10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J/eV})}=\,2.333\,\,\mathrm{eV}\] The wavelength of 532 nm is 5320 A or 5.32 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-5}\) cm. This wavelength corresponds to a color of green.

* 20-31 Determine whether an incident beam of photons with a wavelength of 7500 A will cause luminescence in the following materials (see Chapter 18).

question: What is the energy of the incident photons?
context:
* 20-32 ZnO (b) GaP (c) GaAs (d) GaSb (e) PbS Solution: The incident beam must have an energy greater than the energy gap of the material in order for luminescence to occur. The energy of the incident photons is: \[E=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\,\times\,10^{10} \,\mathrm{cm/s})}{(7500\,\times\,10^{-8}\,\mathrm{cm})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\, \mathrm{J/eV})}=\,1.655\,\,\mathrm{eV}\]
From Chapter 18 and literature values, the energy gaps of the five materials are:
\begin{tabular}{r c} ZnO: & 3.2 eV \\ GaP: & 2.24 eV \\ GaAs: & 1.35 eV \\ GaSb: & 0.67 eV \\ PbS: & 0.37 eV \\ \end{tabular} Consequently the photons, having energy 1.655 eV, will be able to excite electrons in GaAs, GaSb, and PbS; however electrons will not be excited in ZnO and GaP.

question: Determine the wavelength of photons produced when electrons excited into the conduction band of indium-doped silicon (a) drop from the conduction band to the acceptor band and (b) then drop from the acceptor band to the valence band.
context:
**20\(-\)32**: Determine the wavelength of photons produced when electrons excited into the conduction band of indium-doped silicon (a) drop from the conduction band to the acceptor band and (b) then drop from the acceptor band to the valence band (see Chapter 18).
\begin{tabular}{r c} Solution: & The acceptor energy in Si-In is 0.16 eV; the energy gap in pure Si is 1.107 eV. The difference between the energy gap and the acceptor energy level is 1.107 \(-\) 0.16 \(=\) 0.947 eV. \\ \end{tabular}
* The wavelength of photons produced when an electron drops from the conduction band to the acceptor band, an energy difference of 0.947 eV, is: \[\lambda\,=\,\text{h}c/E=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\text{J}\cdot\text{s}) (3\,\times\,10^{10}\,\text{ cm}/\text{s})}{(0.947\,\text{eV})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\, \text{J}/\text{eV})}=\,13.11\,\times\,10^{-5}\,\text{cm}\]
* The wavelength of photons produced when the electron subsequently drops from the acceptor band to the valence band, an energy difference of 0.16 eV, is: \[\lambda\,=\,\text{h}c/E=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\text{J}\cdot\text{s}) (3\,\times\,10^{10}\,\text{cm}/\text{s})}{(0.16\,\text{eV})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19 }\,\text{J}/\text{eV})}=\,77.58\,\times\,10^{-5}\,\text{cm}\]

question: Which, if any, of the semiconducting compounds listed in Chapter 18 are capable of producing an infrared laser beam?
answer: The semiconducting compounds capable of producing an infrared laser beam are: InSb, InAs, PbS, PbTe, CdSnAs2.
context:
**20\(-\)33**: Which, if any, of the semiconducting compounds listed in Chapter 18 are capable of producing an infrared laser beam?
\begin{tabular}{r c} Solution: & Infrared radiation has a wavelength of between 10\({}^{-2}\) and 10\({}^{-4}\) cm. Thus the semiconducting compound must have an energy gap that lies between the energies corresponding to these wavelength limits: \\ \(Eg\,=\,\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\text{J}\cdot\text{s})(3\,\times\,10^{10} \,\text{cm}/\text{s})}{(10^{-2}\,\text{cm})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\,\text{J}/ \text{eV})}=\,0.0124\,\text{ eV}\) \\ \(Eg\,=\,\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\text{J}\cdot\text{s})(3\,\times\,10^{10} \,\text{cm}/\text{s})}{(10^{-4}\,\text{cm})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\,\text{J}/ \text{eV})}=\,1.24\,\text{ eV}\) \\ \end{tabular} Of the semiconducting compounds in Table 18\(-\)8, the following have energy gaps between 0.0124 and 1.24 eV and can therefore act as infrared lasers:
\begin{tabular}{r c c c} InSb & InAs & PbS & PbTe & CdSnAs\({}_{2}\) \\ \end{tabular}

* 20-34 What type of electromagnetic radiation (ultraviolet, infrared, visible) is produced from (a) pure germanium and (b) germanium doped with phosphorous? (See Chapter 18.)

question: What is the wavelength of pure germanium with an energy gap of 0.67 eV?
context:
* 1. For pure germanium, the energy gap is 0.67 eV; the wavelength is: \[\lambda=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\,\times\,10^ {10}\,\mathrm{cm/s})}{(0.67\,\mathrm{eV})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J/eV})} =\,1.853\,\times\,10^{-4}\,\mathrm{cm}\] This corresponds to the infrared region of the spectrum. 2. For Ge doped with phosphorous, the energy gap is 0.012 eV. \[\lambda=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\,\times\,10^ {10}\,\mathrm{cm/s})}{(0.012\,\mathrm{eV})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J/eV})} =\,1.034\,\times\,10^{-2}\,\mathrm{cm}\] This wavelength is also in the infrared region.

* 20-35 Which, if any, of the dielectric materials listed in Chapter 18 would reduce the speed of light in air from 3 \(\times\) 10\({}^{10}\) cm/s to less than 0.5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{10}\) cm/s?

question: What is the wavelength of germanium doped with phosphorous having an energy gap of 0.012 eV?
context:
* 1. For pure germanium, the energy gap is 0.67 eV; the wavelength is: \[\lambda=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\,\times\,10^ {10}\,\mathrm{cm/s})}{(0.67\,\mathrm{eV})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J/eV})} =\,1.853\,\times\,10^{-4}\,\mathrm{cm}\] This corresponds to the infrared region of the spectrum. 2. For Ge doped with phosphorous, the energy gap is 0.012 eV. \[\lambda=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\,\times\,10^ {10}\,\mathrm{cm/s})}{(0.012\,\mathrm{eV})(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J/eV})} =\,1.034\,\times\,10^{-2}\,\mathrm{cm}\] This wavelength is also in the infrared region.

* 20-35 Which, if any, of the dielectric materials listed in Chapter 18 would reduce the speed of light in air from 3 \(\times\) 10\({}^{10}\) cm/s to less than 0.5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{10}\) cm/s?

question: To reduce the speed of light the required amount, the index of refraction must be greater than:
context:
* 2. To reduce the speed of light the required amount, the index of refraction must be greater than: \[n=c/v=3\,\times\,10^{10}\,\mathrm{cm/s/0.5\,\times\,10^{10}\,\mathrm{cm/s}}=\,6\] Consequently the dielectric constant \(\kappa\) of the material must be greater than: \[\kappa\,=\,n^{2}=\,6^{2}=\,36\] From Table 18-9, only H\({}_{2}\)O, BaTiO\({}_{3}\), and TiO\({}_{2}\) have dielectric constants greater than 36.

* 20-36 What filter material would you use to isolate the \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of the following x-rays: iron, manganese, nickel? Explain your answer.

question:
What are the absorption edges for manganese, iron, and nickel?
1.2
answer:
The absorption edge for manganese is 1.896 A, for iron is 1.937 A, and for nickel is 1.608 A.

2.1
context: * 3. Iron: use a manganese filter. The absorption edge for Mn is 1.896 A, which lies between the iron \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 1.937 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.757 A. Manganese: use a chromium filter. The absorption edge for Cr is 2.070 A, which lies between the manganese \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 2.104 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.910 A. Nickel: use a cobalt filter. The absorption edge for Co is 1.608 A, which lies between the nickel \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 1.660 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.500 A.

question:
What are the \(K_{\alpha}\) and \(K_{\beta}\) peaks for iron and nickel?
2.2
answer:
The \(K_{\alpha}\) peak for iron is 1.937 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak is 1.757 A, while the \(K_{\alpha}\) peak for nickel is 1.660 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak is 1.500 A.

3.1
context: * 3. Iron: use a manganese filter. The absorption edge for Mn is 1.896 A, which lies between the iron \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 1.937 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.757 A. Manganese: use a chromium filter. The absorption edge for Cr is 2.070 A, which lies between the manganese \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 2.104 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.910 A. Nickel: use a cobalt filter. The absorption edge for Co is 1.608 A, which lies between the nickel \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 1.660 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.500 A.

question:
What filter should be used for iron, manganese, and nickel respectively?
3.2
answer: Use a manganese filter for iron, a chromium filter for manganese, and a cobalt filter for nickel.
context: * 3. Iron: use a manganese filter. The absorption edge for Mn is 1.896 A, which lies between the iron \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 1.937 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.757 A. Manganese: use a chromium filter. The absorption edge for Cr is 2.070 A, which lies between the manganese \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 2.104 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.910 A. Nickel: use a cobalt filter. The absorption edge for Co is 1.608 A, which lies between the nickel \(K_{\alpha}\) peak of 1.660 A and the \(K_{\beta}\) peak of 1.500 A.

question: What voltage must be applied to a tungsten filament to produce a continuous spectrum of x-rays having a minimum wavelength of 0.09 nm?
context: * 3. What voltage must be applied to a tungsten filament to produce a continuous spectrum of x-rays having a minimum wavelength of 0.09 nm? Solution: \[E =\frac{\mathrm{h}c}{\lambda}=\frac{(6.62\,\times\,10^{-34}\,\mathrm{ J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\,\times\,10^{10}\,\mathrm{cm/s})}{(0.09\,\times\,10^{-9}\, \mathrm{m})(100\,\mathrm{cm/m})}=\,2.206\,\times\,10^{-15}\,\mathrm{J}\] \[E =(2.206\,\times\,10^{-15}\,\mathrm{J})/(1.6\,\times\,10^{-19}\, \mathrm{J/eV})\,=\,13,\!790\,\mathrm{V}\]* 20-38 A tungsten filament is heated with a 12,400 V power supply. What is (a) the wavelength and (b) frequency of the highest-energy x-rays that are produced? Solution: \[E=(12,\!400\;\mathrm{eV})(1.6\;\times\;10^{-19}\;\mathrm{J/eV})\;=\;1.984\; \times\;10^{-15}\;\mathrm{J}\] \[1.984\;\times\;10^{-15}\;\mathrm{J}\;=\;\mathrm{h}c/\lambda\;=\; \frac{(6.62\;\times\;10^{-34}\;\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\;\times\;10^{10}\; \mathrm{cm/s})}{\lambda}\] \[\lambda=\;1.00\;\times\;10^{-8}\;\mathrm{cm}\;=\;1.00\;\mathrm{\AA} \;=\;0.100\;\mathrm{nm}\] \[\mathrm{(b)}\;\nu=c/\lambda=\;3\;\times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{cm/s/1.00 }\;\times\;10^{-8}\;\mathrm{cm}\;=\;3.0\;\times\;10^{18}\;\mathrm{s}^{-1}\]

question: What is the minimum voltage required to produce \(K_{a}\) x-rays in nickel?
context: * 20-39 What is the minimum voltage required to produce \(K_{a}\) x-rays in nickel? Solution: The wavelength of \(K_{a}\) x-rays in nickel is 1.66 A \(=\) 1.66 \(\times\;10^{-8}\;\mathrm{cm}\) \[E=\frac{(6.62\;\times\;10^{-34}\;\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\;\times\;10^{10} \;\mathrm{cm/s})}{(1.66\;\times\;10^{-8}\;\mathrm{cm})(1.6\;\times\;10^{-19}\; \mathrm{J/eV})}=\;7,\!477\;\mathrm{V}\]

question: What is the difference in energy between electrons in tungsten for the \(K\) and \(M\) shells based on the characteristic x-rays emitted?
context: * 20-40 Based on the characteristic x-rays that are emitted, determine the difference in energy between electrons in tungsten for (a) the \(K\) and \(L\) shells, (b) the \(K\) and \(M\) shells, and (c) the \(L\) and \(M\) shells. Solution: The energy difference between the \(K\) and \(L\) shells produces \(K_{a}\) x-rays. The wavelength of these x-rays is 0.211 A: \[E\left(K-L\right)=\frac{(6.62\;\times\;10^{-34}\;\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\; \times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{cm/s})}{(0.211\;\times\;10^{-8}\;\mathrm{cm})(1.6\; \times\;10^{-19}\;\mathrm{J/eV})}=\;58,\!830\;\mathrm{eV}\] The energy difference between the \(K\) and \(M\) shells produces \(K_{\beta}\) x-rays. The wavelength of these x-rays is 0.184 A: \[E\left(K-M\right)=\frac{(6.62\;\times\;10^{-34}\;\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\; \times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{cm/s})}{(0.184\;\times\;10^{-8}\;\mathrm{cm})(1.6\; \times\;10^{-19}\;\mathrm{J/eV})}=\;67,\!459\;\mathrm{eV}\] The energy difference between the \(L\) and \(M\) shells produces \(L_{a}\) x-rays. The wavelength of these x-rays is 1.476 A: \[E\left(L-M\right)=\frac{(6.62\;\times\;10^{-34}\;\mathrm{J}\cdot\mathrm{s})(3\; \times\;10^{10}\;\mathrm{cm/s})}{(1.476\;\times\;10^{-8}\;\mathrm{cm})(1.6\; \times\;10^{-19}\;\mathrm{J/eV})}=\;8,\!410\;\mathrm{eV}\]

question: Calculate the heat (in calories and joules) required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of the following materials by 50\({}^{\circ}\)C: (a) lead, (b) nickel, (c) Si\({}_{3}\)N\({}_{4}\), (d) 6,6-nylon.
context:
* 21-3 Calculate the heat (in calories and joules) required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of the following materials by 50\({}^{\circ}\)C.
* (a) lead (b) nickel (c) Si\({}_{3}\)N\({}_{4}\) (d) 6,6-nylon Solution: The heat is the specific heat times the weight times the temperature change. Calories can be converted to joules by multiplying by 4.184.
* (a) \(c_{\text{Pb}}\) = (0.038 cal/gK)(1000 g)(50 K) = 1900 cal = 7,950 J
* (b) \(c_{\text{Ni}}\) = (0.106 cal/gK)(1000 g)(50 K) = 5300 cal = 22,175 J
* (c) \(c_{\text{silicon nitride}}\) = (0.17 cal/gK)(1000 g)(50 K) = 8,500 cal = 35,564 J
* (d) \(c_{\text{6,6 nylon}}\) = (0.40 cal/gK)(1000 g)(50 K) = 20,000 cal = 83,680 J

question: What is the original length of the cavity in the mold for aluminum casting?
context:
* 21-4 Calculate the temperature of a 100-g sample of the following materials, (originally at 25\({}^{\circ}\)C) when 3000 calories are introduced.
* (a) tungsten (b) titanium (c) Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\) (d) low-density polyethylene Solution: (a) W: 3000 cal = (0.032 cal/gK)(100 g)(T - 25) or \(T_{\text{W}}\) = 962.5\({}^{\circ}\)C (b) Ti: 3000 cal = (0.125 cal/gK)(100 g)(T - 25) or \(T_{\text{Ti}}\) = 265\({}^{\circ}\)C (c) Al\({}_{2}\)O\({}_{3}\): 3000 cal = (0.20 cal/gK)(100 g)(T - 25) or \(T_{\text{alumina}}\) = 175\({}^{\circ}\)C (d) LDPE: 3000 cal = (0.55 cal/gK)(100 g)(T - 25) or \(T_{\text{PE}}\) = 79.5\({}^{\circ}\)C
[MISSING_PAGE_FAIL:227]
* [leftmargin=*] Solution: The aluminum casting shrinks between the solidification temperature (660.4\({}^{\circ}\)C) and room temperature (25\({}^{\circ}\)C). However, the gray cast iron mold expands when it is heated from 25\({}^{\circ}\)C to 350\({}^{\circ}\)C during the casting process. The original length of the cavity in the mold is therefore given by the amount of contraction of the aluminum minus the amount of expansion of the mold: \[\ell = \ell_{\mathrm{o}}\,+\ \Delta\,\ell_{\mathrm{gray\ iron}}\,-\,\Delta\, \ell_{\mathrm{aluminum}}\] \[15 = \ell_{\mathrm{o}}\,+\ \ell_{\mathrm{o}}[(12\times 10^{-6})(350 -25)\,-(25\times 10^{-6})(660.4\,-25)]\] \[15 = \ell_{\mathrm{o}}\,+\ 0.0039\ell_{\mathrm{o}}\,-\,0.015885\ell_{ \mathrm{o}}=0.988\ell_{\mathrm{o}}\] \[\ell_{\mathrm{o}}\,=\,15.182\;\mathrm{in}.\]
* We coat a 100-cm-long, 2-mm-diameter copper wire with a 0.5-mm-thick epoxy insulation coating. Determine the length of the copper and the coating when their temperature increases from 25\({}^{\circ}\)C to 250\({}^{\circ}\)C. What is likely to happen to the epoxy coating as a result of this heating? Solution: Both the copper and the epoxy expand when heated. The final length of each material, assuming that they are not bonded to one another, would be: \[\ell_{\mathrm{Cu}} = (100\;\mathrm{cm})(16.6\times 10^{-6})(250\,-\,25)\,+\,100\,=100.3735\; \mathrm{cm}\] \[\ell_{\mathrm{epoxy}} = (100\;\mathrm{cm})(55\times 10^{-6})(250\,-\,25)\,+\,100\,=101.2375\; \mathrm{cm}\] The epoxy expands nearly 1 cm more than does the underlying copper. If the copper and epoxy are well bonded, the epoxy coating will buckle, debond, and perhaps even flake off.
* We produce a 10-in.-long bimetallic composite material composed of a strip of yellow brass bonded to a strip of Invar. Determine the length to which each material would like to expand when the temperature increases from 20\({}^{\circ}\)C to 150\({}^{\circ}\)C. Draw a sketch showing what will happen to the shape of the bimetallic strip. Solution: If the two metals are not bonded to one another, the amount each would like to expand is: \[\pi_{\mathrm{ brass}} = 10\,+\,(10)(18.9\times 10^{-6})(150\,-\,20)\,=10.0246\;\mathrm{in}.\] \[\ell_{\mathrm{Invar}} = 10\,+\,(10)(1.54\times 10^{-6})(150\,-\,20)\,=10.0020\;\mathrm{in}.\] The brass expands more than the Invar; if the two are bonded together, the bimetallic strip will bend, with the Invar on the inside radius of curvature of the strip.

question: What is the length of the copper and the epoxy coating when their temperature increases from 25\({}^{\circ}\)C to 250\({}^{\circ}\)C?
answer:
- Length of Copper: 100.3735 cm
   - Length of Epoxy: 101.2375 cm
